data.topic: a detective solving a mystery in a haunted mansion

data.final_scene:
Gravel cracked under my tires as I pulled onto Greystone’s front drive. The house rose from its oval of lawn like it had been poured from the same gray weather as the sky—slate roof, stone shoulders, a bell tower whose louvers blinked black against the light. Late-afternoon glare scraped the windows. A maple at the turn cast a tangle of shadows over the hood as I eased to a stop beneath the carport’s trussed ribs.

The bell didn’t ring. Nothing rang. My engine ticked, the wind touched the cedar shingles, and somewhere out back a bird gave up on a call halfway through. I cut the ignition and the stillness felt padded, a thick quiet that made the faint scent of diesel—exhaust, familiar and metallic—stand up in the nose. It drifted from the side yard, creeping around the stone like a stubborn perfume.

The front door opened before I got a hand on the handle. Lila filled the frame, thin in a navy cardigan with a clipboard held level as a tray. Her hair was pinned up and already fuzzing in the damp. She didn’t smile; she looked relieved that the distance between us was measurable, numbers she could record.

“You’re on Day Eighty-Three,” she said, as if I should know. Her pen tapped the top of the clipboard, then pointed to a metal sign bolted to the door jamb—white letters on black enamel: ALL CONTRACTORS AND VISITORS MUST SIGN THE STAY LOG.

“Hello to you too,” I said. I hoisted my duffel. “I’m here to—”

“I know why you’re here,” she said briskly. “You’re the one Victor agreed to. You’ll sign in, you’ll wear the badge at all times. Shoes off on the runner only. No rooms without escort, west wing closed, cell phones on silent. It’s all here.” She shifted the clipboard. “It’s called a stay log. We log every day of occupancy to avoid ambiguity.”

“Ambiguity about what?”

“Stay length. Presence. Who is here, when they arrived, when they leave. It matters.” She stepped back only as far as the threshold. “You can come to the rug. Not off it.”

The rug was a long runner that split the entry hall, Persian swirls anchored by brass rods. I put my bags down on the mat outside, peeled my boots off, and carried the duffel to the runner like a pilgrim staying on painted footprints. The hall opened up around us: hewn beams stained nearly black, a staircase with a lion-carved newel, and a tray ceiling inlaid with squares that caught the late light in honey pools. The air carried cool limestone, old polish, and that thread of diesel like a pencil line saved for last.

She held the clipboard out. A bound ledger sat on it, pages onion-thin and ruled, a fountain pen tucked into the spine. The handwriting above the blank line rolled in tidy loops: names, dates, in-and-out times, initials in the margin like checkmarks.

“Print, then sign,” she said. “Both. And write your time of arrival. If you don’t know the exact minute, estimate within five. If you want to dispute a time, annotate, don’t cross out.”

“You sound like a magistrate,” I said, taking the pen.

“I am a property manager,” she said. “And this is not a casual property.”

The nib caught on the paper’s tooth as I wrote my name, the date, 4:37 p.m. Lila craned to see, then drew a neat line beneath and initialed the margin with a practiced flick.

A wall-mounted brass bellpull cord hung nearby. It ended in a tassel the color of dried blood. I touched my knuckle to it and let the fringe brush my skin. No bell answered. Somewhere a motor coughed and died. The diesel edge sharpened then thinned.

“Do you ring that for tea?” I said.

“It’s ornamental,” she said. “Don’t pull it.”

“I wasn’t—”

“You touched it.”

“You’re observant,” I said.

“I have to be.” She slid a plastic holder from a drawer in the entry table and pressed a sticker into it: TEMPORARY GUEST in black, today’s date in red, a square space for a name that she filled with my initials, all caps. A thin lanyard looped like an afterthought. “Wear it high. Not tucked. If it turns around, fix it.”

“I was hoping for something with my picture,” I said. “Hologram, retina scan.”

“If you want a permanent badge, that requires a different agreement.” She clipped the holder to the collar of my jacket herself, fingers quick, the plastic icy through the cloth. “This is sufficient for now.”

“‘For now’ isn’t my favorite phrase.” I looked past her, down the hall. A corridor ran out of the entry at a right angle, and along it hung a wash of portraiture: faces the size of dinner plates and doorframes, gilt frames chunked like cake icing, pale ovals of cheeks. A girl with a violet ribbon looked just over my shoulder, pleased at some private joke. The sconces under their shades breathed an even glow. “I’ll need to see everything,” I said, still watching the corridor. “Attic, mechanicals, tower. Outside structures. I’m not effective if I’m chaperoned.”

“You’ll be escorted,” Lila said, as if she were reading it off a stone. “We’re not casual, we’re not careless, we’re not opening every door because someone asks nicely. Procedures exist for reasons.”

“I can move faster without them.”

“Speed isn’t value,” she said. “Accuracy is. Also: safety. Also: chain of custody, documentation, security.” Her pen was doing that tap again, a pulse against the clipboard. “If you want unfettered access, you’ll ask Victor. He’ll say no.”

“I’ll settle for unfettered for the next hour,” I said. “Let me walk the perimeter and the interior alone and I’ll keep your stay log neat as hospital corners.”

“No.” Her eyes flicked to my duffel. “You can drop that in the mudroom so it’s not in the hall, and you can bring only what you need, and you’ll sign out when you leave each room. The stay log is a log. It contains stays. It documents an exact flow.”

“I get it,” I said. “You like rivers with banks.”

“I like records.” She lifted the pen. “You’ll also note reasons for movement. ‘Inspection,’ ‘assessment,’ ‘meal,’ ‘bathroom.’”

“I have to log bathroom?”

“Everyone does,” she said. “We all agree to the same rules. It makes things…steady.” She didn’t change her tone, but something in the last word relaxed it, like a knot eased with a thumb.

“Alright. Steady it is.” I nodded toward the corridor of faces. “You’re going to walk me through that anyway, I bet.”

“That’s for orientation,” she said. “It’s part of arrival. After you read and sign the house rules.” She turned the ledger’s companion sheet toward me. Laminated, bullet-points. Remove shoes at the door. Do not open windows without approval. Close all doors behind you. No plugs into orange outlets—those are generator-fed. Report smells. Report noises. Report any changes.

“Smells,” I repeated.

“Smoke, gas, ozone, anything unusual. Odors are information,” she said. “Some of us can’t smell everything, so we share.”

“I’m getting diesel. Stronger outside, right side of the house.”

“I’m aware. They ran the generator earlier,” she said. “It lingers. Make note.” She pointed to a smaller notebook on the table—thin, spiral-bound, titled Observations in a hand pretty as a recipe card. “You can write there or tell me, and I’ll write it.”

“I can write it,” I said. I picked up the little notebook. The first page was dated Day One, then Two, and on until today. Each day had columns: time, observation, initial. The script repeated in one neat rhythm: Lila’s. “Do you do all of this yourself?”

“I maintain the stay log and the observation log. If others cooperate, it’s more complete. If they don’t, it’s less so.”

“And today is Day Eighty-Three,” I said. “Since when?”

“Since we returned,” she said. “Does it matter to you?”

“It might.” I wrote: 4:41 p.m. faint diesel odor from right side, persistent drift into entry hall. I initialed with the same block letters. She watched, read, and nodded once, a stamp of approval.

Behind her, the lion carved into the newel post showed its teeth: not a snarl, just polished humor. The entry’s high windows caught a darker seam of cloud and, as if it had been waiting for an entry, a draft curled along the floor, cool against my socks. The tassel of the bellpull fluttered in the edge of it. Lila’s eyes tracked the motion, then returned to mine.

“You’ll be escorted,” she said again, final as a lock clicking. “We can begin the orientation now. Then we can schedule your access to systems.”

“I prefer not to schedule,” I said. “I prefer to move around before the house has time to—”

“This house doesn’t have preferences,” she said. “We do. Put your bag in the mudroom. Right there.” She pointed to a door that opened onto a square of brick and pegs with a few coats, rubber boots in a row, a wire shelf with baskets labeled in the same tidy hand: Rags, Gloves, Flashlights. A box fan rested on its side, a drying rack leaned against the wall. The diesel smell nosed in stronger through a screened vent.

I set the duffel down under the pegs, grabbed my notebook and a small toolkit, slid both into a canvas satchel. When I turned back, Lila lifted a thin brown leather strap from the entry table and looped it over her wrist. It carried a flat ring of keys that chimed softly, a sound more intimate than the absent bell.

“Ready?” she said.

“Steady,” I said.

“Don’t be cute. It wastes time.” She stepped onto the runner, pivoted like a metronome. “We’ll start with portraits. They’re at the heart of the house. You’ll stay on the carpet. You’ll make notes. If you need to touch something, you ask. If I say no, it’s no.”

“And if I say I need to go somewhere without you?”

“Then you’ll wait,” she said. “Or you’ll leave. Those are your options.”

“Not much of a choice.”

“It’s the choice,” she said, and she started down the runner. The frames along the corridor caught her reflection in slices: eyebrow, cheekbone, the line of her mouth. I adjusted the plastic badge at my collar where it had flipped and followed, my voice low enough for the walls to ignore.

“Fine,” I said. “Escort it is.”

Place: Greystone front drive, entry hall
Time: Day 83, late afternoon
Event: I arrive; Lila signs me in and mentions her “stay log.”

data.final_scene:
The office sat just off the foyer behind a door with cloudy glass. Lila keyed it open and let the door swing wide with a restraint that felt practiced. The room was rectangular, spare, the air cooler than the hall. A single window faced a hedge, the light flattened by late cloud. On the wall to the right, a calendar grid was pinned under glass, days crossed with a thin slash, Day 83 boxed in pencil. A low file cabinet ran the opposite wall, its top holding a three-hole punch, a stapler aligned with it, two trays labeled In and Out. The diesel smell was weaker here, edged by dry paper and graphite.

On the desk—walnut, square corners—she’d set a ledger: thick cream pages, bound in green buckram, a cloth ribbon marking a place. A ballpoint lay parallel to the edge. Beside it, a thin laptop hummed, lid closed, and a plastic dish held paperclips arranged like fish bones.

“Sit,” she said, indicating a chair that had no cushion. She remained standing. Her keys rested on the desk, the leather strap looped tight. “This is the stay log. You’ll review it first. Then you can ask questions.”

I stayed standing. “I’ll need the raw entries.”

“This is the log,” she said. “It is the record.”

“What it says. Not the raw entries.”

Her mouth considered that. “This is how the record is kept for the trust. It includes everything material.”

I glanced at the segmented tabs she had added with perfect spacing: Incidents, Bell, Utilities, Access, Guests, Vendor. Each tab had a thin strip of tape with dates in neat caps. The ribbon rested on the Bell section.

“Material by whose standard?” I asked.

“Mine,” she said. “In adherence to policy.” She opened to the tab without looking down. Her nails were clean, short. “We begin the day of arrival, Day zero, and we carry forward. Your interest is late-stage. We won’t re-litigate the first month.”

She angled the book toward me. The first open spread was ruled into columns with headings penciled and then inked over. Date. Time. Location. Description. Action. Witness. Bell Note, a column barely wider than a finger.

“Read.” She stepped back as if distance gave me permission.

The entries marched in small, steady script that looked like a machine had taught a human to write like it.

Day 49 03:12—East hall—single metallic sound (north)—no wind noted—checked bellpull: rope stationary; no movement at hatch; no visible swing in weight—Action: none—Witness: L.

Bell Note: N/A.

Day 53 16:40—Generator test start—diesel odor in foyer and mudroom—Action: opened mudroom window; box fan to exhaust—Witness: L, V—Bell Note: N/A.

Day 59 21:07—Front door latch dropped with pressure change as cold front passed (barometer fell 0.14 inHg within 22 min)—Action: re-latched; set doorblock—Witness: L, C—Bell Note: N/A.

Day 60 11:58—Tour group paused at portrait seven—comment “ringing?” from guest; no audible bell; upstairs register knocking—Action: escorted group to music room; checked duct above portrait seven: loose flange—Witness: L, R—Bell Note: N/A.

She turned the page before I asked her to. The ribbon whispered.

Day 61 02:13—Report (phone) from caretaker at gate: “heard one heavy bell from outside”—No one on interior heard bell; wind light NW; no evidence of movement at bellpull; counterweight at stop—Action: checked tower door from interior: locked—Witness: T—Bell Note: Report outside only.

Day 72 15:09—UPS delivery; driver asked about “the sound last week”—no bell in log last week—Action: N/A—Witness: L—Bell Note: N/A.

Day 78 18:22—CO detector in east generator room test chirp from low battery—Action: battery replaced; reset—Witness: L—Bell Note: N/A.

She tapped the header on the right page with the tip of her nail. “This is what you need.”

“What I need are the slips,” I said. “The original notes. The things written in the middle of a night that got transcribed later to this. The scratch lines.”

“I don’t keep slips,” she said.

“You didn’t at first.” I nodded toward the neatness. “Nobody writes like this at three in the morning while a sound is happening.”

Her gaze flicked to the pencil in the dish, then back. “You’re conflating.”

“Then show me the bell notes.”

She turned to the Bell section. The columns were narrower; the entries were precise.

Day 49—03:12—Report type: in-house—Source: north—Count: 1—Duration: <2 sec—Repeat: no—Concurrent events: return duct tick at 03:11.48—Action: none.

Day 61—02:13—Report type: external caller—Source: undetermined (gate hearing)—Count: 1—Duration: unconfirmed—Repeat: no—Concurrent events: none—Action: logged.

Day 77—12:00—Report type: siren test county—Source: N/A—Count: N/A—Duration: 90 sec—Repeat: quarterly—Concurrent events: front desk pen fell (unknown cause)—Action: none—Note: included for noise baseline.

She had initialed each line—LJ—and drawn a small tick at the edge where her page ruler had been.

“Do you have recordings?” I asked. “Phone audio, camera, anything.”

“No bell recordings exist,” she said.

“How do you know?”

“I manage the systems,” she said. “Nothing captured in-house. Guests do not have camera privileges inside. Exterior is Victor’s domain.”

I read another cluster.

Day 80—05:33—Report type: internal—it read, then: East stair riser creak—Count: N/A—her script was unwavering—Action: checked riser wedge; applied pressure; creak repeatable—Bell Note: N/A.

“You see the pattern,” she said. “You’re here late. You’ll be sleeping on those patterns.”

“Not if I only get the tidy version.” I flipped back to Day 53. “Who else has written in this? I don’t see another hand.”

“No one else is permitted,” she said. “Consistency is the value.”

“I want inconsistency,” I said. “It’s where the truth hides.”

“That’s not a helpful word,” she said, without heat. “Truth. We’re not mythologizing. We’re governing a property. We record. We act. We move on.”

The desk lamp wasn’t on, and I could see the graphite from preliminary pencil marks under the ink in places where she had corrected a time—02:14 overwritten to 02:13—so faint it would vanish in a copy. Under Day 61 there was a small erasure, the paper slightly roughened.

“What did you erase,” I said, tapping it.

She didn’t look. “A redundant comma.”

“Don’t patronize me.”

“I’m not,” she said. “It is not your job to audit my punctuation. It is your job to map drafts and brakes and say which noises are house and which are not. We will support you. You will not waste time reading marginalia for gossip.”

“Where are the margins, then?” I asked. “If not here?”

“In my head,” she said. “Which is why I’m in the room.”

I closed the book halfway and watched her reaction. None. The keys at her wrist were still.

“I’ll need access to whatever raw channels there are,” I said. “Door logs. Call logs. The gate phone history. The WeatherFlow archive. The generator service notes.”

“You will get extracts,” she said. “Requests through me. Nothing leaves this desk.”

“Then I’ll take what I can.” I slid the log back open, angled my satchel open with my hip, brought my phone up, and framed the page so the columns sat square. The shutter made a soft artificial click. I took three, each with a different slant to catch the pencil under-ink.

Lila watched me without moving. The keys tilted and settled.

“You’re not permitted to—” she began, and stopped. “Keep your device in airplane mode in-house.”

“It is,” I said. It was.

“You will not share photographs,” she said. “Until the report is vetted.”

“I will use them to work,” I said. “Which is now.”

She said nothing. I turned a page.

Day 82 14:01—Water hammer in south bath with test of garden hose spigot; pipe reverberation sounded “low”—Action: bled line; added clamp at joist—Witness: T—Bell Note: sound reported by guest as “bell-like,” corrected.

“Who’s T?” I asked.

“Tom.”

“He writes?”

“He reports,” she said. “I write.”

I took a photo of that line and the ones around it. I cropped in on the word “corrected.” I didn’t ask if she objected. She didn’t.

“Where are the call logs,” I asked.

She pivoted, slid open the top drawer of the file cabinet, and pulled out a manila folder with CALLS written on the tab in that same hand. Inside—printouts from the VOIP system, each sheet clipped to the next. She tapped the stack square on the desk and flipped to Day 61. 02:13 From: GATE. Duration: 00:00:41. Notes: “heard one heavy bell from outside.”

“Verbatim,” she said. “I wrote it down while he spoke.”

“Raw audio?”

“There is no audio. The gate phone records and forwards, it doesn’t store.”

“Screenshots?”

“You’re reaching.” She laid the call sheets down but kept a finger on them. “You can have the dates and times. You can cross them against your wanders.”

“I don’t wander,” I said. “I look.”

“Then look,” she said, and lifted her finger.

I shot the page, then the next, flattening the curl with the side of my hand. She didn’t assist; she didn’t block. The diesel smell rose and fell with the door when the foyer breathed.

“Utilities,” I said. “Show me.”

She closed the log, moved it aside, and set a thinner binder down, white with a clear sleeve. Inside: spreadsheets with dates and run-times, the generator line in red.

Day 53—16:40—GEN start—18:10 stop—test cycle per vendor—note: odor noted at foyer/mudroom—window opened.

Day 78—18:22—CO chirp—low battery—replaced.

I photographed those and the bell correlations chart she had made—two axes, two neat lines, one flat.

“You see how I’ve already done the work,” she said. “You’re here to confirm.”

“I see how you’ve organized the work,” I said. “I don’t see the noise.”

She breathed out through her nose. “Noise wastes time.”

“Noise is data,” I said.

“This isn’t a lab,” she said. “This is a house.”

The office sat just off the foyer behind a door with cloudy glass. Lila keyed it open and let the door swing wide with a restraint that felt practiced. The room was rectangular, spare, the air cooler than the hall. A single window faced a hedge, the light flattened by late cloud. On the wall to the right, a calendar grid was pinned under glass, days crossed with a thin slash, Day 83 boxed in pencil. A low file cabinet ran the opposite wall, its top holding a three-hole punch, a stapler aligned with it, two trays labeled In and Out. The diesel smell was weaker here, edged by dry paper and graphite.

On the desk—walnut, square corners—she’d set a ledger: thick cream pages, bound in green buckram, a cloth ribbon marking a place. A ballpoint lay parallel to the edge. Beside it, a thin laptop hummed, lid closed, and a plastic dish held paperclips arranged like fish bones.

“Sit,” she said, indicating a chair that had no cushion. She remained standing. Her keys rested on the desk, the leather strap looped tight. “This is the stay log. You’ll review it first. Then you can ask questions.”

I stayed standing. “I’ll need the raw entries.”

“This is the log,” she said. “It is the record.”

“What it says. Not the raw entries.”

Her mouth considered that. “This is how the record is kept for the trust. It includes everything material.”

I glanced at the segmented tabs she had added with perfect spacing: Incidents, Bell, Utilities, Access, Guests, Vendor. Each tab had a thin strip of tape with dates in neat caps. The ribbon rested on the Bell section.

“Material by whose standard?” I asked.

“Mine,” she said. “In adherence to policy.” She opened to the tab without looking down. Her nails were clean, short. “We begin the day of arrival, Day zero, and we carry forward. Your interest is late-stage. We won’t re-litigate the first month.”

She angled the book toward me. The first open spread was ruled into columns with headings penciled and then inked over. Date. Time. Location. Description. Action. Witness. Bell Note, a column barely wider than a finger.

“Read.” She stepped back as if distance gave me permission.

The entries marched in small, steady script that looked like a machine had taught a human to write like it.

Day 49 03:12—East hall—single metallic sound (north)—no wind noted—checked bellpull: rope stationary; no movement at hatch; no visible swing in weight—Action: none—Witness: L.

Bell Note: N/A.

Day 53 16:40—Generator test start—diesel odor in foyer and mudroom—Action: opened mudroom window; box fan to exhaust—Witness: L, V—Bell Note: N/A.

Day 59 21:07—Front door latch dropped with pressure change as cold front passed (barometer fell 0.14 inHg within 22 min)—Action: re-latched; set doorblock—Witness: L, C—Bell Note: N/A.

Day 60 11:58—Tour group paused at portrait seven—comment “ringing?” from guest; no audible bell; upstairs register knocking—Action: escorted group to music room; checked duct above portrait seven: loose flange—Witness: L, R—Bell Note: N/A.

She turned the page before I asked her to. The ribbon whispered.

Day 61 02:13—Report (phone) from caretaker at gate: “heard one heavy bell from outside”—No one on interior heard bell; wind light NW; no evidence of movement at bellpull; counterweight at stop—Action: checked tower door from interior: locked—Witness: T—Bell Note: Report outside only.

Day 72 15:09—UPS delivery; driver asked about “the sound last week”—no bell in log last week—Action: N/A—Witness: L—Bell Note: N/A.

Day 78 18:22—CO detector in east generator room test chirp from low battery—Action: battery replaced; reset—Witness: L—Bell Note: N/A.

She tapped the header on the right page with the tip of her nail. “This is what you need.”

“What I need are the slips,” I said. “The original notes. The things written in the middle of a night that got transcribed later to this. The scratch lines.”

“I don’t keep slips,” she said.

“You didn’t at first.” I nodded toward the neatness. “Nobody writes like this at three in the morning while a sound is happening.”

Her gaze flicked to the pencil in the dish, then back. “You’re conflating.”

“Then show me the bell notes.”

She turned to the Bell section. The columns were narrower; the entries were precise.

Day 49—03:12—Report type: in-house—Source: north—Count: 1—Duration: <2 sec—Repeat: no—Concurrent events: return duct tick at 03:11.48—Action: none.

Day 61—02:13—Report type: external caller—Source: undetermined (gate hearing)—Count: 1—Duration: unconfirmed—Repeat: no—Concurrent events: none—Action: logged.

Day 77—12:00—Report type: siren test county—Source: N/A—Count: N/A—Duration: 90 sec—Repeat: quarterly—Concurrent events: front desk pen fell (unknown cause)—Action: none—Note: included for noise baseline.

She had initialed each line—LJ—and drawn a small tick at the edge where her page ruler had been.

“Do you have recordings?” I asked. “Phone audio, camera, anything.”

“No bell recordings exist,” she said.

“How do you know?”

“I manage the systems,” she said. “Nothing captured in-house. Guests do not have camera privileges inside. Exterior is Victor’s domain.”

I read another cluster.

Day 80—05:33—Report type: internal—it read, then: East stair riser creak—Count: N/A—her script was unwavering—Action: checked riser wedge; applied pressure; creak repeatable—Bell Note: N/A.

“You see the pattern,” she said. “You’re here late. You’ll be sleeping on those patterns.”

“Not if I only get the tidy version.” I flipped back to Day 53. “Who else has written in this? I don’t see another hand.”

“No one else is permitted,” she said. “Consistency is the value.”

“I want inconsistency,” I said. “It’s where the truth hides.”

“That’s not a helpful word,” she said, without heat. “Truth. We’re not mythologizing. We’re governing a property. We record. We act. We move on.”

The desk lamp wasn’t on, and I could see the graphite from preliminary pencil marks under the ink in places where she had corrected a time—02:14 overwritten to 02:13—so faint it would vanish in a copy. Under Day 61 there was a small erasure, the paper slightly roughened.

“What did you erase,” I said, tapping it.

She didn’t look. “A redundant comma.”

“Don’t patronize me.”

“I’m not,” she said. “It is not your job to audit my punctuation. It is your job to map drafts and brakes and say which noises are house and which are not. We will support you. You will not waste time reading marginalia for gossip.”

“Where are the margins, then?” I asked. “If not here?”

“In my head,” she said. “Which is why I’m in the room.”

I closed the book halfway and watched her reaction. None. The keys at her wrist were still.

“I’ll need access to whatever raw channels there are,” I said. “Door logs. Call logs. The gate phone history. The WeatherFlow archive. The generator service notes.”

“You will get extracts,” she said. “Requests through me. Nothing leaves this desk.”

“Then I’ll take what I can.” I slid the log back open, angled my satchel open with my hip, brought my phone up, and framed the page so the columns sat square. The shutter made a soft artificial click. I took three, each with a different slant to catch the pencil under-ink.

Lila watched me without moving. The keys tilted and settled.

“You’re not permitted to—” she began, and stopped. “Keep your device in airplane mode in-house.”

“It is,” I said. It was.

“You will not share photographs,” she said. “Until the report is vetted.”

“I will use them to work,” I said. “Which is now.”

She said nothing. I turned a page.

Day 82 14:01—Water hammer in south bath with test of garden hose spigot; pipe reverberation sounded “low”—Action: bled line; added clamp at joist—Witness: T—Bell Note: sound reported by guest as “bell-like,” corrected.

“Who’s T?” I asked.

“Tom.”

“He writes?”

“He reports,” she said. “I write.”

I took a photo of that line and the ones around it. I cropped in on the word “corrected.” I didn’t ask if she objected. She didn’t.

“Where are the call logs,” I asked.

She pivoted, slid open the top drawer of the file cabinet, and pulled out a manila folder with CALLS written on the tab in that same hand. “Verbatim,” she said. “I wrote it down while he spoke.”

“Screenshots?”

“I don’t wander,” I said. “I look.”

“Then look,” she said, and lifted her finger.

“Utilities,” I said. “Show me.”

Day 53—16:40—GEN start—18:10 stop—test cycle per vendor—note: odor noted at foyer/mudroom—window opened.

Day 78—18:22—CO chirp—low battery—replaced.

I photographed those and the bell correlations chart she had made—two axes, two neat lines, one flat.

“You see how I’ve already done the work,” she said. “You’re here to confirm.”

“I see how you’ve organized the work,” I said. “I don’t see the noise.”

She breathed out through her nose. “Noise wastes time.”

“This isn’t a lab,” she said. “This is a house.”

data.final_scene:
We left the desk and the grids and the tidy tabs and went into the long throat of the portrait corridor. Evening was a flat blue through the far windows, the kind of light that makes picture varnish feel like ice. The faces on the walls watched us the way weeds look up from a pond—patient, imperturbable, each eye set in its own lacquered weather. Lila didn’t slow; she knew the route and the creaks and the slight buckle in the runner where the tack had let go.

“This is where they always say they hear it,” she said. “Here or on the landing above.”

“Hear what,” I said, though we both knew.

“The bell. When it rings, it’s… it fills this space. It sits in the walls.”

“But not now.”

“Not now,” she said. “Now it’s just a hallway.”

It was not just a hallway. Air moved here in a way it didn’t in the study, more in pulses than draft—breath following breath. Somewhere behind plaster a joist gave a quiet mouse gnaw, wood on metal. The runner carpet exhaled an old soap scent when our feet lifted, and beneath that, faint and sour, a diesel thread. Not the blast you get outside a running unit—this was the after-scent, the slipstream.

I stopped by a portrait of a girl in a yellow dress holding a book whose pages had never been cut. The gilt frame cast a fine shadow-line on the paint. I lifted my hand and felt the wall—cooler at shoulder height than at my waist.

“You’ll find what you’re looking for in the utility wing,” Lila said. “That’s where the smells live. The old place keeps them.”

“The old place doesn’t make diesel,” I said.

“She’s a collector,” Lila said. “She keeps whatever comes to her.”

“She’s a house,” I said. “She moves air.”

“You say that like it’s a choice.”

We moved down a few paces. Along the baseboard there were two iron grilles, painted over six times, the louvers held half-closed by paint and lint, a felt beard along the bottom slot.

“These are returns?” I said.

“From another era,” she said. “We don’t use this zone unless we have guests.”

“Air doesn’t care about your zones.”

“That would be convenient.”

I crouched and put two fingers at the edge where the paint had chipped to metal. The grille hummed with nothing audible, but my knuckles felt the faintest pull inward, a slow inhaling. The diesel note strengthened when I was down low; it sat near the floor, the way cold sits in a cellar.

“Generator ran on Day Fifty-Three,” Lila said, standing with her hands in the sleeves of her sweater like she was warming them. “It ran again on Seventy, and we had the test last week. I logged the times. You have the sheet.”

“And you smelled it here.”

“In passing. Sometimes not at all.”

“Doorways?” I said, pointing toward the cross-corridor. “Which were open.”

“It depends.”

“That’s not a log,” I said. “That’s a shrug.”

She closed her mouth at that, but not in anger. Her face went still, like she was letting a wave pass.

We came to the bell pull near the main landing—braided cord the color of dried blood, ending in a dusty tassel that had knocked its own print into the wall over years. Above it, a small porcelain guide plaque: Ringers. The porcelain was cracked like a dry lake. To the right, a brass indicator board in a shallow box, the kind with room names behind glass. The needles were all at rest.

“You kept this?” I said.

“It came with the house,” she said. “It stays with the house.”

“You use it?”

“No one comes when you pull it. They’ve all got phones.”

I took the cord and weighed it. The tassel was heavy with embedded grit. When I pulled, there was no sound—no bell from any kitchen or pantry, no small civilized note. But there was weight: a slither of rope over a pulley, a feel of something turning somewhere up in the wall and then catching, like a shoulder that had learned to stick. A fine dust discharged at my cuff.

“Nothing,” Lila said, flat, but the word meant she was listening harder.

“Something,” I said. “Just not a bell.”

“Just the old place moving around herself.”

I took another measured pull. The resistance came on fast and then eased as if a counterweight had kissed a stop. No clang, nothing vocal. The brass needles on the indicator board wavered a hair, then settled, as if they remembered the trick but didn’t want to bother.

“You hear that?” I said.

“I hear you,” she said.

I let the cord rest. The diesel trace edged stronger when I stood, as though pulling the rope had brushed air down the cavity. I leaned my ear to the wall and heard the most domestic sound: a duct’s soft whisper somewhere beyond, skin on breath. The corridor’s length took that and made it smaller.

“You smell it now,” I said.

She held still. “I smell the runner and the wax. And yes. A little.”

“Which way is the service wing from here,” I said, though I’d already clocked the turnings.

She pointed past the turn in the corridor where the portraits grew less grand—family faces thinning into landscapes and dogs. “Past the butler’s pantry, then right, then through the mudroom. The generator’s outside, beyond that.”

“Doors between?”

“Three,” she said. “Two we keep shut. The pantry swing door refuses the latch.”

We walked. The diesel thread thickened a degree at the pantry threshold, a notch warmer in the nose. The swing door had indeed given up: the brass tongue didn’t line with the strike, a dropout in the geometry. The pantry smelled of lemon oil and dry sugar and old paper labels—something sweet standing guard over steel shelving. On the far side, the cross-draft from the mudroom corridor pushed gently, not a breeze so much as a suggestion. It moved the edge of a pinned shopping list. I touched the list and felt the tug.

“The old place,” Lila said, not so much arguing now as offering arms to put around a word. “She’s always had currents.”

“Where do the currents start,” I said.

“She’d say the river,” Lila said. “If she talked.”

“She talks like a generator vent,” I said, and she almost smiled, then didn’t.

We went right. The runner stopped and wood took over, bare and glossy with that rubbed-dry finish that tells you a hundred feet have passed and fifteen hands have buffed a stain with the side of a sleeve. Diesel picked up again as the space narrowed. At ankle height a thin line of daylight cut under the mudroom door like a scalpel. The trim had pulled away from the plaster. A crack ran from the miter down to the baseboard where someone had caulked and the caulk had dried to a brittle crust.

“Hold there,” I said, and flattened my hand over the crack. Air moved—not blasting, not a leak, but a faint, steady sibilant draw. Behind the door, metal clicked—cooling, the sound of outside hardware relenting its heat.

“You’re building a crime scene in your head,” she said. “I can see it. Angles and charts.”

“I’m building a map,” I said.

“Of a smell.”

“Of a pathway,” I said. “Smell is the tracer.”

She leaned her shoulder to the wall opposite, careful not to touch the portrait of a hound with a ribbon. “Pathway to what.”

“Where air comes from and where it goes.”

“Out, in, out, in,” she said, a metronome. “That’s the whole story.”

“Maybe,” I said. “Maybe the whole story is a swing door that won’t latch and a mudroom with a leaking seal and a return grille painted shut that still pulls.”

“And the old place is innocent,” she said, as if trying on the fit of the word on her tongue.

“She does what she’s built to do,” I said.

From somewhere along the corridor a clock struck six in measured brass. It didn’t echo here; it hung like pins in fabric. The diesel thread faltered and came again. I put my face near the crack and tasted the faint metallic after-bite that fuel leaves on the back of the throat, even when it’s hours old. Not hot. Not fresh. But present.

“Victor says the service wing is closed after five,” Lila said.

“Closed and sealed aren’t the same,” I said. “What’s behind this door?”

“Mudroom. Boot trays. The laundry. The back hall to the service stairs.”

“Stairs up or down?”

“Both.”

I nodded, just once, to myself. Then back, retracing the corridor the way a dog learns a yard—returning to the places where the smell had not been, checking them for absence. The odor faded as we passed the pantry and softened near the bell pull, thinned further under the gaze of the yellow-dress girl, then returned in a small pulse by the first of the returns. I knelt at each grille in turn, palm hovering, then touching metal, fingers to baseboard gaps, noting temperature differences like small hills. Lila said nothing until I stood again and brushed dust from my pants.

“You’re going to measure all this,” she said, a statement, not a question.

“Yes.”

“And then you’ll tell me it was a draft.”

“I’ll tell you where the draft runs.”

She looked past me to the far end where the corridor met the foyer and the evening gathered in the glass of the sidelights. “Do you have to name it for it to stop.”

“It doesn’t stop because you name it,” I said. “It stops because you change what moves.”

“The old place won’t like that,” she said, but lightly, as if saying it made it smaller and safer.

I set my back to the portraits and let my eyes travel the line we had walked, mapping the sequence: foyer breath, then the faint pull at the first grille; the dead bell pull catching on its pulley and the small discharge of dust; the pantry swing door with the lazy latch; the mudroom seam glowing with a knife of light and a steady draw; the stair door somewhere beyond that, up and down to other pressures. In my head, not lines but a band of current, drawn in graphite, shading heavier toward the service wing. Diesel sat in that shading like dye in water.

“Okay,” I said. “We’ll start with the mudroom door.”

“We keep it closed,” she said, as if that were an answer and also a request.

“Closed isn’t sealed,” I said.

She didn’t roll her eyes. She did a small thing with her mouth, a pinched smile that might have been irritation if it weren’t tired. “I’ll get you tape.”

“I have tape.”

“Of course you do,” she said. “You have everything.”

“Not yet.”

She stepped back down the corridor, the portraits resuming their silent procession on either side. “I’ll show you the service stairs,” she said over her shoulder. “Since you’re drawing your invisible maps.”

“I am.”

“And the bell,” she added, one hand lifting to the dead pull without touching it. “You can pretend it’s part of your ductwork.”

“I don’t pretend,” I said.

“You’re right,” she said placidly. “You look.”

We moved toward the service wing, and the corridor kept breathing, and the odor, slight and stubborn, kept pointing.

“And the old place is innocent,” she said, as if trying on the fit of the word on her tongue.

“She does what she’s built to do,” I said.

From somewhere along the corridor a clock struck six in measured brass. It didn’t echo here; it hung like pins in fabric. The diesel thread faltered and came again. I put my face near the crack and tasted the faint metallic after-bite that fuel leaves on the back of the throat, even when it’s hours old. Not hot. Not fresh. But present.

“Victor says the service wing is closed after five,” Lila said.

“Closed and sealed aren’t the same,” I said. “What’s behind this door?”

“Mudroom. Boot trays. The laundry. The back hall to the service stairs.”

“Stairs up or down?”

“Both.”

I nodded, just once, to myself. Then back, retracing the corridor the way a dog learns a yard—returning to the places where the smell had not been, checking them for absence. The odor faded as we passed the pantry and softened near the bell pull, thinned further under the gaze of the yellow-dress girl, then returned in a small pulse by the first of the returns. I knelt at each grille in turn, palm hovering, then touching metal, fingers to baseboard gaps, noting temperature differences like small hills. Lila said nothing until I stood again and brushed dust from my pants.

“You’re going to measure all this,” she said, a statement, not a question.

“Yes.”

“And then you’ll tell me it was a draft.”

“I’ll tell you where the draft runs.”

She looked past me to the far end where the corridor met the foyer and the evening gathered in the glass of the sidelights. “Do you have to name it for it to stop.”

“It doesn’t stop because you name it,” I said. “It stops because you change what moves.”

“The old place won’t like that,” she said, but lightly, as if saying it made it smaller and safer.

I set my back to the portraits and let my eyes travel the line we had walked, mapping the sequence: foyer breath, then the faint pull at the first grille; the dead bell pull catching on its pulley and the small discharge of dust; the pantry swing door with the lazy latch; the mudroom seam glowing with a knife of light and a steady draw; the stair door somewhere beyond that, up and down to other pressures. In my head, not lines but a band of current, drawn in graphite, shading heavier toward the service wing. Diesel sat in that shading like dye in water.

“Okay,” I said. “We’ll start with the mudroom door.”

“We keep it closed,” she said, as if that were an answer and also a request.

“Closed isn’t sealed,” I said.

She didn’t roll her eyes. She did a small thing with her mouth, a pinched smile that might have been irritation if it weren’t tired. “I’ll get you tape.”

“I have tape.”

“Of course you do,” she said. “You have everything.”

“Not yet.”

She stepped back down the corridor, the portraits resuming their silent procession on either side. “I’ll show you the service stairs,” she said over her shoulder. “Since you’re drawing your invisible maps.”

“I am.”

“And the bell,” she added, one hand lifting to the dead pull without touching it. “You can pretend it’s part of your ductwork.”

“I don’t pretend,” I said.

“You’re right,” she said placidly. “You look.”

We moved toward the service wing, and the corridor kept breathing, and the odor, slight and stubborn, kept pointing.

The library had two fireplaces and a single source of heat: the morning sun, flattening across the rug and waking the old leather smell under the polish. Victor stood in it as if he’d arranged it for his suit, hands hooked in his pockets, jacket open, tie knotted the way a knife ties a knot. He didn’t sit. He had a folder under his arm and a thin stack of papers in his hand like playing cards he intended to control.

“Day eighty-four,” he said, without looking at the clock or a calendar. “Let’s be efficient.”

“I like efficient,” I said. I set my case on the long walnut table and opened it. The table had been scrubbed so many times the grain showed its ruts like dried riverbeds. He remained standing. I remained standing.

“This is the engagement letter,” he said, sliding the top page toward me with one finger. “And the work order. It reflects your… scope.” He stretched the vowel just enough to suggest it was suspect. “Twenty-four to forty-eight hours would be ideal.”

I read the header, the footers, the dense center. My thumbnail picked up the edge of the paper the way you test a bill. “My scope is three phases,” I said. “Walkthrough, baseline, interventions. I don’t do forty-eight.”

“Then let’s call it seventy-two,” he said immediately, as if he’d brought the concession with him pre-warmed in his pocket. “But we need clarity on deliverables.”

“Data logs, maps, photographs, recommendations.” I didn’t look up. “And a classification. Mechanical, electrical, atmospheric, acoustic. Or unknown.”

His eyes flicked. “Or paranormal.”

“No,” I said. “I don’t use paranormal.”

“We can debate nomenclature,” he said, flipping the next page toward me like a new card in a losing hand. “However. The trust requires a categorical determination. If phenomena cannot be resolved within a reasonable period, they must be named for risk management purposes. We cannot leave things in an indeterminate state.”

“You can,” I said. “People do. But you don’t want to.”

“What I don’t want,” he said evenly, “is for Ms. Greystone to drift into noncompliance because an investigator refuses to say what is present in her house.”

He let that hang for a moment, then tapped the bold paragraph blocked in the center of the page. “Abandonment,” he said. “You should be aware of this clause.”

I read it. I read it again. “Abandonment,” I said, “is defined as vacating the primary residence for more than seventy-two continuous hours without designated caretaker occupancy, not including medical emergencies or force majeure.”

“And,” he said, “should an independent expert conclude that occupancy presents ‘a credible threat beyond reasonable mitigation measures,’ the clock triggers immediately. You are the independent expert.”

“I’m here to measure pressure differentials and kinks in ductwork, not pronounce a haunting,” I said, still reading. “I don’t consider superstitions credible threats.”

He smiled in a way that didn’t warm anything. “No one used the word haunting,” he said. “We need a category to inform insurers and trustees. The word is not a moral judgment. It is a box on a form.”

“My box is ‘unresolved physical cause,’ if necessary,” I said. “That is a form.”

“That is a hedge,” he said. “And hedges cost us time.”

He moved, finally, around the corner of the table, unspooling a pen. It was heavy, engraved, and made me think not of writing but of signatures made to feel inevitable. He put it on the paper and clicked it. The click rang too loud in the paneled room and vanished into the books.

“Walk me through your phases,” he said. “Every hour. I need to know what I can tell the board.”

“Today,” I said, “I map the return paths, check for bypasses, isolate drafts, and place monitors. That requires access to the service wing, the attic hatch, and the subpanel in the pantry. I’ll need to tape certain seams, wedge certain doors, and I’ll be killing a few circuits for short bursts. I’ll also be placing CO detectors and temperature loggers.”

“You will not be obstructing egress,” he said, not asking.

“No,” I said. “And I won’t be sealing anything in a way that violates code. Painter’s tape, rope wedges, foam gaskets. Reversible, documented.”

“And you will not be altering the property in any way that would create the appearance of tampering.” He had the rhythm of a deposition.

“I document before adjustment,” I said. “Video, stills, time stamps, with you or your designee initialing a log. Chain of custody for any objects removed or inspected.”

He nodded, satisfied and irritated at the same time, as if my answer had cost him opportunities to object later. “Ms. Greystone is… suggestible,” he said, as if that were a technical term. “We need to avoid reinforcing certain narratives.”

“I don’t tell clients stories,” I said. “I tell them what moves air and what hums. If they want a story, they can hire someone else.”

“Don’t be precious,” Victor said, almost gently. “Everyone hires stories. I’m hiring a result.” He tapped the abandonment clause again. “The result is: the house can be lived in without triggering penalties. Or it cannot.”

“And you think if I say ‘paranormal’ you get to move her,” I said, flipping to the back where the signatures waited in their solemn boxes.

He didn’t answer that. He straightened the pen so it sat perfectly parallel to the paper’s margin. “What I think,” he said, “is that we are at day eighty-four. And the previous consultant—”

“Don’t care,” I said.

“—declined to commit,” he finished, with no visible reaction to the interruption. “Ambiguity looks like dereliction in front of a trustee. We are not going to be ambiguous at day eighty-seven.”

“Seventy-two hours,” I said. “No categorical call until then. I don’t need you to agree with my methods. I need you not to interfere.”

“I don’t interfere,” he said. “I set parameters. Appendix C.” He slid another page across, full of small type that had sharp little teeth. “No dissemination of raw data without prior approval. No statements to press, social media, or neighbors. You coordinate all communications through me.”

“I don’t talk to press,” I said. “I talk to my equipment and whoever pays me.”

“I’m very grateful,” he said, without warmth. “Fees. Let’s address them. We’ll release the initial retainer today upon receipt of a signed work order and your insurance certificate. Additional releases are contingent on delivery of logs and your preliminary memorandum at the twenty-four-hour mark.”

“No,” I said. “Twenty-four-hour memo is a waste. You’ll get a preliminary at forty-eight. Retainer on signing. Balance on delivery of final report.”

He opened his mouth. I raised a finger, not to silence him, but to mark the precise second the negotiation turned.

“You also get,” I said, “a field diary with time stamps, accessible in read-only. You get door and panel disturbance logs. You get circuit maps as I complete them. You don’t get a premature classification that triggers a clause before I have baselines.”

“Forty-eight preliminary,” he repeated, as if testing the fit of the compromise on his tongue. He looked at the pen, at the papers, at my face. “And seventy-two for your final.”

“Seventy-two for my classification,” I said. “Final report can take longer for formatting and cross-references. The classification is the piece you say you need.”

“And in the interim,” he said carefully, “you do not, to anyone, suggest that the cause is… nonphysical.”

“I don’t suggest causes,” I said. “I state findings. If someone asks me if the house is haunted, my answer is that the house has air, heat, mass, openings, and people.”

He stared at me for a long moment. I let the silence sit, the kind of silence lawyers think they own but engineers cultivate differently. It filled the books, ran along the ladder rails, moved through the vents behind the wall. Somewhere far away the clock over the front hall clicked.

“You will not advise Ms. Greystone to vacate,” he said finally. “Unless there is a demonstrable, immediate hazard.”

“Correct,” I said. “And if there is, I’ll shut it down and you’ll see the numbers.”

“We agree on numbers,” he said, and something in his posture loosened by a millimeter. He reached for the pen, took it between two fingers, and twirled it once. “One more thing. Access to the ledger cabinet in the study is restricted. You do not need it for your… ducts.”

“I don’t do ledgers,” I said. “I do returns.”

“The bell,” he said, testing me. “Do you do the bell?”

“I do the opening where the bell rope passes the ceiling,” I said. “If air moves there, I map it. If it doesn’t, I move on.”

“Very good,” he said. He put the pen to the paper and signed in a clean, slanted hand, the kind of signature that had practiced making ink look irrevocable. He turned the pages toward me, already flipped to the spots where he wanted me to lay my name down. “Initial the abandonment clause.”

I read it again before I initialed. “This clause,” I said, tapping the sentence about an independent expert, “does not obligate me to use your categories. It obligates me to state whether there is a credible threat beyond reasonable mitigation.”

“Of course,” he said, as if that were what he’d said all along.

“I’ll put that in the addendum.”

He closed his eyes and opened them again and considered whether to argue from fatigue or from pride. “Draft your addendum,” he said. “I’ll countersign.”

I wrote it in neat block letters on a blank sheet from my case, stapled it to his stack, and slid the whole bundle back. He read, lips moving once over the line about categories, then once again over the line about access to panels and hatches. He initialed each page with identical care, then set the pen down with a small click that this time didn’t echo.

“Seventy-two hours,” he said, as if trying the sound of it for its weakness. “No premature call.”

“Seventy-two,” I said. “No premature anything.”

He gave a small, almost imperceptible shrug, as if sacrificing a very small animal to appease a very distant god. “I’ll expect your first map by four,” he said. “And a door and window status every six hours.”

“You’ll have them,” I said.

He collected the papers, aligned their corners, squared them on the table. The morning had gone from gold to white. Dust motes hung at careful attention between us.

“Do you require anything else?” he asked.

“Someone to keep the kitchen door from being propped open,” I said. “And Conrad to leave the mudroom alone while I tape.”

“I’ll inform staff,” he said, which was not the same as agreeing, but not the same as refusing. “And your insurance certificate?”

I slid it over. He glanced, nodded, tucked it under the stack. He buttoned his jacket. I latched my case.

At the door he paused, turning back with that administrative courtesy that covers a multitude of motives. “Remember,” he said. “The clause exists to prevent harm.”

“I’ll prevent harm,” I said. “That’s why you hired me.”

He let the door swing slowly behind him instead of closing it, and his footsteps crossed the parquet and diminished. I waited until I could no longer hear them, then put my palms flat on the table and looked at the grain again—those dry riverbeds, running their maps in wood. Seventy-two hours, I said to myself. Then I took the painter’s tape from my case and went to find the drafts.

data.final_scene:
The service door stuck on the swollen jamb, then gave with a grainy sigh that pushed a square of bright cold into the mudroom. The smell hit first—wet gravel, warm rubber, and the sour sweetness of spilled lawn fuel that never truly leaves a place like this. Beyond the threshold, the gravel lot was sunstruck and white, the kind of glare that makes shadows look like precision cuts. The kitchen’s extractor fan thudded a steady pulse behind me, the ductwork clicking as it cooled.

Conrad’s SUV sat a little crooked on the far side, nose angled toward the trash corral as if it had meant to slip through and changed its mind. A matte gray Range Rover, the good kind, with its rear window dusted in dried river freckles and the lower doors mottled from a day that had gone past the pavement. The tires were still bearded with mud in the grooves, not caked, but present enough to write a story if you knew the alphabet.

“Hey,” I said, stepping off the concrete apron and under the thin strip of shade cast by the eave. Gravel scraped under my boots, that brittle beach-sound. “You got a minute?”

He was at the open hatch, arm deep, rummaging in a crate of contractor rags. He straightened in one smooth levered movement, a rag in hand. Conrad in daylight was all angles softened by familiarity—blond beard kept short, jaw a little too determined, eyes the near-colorless kind that read as blue if you wanted them to. He wore a Greystone maintenance polo faded to a memory of navy, and jeans that had earned their white paint flicks honestly. He tipped his chin in an acknowledgement that could be read as yes, no, or what now.

“Morning,” he said. “You need something fixed?”

“Not yet,” I said. “I’m doing a perimeter walk, and you’re in my path.”

He grinned a little. “Then I’ll step aside.”

I didn’t move aside. I crouched instead, let my case thump lightly at my heel, and looked at his rear tires. The mud had dried to an ocher crust, flecked with darker grit. The center blocks had a staggered rectangle pattern with a snipe cut at the corner; the shoulder lugs stepped in alternating pairs. There was a chip out of one of the outer lugs, front driver’s side, fresh enough that the torn rubber still showed a matte underbelly. In the gravel, the tread stamped itself like a negative, wide, confident, a little arrogant. There were also sidewall scuffs, gray on gray.

He watched me watching. “They’re new,” he said. “You like tires?”

“I like whatever brings dirt inside,” I said. I pointed with two fingers at the step pattern. “These from town or farther?”

Conrad wiped his hands. “Potholes out by the mill road will put those on anything.”

“The mill road’s paved,” I said. “Mostly. This looks like you climbed a wet shoulder and made it work for you.”

“Or I drove through the employee lot when the trash truck leaked.” He tossed the rag into the crate. “What are we doing?”

“Routes,” I said, straightening. The sun found the metal of my tape measure and glanced off it hard. “Victor wants me to track open doors and drafts. I want to know where people are at night. You were on late last night?”

He rolled one shoulder. “A bit.”

“Define a bit.”

“Till after ten.”

“Doing what?”

He nodded at the house. “House things.”

“Which house things?”

“Bulb in the second-floor laundry, reset the dishwasher, moved a dehumidifier.”

“Where’d you park when you did those things?”

“Here,” he said, as if surprised there were other options.

“This is fresh,” I said, nodding toward the dry sausages of mud braided in his tread. “And your tracks cut over the earlier ones like you swung in and out after midnight.”

“Could be deliveries,” he said.

“Not after midnight.”

He smiled, the friendly kind that offers a truce you haven’t asked for. “You were watching the clock?”

“I was mapping breakers,” I said. “There’s a difference.”

“Sure,” he said.

I walked behind the Rover, stepping over the ridge where the rear tires had pushed the gravel into a berm. The hatch was open; tools nested in foam cutouts, a coil of extension cord, a box of nitrile gloves. The rear bumper showed a smear the color of coffee with too much cream, as if someone had leaned a wet board and let it slither home.

“How many stops?” I asked.

“At night? Depends.” He reached past me and clicked the hatch down with two fingers. His hands were big, nails clean. “You want me to keep a log now?”

“I’d like to know your route last night.”

He looked out at the treeline instead of at me; the wind moved through the honeysuckle vine strangling the fence, and a paper grocery sack folded and unfolded itself by the trash corral like a breathing thing. He let the silence not be awkward.

“Same as most nights,” he said finally. “Up the lane to the gate, back to the shop, around.”

“Up the lane to the gate,” I repeated. “In the Rover.”

“What else would I take, a wheelbarrow?”

“Some people walk.”

“Some people have keys,” he said, not unkindly.

I crouched again, this time at the front passenger side, and pinched a pinch of dried mud from the wheel well. It came away as a flake, grainy between finger and thumb. “The lane’s the property till the mailbox.”

“And the mailbox is the county,” he said. “Now we’re geographers.”

“Before the mailbox,” he said.

“Which side.”

“The lane has one side,” he said. “It goes and it comes back.”

At the threshold he stopped and looked back at the Rover like a man checking he’d left the stove off. Then he was inside and the door sighed and skimmed shut behind him.

I squatted again and traced the shoulder lug with one knuckle, counting the step pattern, then moved to the gravel, where the tire had pressed its geometry into stone. I took another photo, then one more from knee height, because angles matter, then I stood and let the sun make my eyes water and blinked it clear. Then, under it, another line, the kind I kept to myself.

Conrad—watch list. Cagey on routes. Engages but withholds. Avoids specifics. Tires tell more than he does.

data.final_scene:
Day 84, midday

The basement electrical room had a smell all old basements get—warm dust and paint baked a hundred times over, a chalky mineral damp that sat behind your teeth. Fluorescents hummed, their ballasts whining a narrow note that made it easy to find the one tube with a stutter. A pair of gray panels stood side by side on the cinderblock wall like mismatched refrigerators, their doors scuffed with decades of knuckles. Beside them, someone had mounted a bakelite switch box straight onto wood, its toggle polished to a dull tea color by hands that were all dead now. Two newer subpanels lurked lower, labeled with the manufacturer’s slick font and someone’s drunk handwriting: WNSR? E WNG? BOILER? The question marks had their own dust.

I set my case on an upside-down milk crate and clicked open the latches. Tape, Sharpies, labeler, the tone generator, a bag of neon plugs with little LEDs that promised the world and delivered pass/fail. I stuck a strip of blue tape along the long spine of the main panel door and wrote in block letters: GREYSTONE / MAIN / DAY 84 / MAP IN PROGRESS—DO NOT TOUCH.

“You looking for permission to touch it anyway,” Tom said from the doorway.

He had a rag flung over his shoulder and a pair of green earplugs hanging around his neck like candy. His boots left print islands on the dusty floor.

“I’m looking for everything,” I said. “I’ll keep the kitchen intact.”

“You keep the ovens and the hoods on, no one will throw a pan at you. I told them twelve twenty to one you’d be fiddling.”

I checked the time. Twelve twelve. “I’ll start with the ballroom and the north hall. You feel like running?”

“I’m on a sink,” he said, not apologizing. “Lila’s upstairs. She said she’d be your canary.”

I took the radio he offered. It had a strip of tape on the side with LILA in ink that had bled. I clipped it to my belt and turned it down until the squawk wasn’t a threat.

“Anything that explodes if I breathe on it?” I asked him.

He pointed with his chin to the right-hand main. “Middle row, fourth down—tags say ‘parlor west’ but it’s the fire panel. Don’t touch it. Anything else, you blow it, you put it back. You got your ears on, you’ll hear yelling fast.”

“Understood.”

He grinned and went, his boots ticking off down the hall.

The panel door’s spring creaked like an old knee. Inside: a neat column of breakers marching, then an ugly tangle below where someone had doubled up neutrals and then third-thought better of it. The labeling was a palimpsest: pencil, then ballpoint, then Sharpie over tape over old brittle paper. “Study sconces.” “West wing bath 2?” “Roof lights (no).” A marriage of codes and improvisation.

“Lila, you with me?” I said into the radio.

A second’s static, then her voice, bright and thin with the compression. “I’m in the big hall with the ugly Flemish chairs. I’ve got the dragon lamp plugged into a strip. Ready on your mark.”

“Copy.” I taped a numbered blank next to breaker one and wrote 1. Clicked it off. “One.”

The fluorescent hum stuttered, recovered. No change in the room. Down the hall, nothing. The radio hissed.

“Nothing in the dragon,” Lila said. “But a ceiling light just blinked if that’s cheating.”

“Not cheating. Two.” Off. “Three.” Off. “Four.”

At four the basement went quieter, a fan winding down somewhere in a distant wall. The radio made a soft bump sound, Lila adjusting on whatever banister she’d decided was a perch.

“Dragon stays smug,” she said. “The chandelier in the little blue salon died and the thermostat is making a face.”

“Blue salon is four,” I said, writing it. I clicked four back on and the fan started its sighing acceleration. I waited for it to hit its stride before touching five.

We worked the first panel like a metronome. I numbered, I toggled. I made notes in my grid—Blue Salon Chandelier: 4. North Hall Sconces: 7. East Wing First Floor Outlets (half-switched): 9. Twice, the radio snapped with a cook’s cussedness when I dropped a circuit that fed a plug the rolling warmer shouldn’t have been on anyway. Twice, I put it back, wrote a thick caution flag: Service Corridor—Avoid 12–1.

On thirteen I got my reward. “Dragon dead!” Lila said, delighted as if she’d won at a claw machine. “And—wait—dragon still dead, but now there’s a smell.”

“What smell?”

“Ozone? The cheap way. Like when my cousin used to zap herself on the trampoline.”

I put thirteen on and off again, then left it off. I went up the steps into the long north hall—the one with the portraits that watched everything—and found Lila with a ceramic beast under one armpit, its cord trailing. The dragon’s face had been painted with a delicate hand and then chipped by time until it looked like it had survived a coup.

“Outlet’s scorched,” she said, tilting it with one wrist. Inside the duplex you could see the faint brown tide-line around the slots where some loose stab had been heating for months.

“Plug that into the strip over there,” I said. “I’ll mark this.”

I knelt, stuck a square of tape on the plate, and wrote: 13/SCORCH—REPLACE. I pulled the plate with my driver and saw what I had expected: a stab-in connection backing out of the receptacle’s back; cloth-sheathed cable with a recent pigtail crammed in. Someone had saved themselves three minutes ten years ago.

“You okay if I take this down now?” I held the faceplate up.

“You’re asking me permission?” she said, amused.

“Someone has to. The house won’t give it.”

I put the plate back for now, left the mark, and clicked thirteen on long enough for the dragon to glow smug again in its new safe plug. Then we went back to the basement and finished the main.

Halfway through the left-hand panel Victor arrived with his tie loosened one notch and a contract rolled in his hand like it might be a baton. He didn’t come inside. He stood in the doorway where the light fell on his shirt and carefully didn’t on his eyes.

“Is this going to lean on life-safety,” he said, no hello.

“No,” I said. “I’m leaving the fire panel and the sump circuits alone.”

“Good,” he said. His gaze went to the tape on the breaker door. He read my labels with that narrow lawyer’s frown that tries to extract force from paper. “We have an abandonment clause the insurer cares very much about. They are twitchy.”

“You told me,” I said.

“You flick lights off in three rooms and they’ll say no one’s living here, they’ll be that literal.”

“I’m keeping occupancy signals. Kitchen stays hot. Two bathrooms lit. Radios on. You’ll be fine.”

He unrolled the contract, as if measuring my panel labeling against it. “The bell is not to be touched,” he said, as if that were part of a breaker map. “The camera footage is under separate agreement. The generator is fuel-limited. The lawyers on the other side are worse than a balky well.”

“Understood.”

“I want your map. When you have it. A copy.” He pivoted the contract back into a cylinder and thumped it against his palm. “Details matter.”

“That’s why I’m here.”

He made a sound like he agreed but didn’t like that he did. “Carry on.” He left a shadow shape at the threshold that looked like a crossbar until he was gone and it moved.

When I flipped “parlor west” by accident and the fire panel squawked, I learned the exact tone of Tom’s boots at speed. He appeared in the doorway with one green earplug out, saw the breaker already back, saw my hand already rewiring my own caution. He nodded once, a half smile as if to say he’d bet two dollars and had just won.

“Old labels lie,” he said.

“No one writes them to be read,” I said.

He hooked a thumb at the low subpanel. “Laundry. Half the guest wing behaves from there. No one knows why. Don’t kill the iron; Lana will hunt you.”

“I’ll map around them.”

He went again, and I went to work on the subs.

At the lower right panel the neatness fell off a cliff. Doubled taps on the main lugs. A breaker feeding a breaker feeding a junction box whose cover was held with one screw. A whisper of diesel came in around the duct where it had a rip in its foil tape, and I could feel with the heel of my hand the warm exhale that lived down there even at midday.

“Okay,” I said to myself, to the room, to the house. “We do it in small mouthfuls.”

I set my tone generator at an outlet in the servants’ hall, clipped the alligator to the ground, and went hunting with the wand. It chittered when I passed a run of conduit, then went silent, then screamed at a plaster wall where there was nothing visible. Someone had buried a junction and painted over it with the same conviction they brought to labeling. I marked the wall with tape: TONE HI—TRACE UP.

I worked a grid. North hall, main breaker map keys 1–20 done. East wing first floor, subpanel A 1–12. I made little drawings as I went, rectangles for rooms, poached eggs for fixtures, lines with arrows for what ran what. Lila moved around above me like a bright little echo. “Now the blue bedroom.” “Now the pantry.” “Wait, Lana says not the pantry, not for love or money.” I circled PANTRY in a red pen and wrote: SKIP—1–2.

When the lights were mapped enough that Victor’s abstraction could relax, I took the smoke pencil and the tissue streamers up into the halls. The ceiling height changed the way the air moved—taller near the portrait corridor, lower in the servants’ run. The thresholds had their own weather. You could put your hand an inch off the floor and feel a thread of river air sneaking under the east door, a cool band notched between warm. I taped tissue to the jamb with two tiny blue flags and watched the way the fringe moved. A slow draw into the stairwell where the sealed service stair sat behind a smooth sheet of plywood that kept its secrets by doing nothing at all. In the main hall, the movement was lazy, coming and going as a door somewhere opened and shut. At the loading door to the service court, the tissue kicked hard, then stilled, then moved again as the kitchen hoods cycled.

“Can you open the mudroom door and then close it?” I asked Lila on the radio.

“Copy,” she said.

The tissue jumped when she opened it. It settled on the close but didn’t fully stop. I put my smoke pencil under the threshold, pressed the bulb, and watched the thin line bend with obedience. The smoke went under and kept going; the outside air was low, the inside high. I chalked a small arrow on the baseboard pointing in with a little X and wrote: DRAFT HOTSPOT—MUDROOM. Two arrows at the east door. A circle and HRR at the basement stair where the cat door flapped in a current I could almost see.

Lana found me by the service door with a paring knife in her hand and the look of a person who won’t let you cost her prep time. “If this is going to mess with my flames,” she said, “tell me now.”

“It isn’t,” I said. “I’m marking where cold air is sneaking in. If I don’t do it now, I’ll do it during service, and you’ll like that less.”

“What’s it saying now.”

He nodded. “And?”

He made a satisfied noise. “Better than most people. Better than the outfit before you. They put a little digital box on the wall and called it a prayer.”

“Those work if you also move your hands.”

I pinned the final map inside the left-hand panel door with two magnets I found on a dead clip and stood back until the whole ugly cluster of metal and wire looked less like chaos and more like something I owned a little bit.

Then I folded my smoke pencil into its case, wrote my draft notes into the log in the tight script the diary pages liked, and wrote at the bottom: breaker map completed; draft hotspots marked; kitchen undisturbed; occupancy maintained. I put the pen down, wiped the black smudge off my right thumb with the rag Tom had left, and let the house take a long breath I could finally read.

The basement electrical room had a smell all old basements get—warm dust and paint baked a hundred times over, a chalky mineral damp that sat behind your teeth. Beside them, someone had mounted a bakelite switch box straight onto wood, its toggle polished to a dull tea color by hands that were all dead now. I set my case on an upside-down milk crate and clicked open the latches. He had a rag flung over his shoulder and a pair of green earplugs hanging around his neck like candy. His boots left print islands on the dusty floor.

“I’m on a sink,” he said, not apologizing. “Lila’s upstairs. She said she’d be your canary.”

A second’s static, then her voice, bright and thin with the compression. “I’m in the big hall with the ugly Flemish chairs. I’ve got the dragon lamp plugged into a strip. Ready on your mark.”

“Copy.” I taped a numbered blank next to breaker one and wrote 1. Clicked it off. “One.”

The fluorescent hum stuttered, recovered. No change in the room. Down the hall, nothing. The radio hissed.

“Nothing in the dragon,” Lila said. “But a ceiling light just blinked if that’s cheating.”

“Not cheating. Two.” Off. “Three.” Off. “Four.”

At four the basement went quieter, a fan winding down somewhere in a distant wall. The radio made a soft bump sound, Lila adjusting on whatever banister she’d decided was a perch.

“Dragon stays smug,” she said. “The chandelier in the little blue salon died and the thermostat is making a face.”

“Blue salon is four,” I said, writing it. I clicked four back on and the fan started its sighing acceleration. I waited for it to hit its stride before touching five.

On thirteen I got my reward. “Dragon dead!” Lila said, delighted as if she’d won at a claw machine. “And—wait—dragon still dead, but now there’s a smell.”

“What smell?”

“Ozone? The cheap way. Like when my cousin used to zap herself on the trampoline.”

I put thirteen on and off again, then left it off. I went up the steps into the long north hall—the one with the portraits that watched everything—and found Lila with a ceramic beast under one armpit, its cord trailing. The dragon’s face had been painted with a delicate hand and then chipped by time until it looked like it had survived a coup.

“Outlet’s scorched,” she said, tilting it with one wrist. Inside the duplex you could see the faint brown tide-line around the slots where some loose stab had been heating for months.

“Plug that into the strip over there,” I said. “I’ll mark this.”

I knelt, stuck a square of tape on the plate, and wrote: 13/SCORCH—REPLACE. I pulled the plate with my driver and saw what I had expected: a stab-in connection backing out of the receptacle’s back; cloth-sheathed cable with a recent pigtail crammed in. Someone had saved themselves three minutes ten years ago.

“You okay if I take this down now?” I held the faceplate up.

“You’re asking me permission?” she said, amused.

“Someone has to. The house won’t give it.”

I put the plate back for now, left the mark, and clicked thirteen on long enough for the dragon to glow smug again in its new safe plug. Then we went back to the basement and finished the main.

“No,” I said. “I’m leaving the fire panel and the sump circuits alone.”

“You told me,” I said.

“You flick lights off in three rooms and they’ll say no one’s living here, they’ll be that literal.”

“I’m keeping occupancy signals. Kitchen stays hot. Two bathrooms lit. Radios on. You’ll be fine.”

“Understood.”

“I want your map. When you have it. A copy.” He pivoted the contract back into a cylinder and thumped it against his palm. “Details matter.”

“That’s why I’m here.”

He made a sound like he agreed but didn’t like that he did. “Carry on.” He left a shadow shape at the threshold that looked like a crossbar until he was gone and it moved.

When I flipped “parlor west” by accident and the fire panel squawked, I learned the exact tone of Tom’s boots at speed. He appeared in the doorway with one green earplug out, saw the breaker already back, saw my hand already rewiring my own caution. He nodded once, a half smile as if to say he’d bet two dollars and had just won.

“Old labels lie,” he said.

“No one writes them to be read,” I said.

He hooked a thumb at the low subpanel. “Laundry. Half the guest wing behaves from there. No one knows why. Don’t kill the iron; Lana will hunt you.”

“I’ll map around them.”

He went again, and I went to work on the subs.

At the lower right panel the neatness fell off a cliff. Doubled taps on the main lugs. A breaker feeding a breaker feeding a junction box whose cover was held with one screw. A whisper of diesel came in around the duct where it had a rip in its foil tape, and I could feel with the heel of my hand the warm exhale that lived down there even at midday.

“Okay,” I said to myself, to the room, to the house. “We do it in small mouthfuls.”

I set my tone generator at an outlet in the servants’ hall, clipped the alligator to the ground, and went hunting with the wand. It chittered when I passed a run of conduit, then went silent, then screamed at a plaster wall where there was nothing visible. Someone had buried a junction and painted over it with the same conviction they brought to labeling. I marked the wall with tape: TONE HI—TRACE UP.

I worked a grid. North hall, main breaker map keys 1–20 done. East wing first floor, subpanel A 1–12. I made little drawings as I went, rectangles for rooms, poached eggs for fixtures, lines with arrows for what ran what. Lila moved around above me like a bright little echo. “Now the blue bedroom.” “Now the pantry.” “Wait, Lana says not the pantry, not for love or money.” I circled PANTRY in a red pen and wrote: SKIP—1–2.

When the lights were mapped enough that Victor’s abstraction could relax, I took the smoke pencil and the tissue streamers up into the halls. The ceiling height changed the way the air moved—taller near the portrait corridor, lower in the servants’ run. The thresholds had their own weather. You could put your hand an inch off the floor and feel a thread of river air sneaking under the east door, a cool band notched between warm. I taped tissue to the jamb with two tiny blue flags and watched the way the fringe moved. A slow draw into the stairwell where the sealed service stair sat behind a smooth sheet of plywood that kept its secrets by doing nothing at all. In the main hall, the movement was lazy, coming and going as a door somewhere opened and shut. At the loading door to the service court, the tissue kicked hard, then stilled, then moved again as the kitchen hoods cycled.

“Can you open the mudroom door and then close it?” I asked Lila on the radio.

“Copy,” she said.

The tissue jumped when she opened it. It settled on the close but didn’t fully stop. I put my smoke pencil under the threshold, pressed the bulb, and watched the thin line bend with obedience. The smoke went under and kept going; the outside air was low, the inside high. I chalked a small arrow on the baseboard pointing in with a little X and wrote: DRAFT HOTSPOT—MUDROOM. Two arrows at the east door. A circle and HRR at the basement stair where the cat door flapped in a current I could almost see.

“It isn’t,” I said. “I’m marking where cold air is sneaking in. If I don’t do it now, I’ll do it during service, and you’ll like that less.”

“I always do,” she said, and was gone again.

He nodded. “And?”
