data.final_scene:
Dusk took the color out of the east wing hall and left it the same shade as paper that’s been erased too hard. The windows on that side went from mirrors to flat panes. From the exterior eaves the dome sat like a glass bubble full of someone else’s decisions, its smoked plastic trembling with the last flies of the day.

“Day eighty-four, east wing,” I said to the recorder clipped to my collar. “Testing line-of-sight on the hall bend. Known incidents along this axis. Camera three-eaves supposed to cover. This’ll be quick.”

The ladder didn’t like the gravel, so I settled its feet on two split bricks and shook it until the stiles quit whispering. The dome’s bracket had been caulked with an impatient hand—troweled ridges catching lint and a stray hair that had embalmed itself in silicone. I thumbed the hinge, pivoted the shell down until it was an open jaw and the lens could look me in the face. The little internal LEDs tried to be helpful and only made the whites of my fingers glow.

“Hello, sweetheart,” I told it. “Show me what you don’t see.”

I taped a strip of reflective tape to the inside of the dome, dead center over the lens, and stepped down. From my pocket: compact mirror, the kind you buy for a dollar at a gas station; from the bag: chalk line, angle finder, laser pointer, the cheap kind that scares cats and inspectors.

The east wing hall ran straight for thirty feet, then took its delicate right at the linen closet and died at the old schoolroom door. That bend was the question. The incidents had been “heard near the bend,” “figures toward the bend,” “packages left, gone, later found past the bend.” The camera got the approach, the big bay window, the first stretch of rug. After the bend it got the idea of a hallway the way a child draws a hallway: two lines, a vanishing point, no people.

I clicked the laser and rested the mirror against the window glass at the first mullion. The dot found the taped strip inside the dome and came back to me as a red pinprick on my wrist. Good—alignment control. I walked the dot along the mullions, counting panes in my notes. At pane three the beam failed to return, instead staining the soffit with a dull smear. I adjusted the mirror by a fraction. No return.

I stepped back and talked to the recorder. “Pane three east wing hall window, outer corner: entering shallow angle relative to lens. No return indicates occlusion at dome lip or bracket shadow.” I stopped myself, breathed. “Say it simple: the dome’s rim blocks sightline at low approach. Anything hugging that wall past pane three can move like a rumor and never get caught.”

Dusk deepened and with it the corridor turned to a vertical well. I moved inside, left the recorder running, set the mirror against the baseboard at ankle height and propped it with my notebook. From outside the laser found the mirror, flared once, then fled. I stepped back in, bent, and looked along the runner so my face was level with the scuffed cotton borders. It smelled like old lemon oil that had given up and become dust.

I spoke to the empty corridor the way I spoke to bad ducts. “If you were a person who wanted not to be seen, you’d take that seam, left side. You’d keep your shoulder to the wainscot, and when you hit the bend you’d—” I moved, quick step, shade the body with the wall, pivot, gone. I stood beyond the bend and let my breath settle. Outside, a gull croaked like a machine that hadn’t been greased since fall.

I went back out, adjusted the dome’s tilt with two fingers and a stubborn squeak. Two degrees up, three right. A polite nudge. I returned to the mirror, placed it higher, chest height this time, and sent the laser in again. The dot kissed the tape and came home. The bend looked guilty and then looked like nothing again.

“Two inches,” I said to the dome. “He said he could. He won’t.”

I drew an arc on the glass with the side of a dried-out grease pencil, marking the limit where the beam stopped returning. I stepped left along the exterior wall, measured to the downspout with my tape, read it back to the recorder. “From downspout to dead zone start: six feet, three inches. Field-of-view cut by overhang and bracket. At dusk, the auto-iris closes down on the sky; interior reflection becomes dominant; contrast loss makes movement inside panes below midline invisible. Translation: you can waltz in there under the dome’s chin if you keep your head down.”

The wind at the eaves carried diesel. Not a new smell here. It held in the soffit wood like old swearing. The bracket screws had rust halos. I pressed a fingertip to one and the halo broke, came away like old wine on a napkin. The dome’s gasket had a bubble. The kind of thing water smiles at.

I set the ladder again, climbed, and with the angle finder noted the tilt out loud. “Pitch: sixteen degrees negative, yaw: twelve degrees toward north. Dome lip protrusion: nine millimeters. Shadow effect begins at twenty-one degrees.” I knew I was gilding it but the saying mattered. If the saying existed, this could be sliced up later, handed across a table, be undeniable.

I put my own face against the glass of the hall and made myself a figure. Hat brim low, shoulders rounded, phone in palm. I took a step along the left wall, then another, then a third into the bend. Outside, the laser told the truth it could tell: no dot. I came back out, moved to the right wall, walked the same pace. The laser returned and tickled my knuckles. I did it again. Left wall dead, right wall bright. The difference pleased me the way a good map pleases: the kind you can trust because it insults you if you lie to it.

I clicked the recorder off and recommended something to the air. “If this camera were a person, I’d ask it to watch with both eyes.”

With dusk down to its last decisions, the windows went black enough that the hall’s fixtures, set low for economy, started to matter. The sconces produced a smear on the dome. The smear became a veil. I didn’t have to tell the recorder this; I knew it and the night agreed. I held my phone up with the flashlight ribbon on and walked the left line past the bend again. From outside, looking in with my own eyes, I could see myself plainly enough in the brightness I carried. In the dome’s reflection, just the flashlight’s flare, nothing behind it—no person.

“Okay,” I said. “Okay.”

I spread the breaker map on the windowsill and made a place for the east wing overlay I’d drawn from the plans Lila had shown me. I took my blunt pencil and printed what I’d already printed in my head downstairs: BLIND HERE. Then I boxed it. Then, because it had to bleed to scale, I added the hash marks and the measurements I’d said out loud. I drew the field cone from the dome to the bend and shaded the slice where it went dark. On the hall plan I striped the left side, start to bend, past the turn. I drew an eye with one lid half-closed because sometimes I need a joke to make the truth stick to the page.

I taped the little reflective mirror off the baseboard and palmed it. I took down the tape from the dome lens and pocketed the shard of gummy adhesive like it was evidence worth two cents. I cleaned the glass with my sleeve until my sleeve smelled like plastic and Windex from last week.

Back inside, I stood at the bend again. The runner there had a swallow-tail stain where something wet had sucked the color out and left it gray. I looked at it until it was only a shape. “They put you here for a reason,” I told the stain. “They didn’t put a camera where they needed one.”

The recorder clicked back on. “Conclusion: coverage gap confirmed. East wing hall, left wall approach, bend to schoolroom. Dome Canopy field-of-view blocked by bracket lip and auto-iris response at dusk. Recommend reposition bracket two inches outward and rotate three degrees south; add interior unit at bend. Marked blind zone on map.”

I folded the map at the new crease and slid it into the red folder I kept for things that can cost people money. The hall took my last light and made it general. The dome under the eaves watched what it could watch and let the rest be private. I buttoned the recorder down and let the house be as it was.

data.final_scene:
The ladder up to the belfry was a suggestion more than a tool—fourteen feet of gray 2x4s with the rungs chewed to ovals by boots and time. Someone had nailed it to the shaft wall with three sizes of antique nails, none in a straight line. Breathing in there tasted like mouse pillow and pennies. I laid my gloves on the second rung and tested the wobble. It answered with a creak I felt in my teeth.

“Recorder on,” I said to the little brick clipped to my collar. “Greystone tower access. Day Eighty-Four. Time—” I checked my phone: 21:27. “—twenty-one twenty-seven. Objective, bell rope inspection at hatch. Conditions: dark, limited clearance, probable guano. PPE: gloves, goggles, dust mask. No harness. Note: floorboards at base sprung on the west side. Proceeding.”

“Do you need me to hold your ladder?” Lila called up from the dim little anteroom where the tower met the attic. The 40-watt bulb she’d pulled on made a cone that stopped at my knees. Beyond that was the pure black in the throat of the shaft and the sliver of moon off the louvers.

“It’s nailed,” I said. “If it goes, we both go. Stand clear.”

“I’ll stand worried,” she said, and shuffled back so her slippers wouldn’t brush the slick pellets along the edge.

I climbed with my palms open, fingers flat, weight low. I kept my shoulder to the wall so I could use the studs as an extra rail. Every third rung complained; every fourth had a squeak that wasn’t wood. I clicked my headlamp on at the third rung and watched the beam catch floating dust, then bigger pieces—hulls of bees, a feather, a brown curl that could have been rope hair or a mouse tail.

Halfway up I could see the hatch—a square cut into the plank ceiling with a dull brass hasp turned sideways. From below it looked like a mouth with an overbite. A droop of rope hung through, tar-dark where thousands of hands had polished it. The rope had a twist to it that said it had been trained: three-strand, laid hard, probably manila or sisal once but now some blend with synthetics to last in weather. It ended at my shoulder in a big knot that had been hit too many times and had flattened into a fist.

The bell above had its own smell—green metal and old thunder. I put my chin on the rung and tested the droop of the rope with a knuckle. The fibers whispered. No give at the knot, no grit on the surface. Clean.

“Status?” Lila again, quieter.

“Still attached,” I said. “Hatch is shut. No slack beyond what’s hanging. Hold on.”

The ladder skinned my shin where a rung had been worn to a blade. I pressed up and used the heel of my hand to bump the hatch. It stuck. Paint had welded it. I felt with two fingers along the edge and found the nail they’d used to keep it from lifting in wind. Bent over, hammered sideways, exactly the way you’d do it when you didn’t care how it looked because no one would see it.

“Of course,” I said. “Of course.”

“Problem?”

“Tamper nail,” I said. “Cheap fix. I’m going to pull it, then lift. If it binds, I’ll back out.”

“Copy,” she said, like we were on a radio in a small war.

I got the little pry bar out of my back pocket with my teeth because I needed both hands on the ladder. Metal tasted like a coin someone had licked. I wedged the flat under the nail head and levered. The nail screamed in a thin voice and came a quarter-inch. The rung under my foot ticked. I froze, listened to the old wood telling me where my weight was. I exhaled and took another bite. The nail came. I put it in my shirt pocket because you keep what you remove.

The hatch ended up being heavier than it looked. Water had fattened the boards. I lifted with my palm and got the edge high enough to take with my fingers, then shoved it flat against the planks so it wouldn’t pendulum and clock me. Cold air pushed down—sea-wet, threaded with diesel the way the whole house had a faint diesel line through it, like it was a perfume the place wore after a long day pretending to be empty.

I put my head through and set the headlamp on low. The bell’s skirt filled the triangle of roof, a broad green shape with welded ribs and an iron yoke. Pigeons had written their calendar across the beams. Spider silk made a lens through my light. The rope passed over a sheave turned sideways and down along the beam, wrapped once around a fairlead and then straight down through the hatch. By the fairlead the rope had a collar of tape—cloth, frayed to gray.

“Describe the condition,” I told myself, and moved one rung up, then another, until my shoulders were through and I could lean on the hatch frame. The risk calculus did its little dance: If I lost a rung here, I’d fold through the ladder and bruise everything that mattered except maybe my good opinion of myself. The only way to test what I needed to test was to reach, and reaching meant bad angles.

“Carabiner,” I said, and clicked one from my belt to the hatch frame, then a short lanyard to the back of my belt loop. It was symbolic—if I went, the loop would tear—but symbols keep hands calm.

The rope near the hatch had a shine. Not the old sweat-satin you see on pulls in churches where kids have tugged for generations—this was a skin. Under low light it made a subtle wet. I wrapped my glove along the lay and pushed my thumb against the glazing. It wasn’t dust. It was a coat.

“Rope surface coating observed,” I said. “We’re at the hatch, fairlead level. Glazing on the fibers. Extent—” I moved my hand up to the fairlead and back down. “—about fourteen inches. Texture: slick, not tacky. Smell—”

I brought the glove to my face with the mask still on and sniffed. With the mask it was cotton and plastic. I pinched the glove’s fingertips off and sniffed again. A faint pine in it, but sharper. Not wax, not oil. Resin with something cut into it—solvent or heat once applied. The glaze had drawn the outer hairs of the rope down and sealed them along the twist. In the troughs between the strands, clear ridges had formed like melted sugar that set too fast.

“Like someone iced it,” I said, forgetting for a second that I had an audience. The recorder took that too.

I ran my nail along the outer filament, just enough to test. It shaved a sliver that curled like a fingernail and then gave a brittle snap. Fresh coatings don’t carry the dust yet; they keep their edge. This one had a couple of lint hairs captured where a hand had handled it while it was still going off—tiny dark commas in the clear.

“Why would you coat a pull?” Lila asked, right below me. She had crept back without the ladder knowing.

“Reduce fray,” I said. “Waterproof it at a wear point. Or hide transfer. If you pull a rope long enough, it puts itself on you.”

“Hide what,” she said. It wasn’t a question so much as a small defense.

“Nothing,” I said, because the day already had enough. “Everything. Tape makes a print. This makes a glove.”

I reached higher, past the fairlead to the sheave. The sheave turned like it had grudges. It had a dab of the same glaze. Not much. Just a fingertip’s worth where the rope enters. The cold in the belfry made the ridge in the resin answer my nail with a bright, small sound.

“Is that bad?” Lila said.

“It’s deliberate,” I said. “Someone took time.”

I thumbed the tape collar. Under it the rope’s fibers puffed; beyond it they lay sleek and slick. The cutout in the tape showed a little window of rope where the glaze bridged across, a separate application later. The tape had old grime embedded; the glaze did not. I took out a razor from the flat kit on my belt and slid it under one raised lip of resin where it had beaded. One clean slice lifted a chip no bigger than a sesame seed. I breathed steady and laid it onto a piece of clear tape I’d pre-cut, then stuck that onto the inside of a sample bag. I did the same for one stray fiber that had lifted along the edge. It snapped and left a little white. I bagged that too, labeled the bag with the date and “Bell Hatch Glaze/Fiber.”

“Is that going to make it ring?” Lila asked. Her voice went up into the tower and came back as a little question I could have balanced on my thumbnail.

“No,” I said. “If anything it’ll make it quieter. Less squeak. Less dust.”

She breathed, the way you breathe when you remember something you’d rather not tell. The ladder ticked again, a dry bone sound. I came down one rung to change the angle and take the load off the worst of the wood. My thighs told me how long I’d been in half-squats and I told them to do it a little longer.

“Procedure,” I said to the brick. “Collecting transfer off rope surface. Photograph before/after.” I palmed my phone and took three shots: full view, fairlead detail, resin edge with glove fingertip for scale. The flash lit the bell and the beams and the little white planets of guano. In the first shot the glaze took the light like a lake in wind. In the second, you could see where a thumb had smoothed it, a little crescent where the ridge thinned and pooled.

“Anything else?” Lila said. Her voice was fine now. She’d put her hand on some wall down there and cooled.

“Counterweight?” I said. “Do you have one?”

“We did,” she said. “I don’t know if the last man took it off. Tom said it banged.”

I gave the rope a light nudge like I was ringing a towel to check a seam. A weight thumped the wall downshaft—wood on wood—twice, delayed. There was our answer. Up top, the bell did not move. The little iron shiver that runs through a building when a bell wakes stayed asleep. The only thing that moved was the line along my glove where a clear smear had left a narrower clear on the gray.

“Weight’s still on,” I said. “Rope is dressed here. Glaze recent.” I slipped the glove off and touched the smear with a clean knuckle. Nothing transferred. Then I breathed on it and touched again. My skin got a whisper—the faintest tack—and the glaze blinked under my light like a film of ice waking. That’s new product behavior. Old coats don’t do that.

I put my gloves back on. I moved down two rungs to ease the burn in my calves and looked at the hasp—brass, turned sideways—and then at the nail in my pocket and the hatch’s raw edge where the paint had torn when I lifted. I should pick the paint chips off the frame; I didn’t. The house can keep some. I wiped the fairlead with a dry wipe and held it at an angle. The wipe took nothing visible. I bagged it anyway.

The ladder gave me one last warning—a bird-bone crack somewhere under my right foot. I stopped being careful and got efficient, which is a different way of being careful. I hip-scooted down the last three rungs with the bar looped in my belt and the sample bag zipped between my teeth, then I was at the floor and the faint lantern light and Lila’s slippers making small shapes. She looked at the rope like it was a person in a bed she hadn’t talked to in years.

“Find enough?” she asked.

“Yes,” I said. I held up the bag. The sesame seed of resin and the pale hair of fiber looked like nothing at all and felt like enough to move a column in a ledger somewhere. “It’s fresh.”

She nodded without moving. The tower made its old-night noises. A car out on the road made a ribbon of sound that didn’t belong. I took the nail from my pocket and set it on the sill below the ladder.

“I’m not putting that back,” I said.

“No,” she said. “Don’t.”

The recorder chimed in my collar as if to mark a new paragraph. “Conclusion: Bell hatch access achieved. Rope at hatch shows fresh resin glazing on surface fibers, fourteen-inch band centered at fairlead; glaze displays clear ridging and recent application characteristics. Counterweight present; bell static. Samples collected. Photographs logged.”

I clicked it off. I wiped my hands with a baby wipe from the kit until the smell of fake cucumber beat the resin and the diesel both. Then I put the wipe away, because even that can be evidence if someone ever asks a better question than mine.

The nail came. I put it in my shirt pocket because you keep what you remove.

The hatch ended up being heavier than it looked. Water had fattened the boards. I lifted with my palm and got the edge high enough to take with my fingers, then shoved it flat against the planks so it wouldn’t pendulum and clock me. Cold air pushed down—sea-wet, threaded with diesel the way the whole house had a faint diesel line through it, like it was a perfume the place wore after a long day pretending to be empty.

I put my head through and set the headlamp on low. The bell’s skirt filled the triangle of roof, a broad green shape with welded ribs and an iron yoke. Pigeons had written their calendar across the beams. Spider silk made a lens through my light. The rope passed over a sheave turned sideways and down along the beam, wrapped once around a fairlead and then straight down through the hatch. By the fairlead the rope had a collar of tape—cloth, frayed to gray.

“Describe the condition,” I told myself, and moved one rung up, then another, until my shoulders were through and I could lean on the hatch frame. The risk calculus did its little dance: If I lost a rung here, I’d fold through the ladder and bruise everything that mattered except maybe my good opinion of myself. The only way to test what I needed to test was to reach, and reaching meant bad angles.

“Carabiner,” I said, and clicked one from my belt to the hatch frame, then a short lanyard to the back of my belt loop. It was symbolic—if I went, the loop would tear—but symbols keep hands calm.

The rope near the hatch had a shine. Not the old sweat-satin you see on pulls in churches where kids have tugged for generations—this was a skin. Under low light it made a subtle wet. I wrapped my glove along the lay and pushed my thumb against the glazing. It wasn’t dust. It was a coat.

“Rope surface coating observed,” I said. “We’re at the hatch, fairlead level. Glazing on the fibers. Extent—” I moved my hand up to the fairlead and back down. “—about fourteen inches. Texture: slick, not tacky. Smell—”

I brought the glove to my face with the mask still on and sniffed. With the mask it was cotton and plastic. I pinched the glove’s fingertips off and sniffed again. A faint pine in it, but sharper. Not wax, not oil. Resin with something cut into it—solvent or heat once applied. The glaze had drawn the outer hairs of the rope down and sealed them along the twist. In the troughs between the strands, clear ridges had formed like melted sugar that set too fast.

“Like someone iced it,” I said, forgetting for a second that I had an audience. The recorder took that too.

I ran my nail along the outer filament, just enough to test. It shaved a sliver that curled like a fingernail and then gave a brittle snap. Fresh coatings don’t carry the dust yet; they keep their edge. This one had a couple of lint hairs captured where a hand had handled it while it was still going off—tiny dark commas in the clear.

“Why would you coat a pull?” Lila asked, right below me. She had crept back without the ladder knowing.

“Reduce fray,” I said. “Waterproof it at a wear point. Or hide transfer. If you pull a rope long enough, it puts itself on you.”

“Hide what,” she said. It wasn’t a question so much as a small defense.

“Nothing,” I said, because the day already had enough. “Everything. Tape makes a print. This makes a glove.”

I reached higher, past the fairlead to the sheave. The sheave turned like it had grudges. It had a dab of the same glaze. Not much. Just a fingertip’s worth where the rope enters. The cold in the belfry made the ridge in the resin answer my nail with a bright, small sound.

“Is that bad?” Lila said.

“It’s deliberate,” I said. “Someone took time.”

I thumbed the tape collar. Under it the rope’s fibers puffed; beyond it they lay sleek and slick. The cutout in the tape showed a little window of rope where the glaze bridged across, a separate application later. The tape had old grime embedded; the glaze did not. I took out a razor from the flat kit on my belt and slid it under one raised lip of resin where it had beaded. One clean slice lifted a chip no bigger than a sesame seed. I breathed steady and laid it onto a piece of clear tape I’d pre-cut, then stuck that onto the inside of a sample bag. I did the same for one stray fiber that had lifted along the edge. It snapped and left a little white. I bagged that too, labeled the bag with the date and “Bell Hatch Glaze/Fiber.”

“Is that going to make it ring?” Lila asked. Her voice went up into the tower and came back as a little question I could have balanced on my thumbnail.

“No,” I said. “If anything it’ll make it quieter. Less squeak. Less dust.”

She breathed, the way you breathe when you remember something you’d rather not tell. The ladder ticked again, a dry bone sound. I came down one rung to change the angle and take the load off the worst of the wood. My thighs told me how long I’d been in half-squats and I told them to do it a little longer.

“Procedure,” I said to the brick. “Collecting transfer off rope surface. Photograph before/after.” I palmed my phone and took three shots: full view, fairlead detail, resin edge with glove fingertip for scale. The flash lit the bell and the beams and the little white planets of guano. In the first shot the glaze took the light like a lake in wind. In the second, you could see where a thumb had smoothed it, a little crescent where the ridge thinned and pooled.

“Anything else?” Lila said. Her voice was fine now. She’d put her hand on some wall down there and cooled.

“Counterweight?” I said. “Do you have one?”

“We did,” she said. “I don’t know if the last man took it off. Tom said it banged.”

I gave the rope a light nudge like I was ringing a towel to check a seam. A weight thumped the wall downshaft—wood on wood—twice, delayed. There was our answer. Up top, the bell did not move. The little iron shiver that runs through a building when a bell wakes stayed asleep. The only thing that moved was the line along my glove where a clear smear had left a narrower clear on the gray.

“Weight’s still on,” I said. “Rope is dressed here. Glaze recent.” I slipped the glove off and touched the smear with a clean knuckle. Nothing transferred. Then I breathed on it and touched again. My skin got a whisper—the faintest tack—and the glaze blinked under my light like a film of ice waking. That’s new product behavior. Old coats don’t do that.

I put my gloves back on. I moved down two rungs to ease the burn in my calves and looked at the hasp—brass, turned sideways—and then at the nail in my pocket and the hatch’s raw edge where the paint had torn when I lifted. I should pick the paint chips off the frame; I didn’t. The house can keep some. I wiped the fairlead with a dry wipe and held it at an angle. The wipe took nothing visible. I bagged it anyway.

The ladder gave me one last warning—a bird-bone crack somewhere under my right foot. I stopped being careful and got efficient, which is a different way of being careful. I hip-scooted down the last three rungs with the bar looped in my belt and the sample bag zipped between my teeth, then I was at the floor and the faint lantern light and Lila’s slippers making small shapes. She looked at the rope like it was a person in a bed she hadn’t talked to in years.

“Find enough?” she asked.

“Yes,” I said. I held up the bag. The sesame seed of resin and the pale hair of fiber looked like nothing at all and felt like enough to move a column in a ledger somewhere. “It’s fresh.”

She nodded without moving. The tower made its old-night noises. A car out on the road made a ribbon of sound that didn’t belong. I took the nail from my pocket and set it on the sill below the ladder.

“I’m not putting that back,” I said.

“No,” she said. “Don’t.”

The recorder chimed in my collar as if to mark a new paragraph. “Conclusion: Bell hatch access achieved. Rope at hatch shows fresh resin glazing on surface fibers, fourteen-inch band centered at fairlead; glaze displays clear ridging and recent application characteristics. Counterweight present; bell static. Samples collected. Photographs logged.”

I clicked it off. I wiped my hands with a baby wipe from the kit until the smell of fake cucumber beat the resin and the diesel both. Then I put the wipe away, because even that can be evidence if someone ever asks a better question than mine.

data.final_scene:
The maintenance closet was already half-open, a wedge of light leaking across the corridor tiles like a spill of milk. The fan in the ceiling grille rasped at a high pitch, and the smell was layered—bleach, hot dust, plastic buckets that had gone brittle with age, a humid thread of mop water going sour in a wringer. I shouldered in sideways because the shelves were close, made closer by the hanging of coiled hoses and an orange extension cord looped like a sleeping serpent. It was one of those closets designed to swallow a person and pretend they weren’t there.

Tom was inside, sitting on an upturned crate beside the water heater, head down to a phone cupped in one palm. The other hand drummed a dull rhythm on his thigh. He looked up with the flinch people get around flashlights. Mine wasn’t on, but he squinted anyway, eyes rimmed red, pupils fat in the cheap LED.

“You need the vacuum?” he asked, as if there were any room to use it.

“I need you,” I said, and stepped until my knees bumped the mop bucket. The hinge of the door clipped the heel of my boot and stayed against it, so the door pressed me forward, a little force that wouldn’t stop. His shoulders seemed to swell with the closet.

“Yeah?” he said. He put the phone facedown on the crate like a card. The fan up top breathed heat over his head, and the glow from the single bulb pulled the map up out of his skin—the unevenly shaved jaw, the shamrock green of an old tattoo peeking from his sleeve seam, the dryness at the corners of his mouth. He had a new denim work shirt with the sleeves rolled to the elbow. The forearms were red in two long, clean bands, skin raised as if it remembered pressure and heat both, and the inner edges had the fine crosshatch, tiny lines that a rough fiber leaves when it drags.

I let my eyes ask it first. Then I asked it.

“What happened to your arms?”

He looked at them, actually surprised he still had them. Then he shrugged in a way that started at the wrists and worked up. “Winch slip,” he said. “Down at the shed. Cable burned me.”

“That diameter?” I pointed with one finger, not touching. The bands were twin rings, each maybe an inch and a half wide, sitting just where a person would instinctively catch something without thinking through the physics.

“Cable’s cable,” he said. “It’ll eat you if you let it.”

“This didn’t eat you. It kissed you and stepped back.” I tilted my head, let the closet do that other thing closets do, make silence dense. The fan whir clipped and clipped, like a cricket stuck in a bottle. “What were you moving?”

“Generator panel was binding. We greased the rails last storm. It’s stickier now, maybe from the salt. It went fast when it went.” He was giving me that look labor gives a clipboard—polite, skeptical, waiting for a stupid question.

“You greased a panel on Day eighty-four?” I said.

He squinted, doing his math. “Today’s… yeah. Tonight. Evening.”

“What time?” I pulled the small notebook from my shirt pocket and flipped it open to clean paper. My thumb left a faint greenish ghost of fake cucumber from the wipe I’d used upstairs.

“After dinner,” he said, and the way he said it was as if dinner were a drift marker on a river, not a time. “Eight.”

“Who was with you?”

He rubbed the back of one wrist along the edge of the other forearm, not touching the burn but acknowledging it. “Nobody needs to babysit a winch.”

“So nobody saw it.”

He smiled a very small smile that wasn’t happy. “You want me to stage a crowd for you next time a cable goes sideways?”

“You said cable,” I said. “Steel cable. The pattern on your skin isn’t from steel.”

“Okay,” he said. “Rope, then. Winch rope. Synthetic. It’s a kit, you know? Swap out the steel for the rope, help keep the weight down.” He nodded at the corner where the orange extension cord hung. “Made of plastic. Everything’s plastic.”

“What diameter?”

He scratched his jaw. “Haven’t calipered it.”

I held my fingers up, the way you show a child how big the fish was. “About like this?”

“If you say so.”

“I’m asking you.”

He rocked the crate back an inch, let it thump forward. “An inch. Inch and a half. They don’t give me a ruler with it.”

“The generator shed winch rope is an inch and a half?” I said. I kept my voice soft and even, because people will fill a soft space. The fan thrummed. A drop fell somewhere in the plumbing—tick. The corridor outside kept its own counsel.

“It’s whatever they shipped,” he said. “I don’t spec it. I don’t order it. I use it.”

I angled my shoulder to let the pressure of the door ease off my boot heel and then ease back, a slow tide. “You were down there at eight,” I said. “You burned both forearms, symmetrically, with the one winch slip.”

“It caught,” he said. “I grabbed. That’s when it happens.”

“How many pulls?” I asked.

“Two, three.”

“On a binding panel. You had to take the slack by hand?”

“I don’t know what you want me to say, man,” he said. The smile came back but shorter, like a trimmed hedge. The cornered tone slid out of him and sat in the space with us. “You want me to say I did a thing wrong, I’ll say it. I did a thing wrong. I grabbed where I shouldn’t. I’ve done worse. You want to write me up?”

“I’m not your boss,” I said.

“Then why you in my closet?”

“Because your arms look like the bell rope had a conversation with them,” I said, and let the word bell sit there, the clean ring of it not sounding here in the wet air. His eyes flicked, only a centimeter, but I caught the move toward the door, the way bodies confirm exits even when they don’t head for them.

“Rope is rope,” he said. “Winch is a rope.”

“The bell rope has resin on it,” I said. “Fresh. There’s a fourteen-inch band at the fairlead.” I held my fingers apart again. The bands on his skin sat almost that long. “It dresses you different from cable.”

He looked at his arms and then at the mop bucket and then up at the fan as if the answer might be pinned to the grille. “You want me to say I rang the bell?” he said. “I didn’t ring your bell.”

“I didn’t ask you that,” I said. “I’m asking you what tasks you did tonight. In order.”

“Why?”

“So that when someone else says something else, I have your words, and I’m not guessing.”

He snorted. “You and your words.”

“Run me through it.”

He pushed his phone a little farther from his thigh with two fingers. The screen lit for a second and showed a cracked wallpaper—two boys in life jackets with their hands full of sunfish. It went dark again.

“Fine,” he said. “I swapped a filter in the downstairs AHU. The one that wheezes. That’s at seven-thirty. After dinner but before the game. Then I found a broom because someone smashed a glass in the mudroom. Then I checked the generator like I do. Little drips under the carb bowl. I wiped them. I hit the rails with grease like I said. I set the trailer lights to trickle charge because the line’s been weak. I walked back. That’s your night.”

“What time did you leave the generator shed?”

He shrugged. “Nights are mush. Nine. Ten.”

“That’s an hour range,” I said.

He spread his hands, then winced when the skin pulled on the left. “It’s dark out there. You want me to say nine-forty? Call it nine-forty.”

I took my phone out and opened the camera, not quick, not hiding it. I set it to no shutter sound and turned the flash off. “I want your arms for my file,” I said.

He looked at me with something like a laugh in his eyes that didn’t make it to his mouth. “That what we’re doing now? Evidence?”

“Documentation,” I said. “Hold still.”

He held his forearms up, palms toward me so the inner bands were plain. The red had the clean border of friction. I took a shot, then one with a quarter from my pocket held against his skin for scale, then I took the quarter away and took two more at an angle so the raised ridges showed. He was calm like men are calm when they decide not to make trouble, not because trouble isn’t there.

“You done?” he asked.

“One more,” I said, and took it. “When did you last wear gloves?”

“Tonight, when I was greasing. I took them off when they got nasty.”

“What kind?”

“Mechanix. The cheap ones. Spend more, they get stolen.”

“Where are they now?”

He nodded toward a plastic bin under the lowest shelf, the kind you buy to store Christmas decorations. I crouched, tipped the lid. The bin was a jumble—gloves, rags, a broken headlamp, a coil of white nylon rope someone had cut and cut and given up on. The gloves lay on top: black synthetic backs, gray palms with rubberized grip. The inside cuff of one had a smear the same resin color I’d seen upstairs, the tan that wasn’t quite tan.

I looked up at him. He had seen me see it. He had his face arranged like the glove had done this to him, not the other way around.

“Grease picks up whatever,” he said. “Dust. Pollen. Bugs. Your resin. Whatever. It’s a house.”

“It is,” I said. I set the glove back where it had been, reversed nothing. I stood, and the door pressed the heel of my boot again, a little reminder. “Anybody ask you to check the bell?”

“No.”

“You check it anyway?”

“No.”

“You know where the hatch is?”

“Do I look like I go up towers?” He sniffed, a real one, congested from the chemical soup of the closet. “I fix what got wheels.”

I wrote: Tom: filter swap 1930; mudroom glass sweep ~1945; generator—greased rails, wiped drips, set trickle charge—2100–2200; burns: claims winch rope slip; gloves: resin smear present.

He watched the tip of my pen the way a cat watches a bug.

“Anything else?” he said.

“You helped block returns last week,” I said. “With Daniel.”

His jaw tightened at the name but only the muscles did; the skin stayed quiet. “I help anybody if they ask me to move a ladder.”

“How’d you block them?”

“Tape,” he said. “Board. Whatever you handed me.”

“That was which day?” I asked.

“Days are mush,” he said again. He scratched his eyebrow with the side of his thumb. “You got your photos. You got your little book. You want more, get a calendar.”

“I will,” I said.

He stood. The closet shrank. He held the door for me with his hip, the opposite of the pressure I’d been keeping there, and for a second we were linked by that stupid mechanics of hinges. I stepped back into the corridor’s cooler air. The overhead fixtures buzzed. Somewhere down the hall, the ice maker dropped a batch and sounded like a well-suppressed accident.

“Put a note if you’re going to take my gloves,” he said.

“I didn’t take your gloves.”

“Not yet,” he said, and tilted his head just enough to see past me to the dark that began at the end of the hall and went away in both directions. “You walking around more tonight?”

“Yes.”

He nodded, a slow click of the chin, and shut the door. The latch gave a crisp, ordinary sound. I stood for three breaths and then leaned my shoulder against the jamb and spoke into the recorder clipped inside my collar.

“Maintenance closet,” I said. “Day eighty-four, twenty-two forty. Subject: Tom. Observed bilateral friction burns on forearms, inner aspect, approximate length fourteen to sixteen centimeters, width three centimeters; pattern consistent with rope contact, not steel cable. Subject states ‘winch slip’ at generator shed. Provides vague task timeline: filter swap ~1930, mudroom cleanup ~1945, generator service 2100–2200. Gloves present in closet bin show tan resin smear on inner cuff; photo logged. Photographs: four of burns, one with scale. No statement regarding bell inspection. No witnesses cited.”

The recorder’s tiny LED winked once. I tucked the pen back in my pocket, wrote the bare time in the corner of my notebook page, and looked at the maintenance door until it was just a door again. Then I moved, letting the corridor’s draft lick the sweat off my neck as if the house were breathing through me.

Place: Maintenance closet
Time: Day 84, night
Event: I see Tom’s forearms; note rope burns matching diameter.
Conflict: He downplays as “winch slip”; I press for task details.
Story value: Suspicion
Story value charge: Negative
Mood: Cornered
Outcome: He offers vague timeline; I log photos.

“I will,” I said.

“Put a note if you’re going to take my gloves,” he said.

“I didn’t take your gloves.”

“Not yet,” he said, and tilted his head just enough to see past me to the dark that began at the end of the hall and went away in both directions. “You walking around more tonight?”

“Yes.”

He nodded, a slow click of the chin, and shut the door. The latch gave a crisp, ordinary sound. I stood for three breaths and then leaned my shoulder against the jamb and spoke into the recorder clipped inside my collar.

“Maintenance closet,” I said. “Day eighty-four, twenty-two forty. Subject: Tom. Observed bilateral friction burns on forearms, inner aspect, approximate length fourteen to sixteen centimeters, width three centimeters; pattern consistent with rope contact, not steel cable. The diner on Route 7 had a floor that sloped a degree and a half toward the register, enough that spilled coffee took a deliberate path. The bell over the door had been wrapped with a rubber band to stop it from ringing; a handwritten NO CHECKS sign had been taped to the glass so long it had ambered.

Ruth refilled my cup without asking. She wore a pale blue polo with RUTH embroidered in white and a pencil behind her ear that left a graphite smudge on her temple. The coffee tasted like the pot had been rinsed with hot water and then reconsidered. Traffic hissed past in a steady two-lane whisper. A pair of plow flags waited at the end booth like the last two straws at a wake.

“You’re the one up at the big house,” she said, setting down the creamer. “Your hair’s got insulation in it.”

I checked a curl; fiberglass, yellow. “Heat returns,” I said. “They were blocked.”

“That why the lights flicker?” she asked.

“No,” I said. “Probably a bad splice. I’m still checking.”

She nodded like that was fine with her as long as I stayed on my side of the counter. At the far end, two men in canvas jackets were dissecting a stack of pancakes. One had a day-glo vest folded on the seat beside him so the edges made a fluorescent fan.

“You doing the bell,” the vest man said, not exactly to me. “We heard.”

“Everybody hears,” his friend said. “It’s a bell.”

Ruth set down a plate of over-easy eggs in front of me. The yolks sat up like eyes. “You from insurance?” she asked.

“Facilities,” I said. “Temporary.”

“Good,” she said. “Insurance people tip like they’re replacing a roof.”

“I’ll try to keep up the trade’s reputation.”

“It’s not a bad bell,” the vest man added, turning on his stool. “Just loud when it gets a mind.”

“What’s your name?” I asked him.

“Donnie.” He chewed. “Don with an -nie. Not Donald.”

“Okay, Don with an -nie,” I said. “What makes it ring?”

He gestured with his fork at nothing precise. “When the siren goes,” he said. “Ask anybody.”

“Which siren,” I said. “Ambulance?”

“No,” the friend said. He had a cap with a stitched trout and an oil stain that wasn’t new. “Civil defense. County test. First... first Wednesday? Unless there’s a parade. Or rain.”

Donnie shook his head. “Naw. It’s the first Monday. Ten o’clock. Ten-oh-five if they’re late, which they are. Been that way since my mother’s mother.”

“First Monday of the month?” I asked Ruth.

Ruth was counting out change to a contractor with a tape on his belt, lips moving. She lifted her hand at me, give me a second, then slid the fives into the till and pressed the drawer shut with her hip. “Siren test?” she said. “I got the paper calendar. Holcomb brings it in. Here.” She bent under the counter and came up with a thumbtacked sheet that had blue municipal seal at the top and clip art fireworks where July would be. “They tape one at the bait shop too so the out-of-towners don’t panic.”

She laid it between my plate and my elbow, a careful, practiced move that avoided ketchup. In the left margin, a legend: First Wednesday—Outdoor Warning System Test—1100 hours (weather permitting).

“First Wednesday,” I said.

Donnie frowned at it like it owed him money. “No,” he said. “We used to do Monday. They changed it after the school did that new... something. The superintendent said so. I remember because the bulletin came on a Tuesday and it didn't make sense and then Wednesday came and there it was, right on time, and I said to my wife, I said, ‘They messed it again,’ but it was the new thing.” He tilted his head like he could tip the memory out clearly. “I’m not crazy.”

“I didn’t say you were,” I said.

“They had it noon once,” the trout cap said. “Back in ‘18. I was in the barbershop and Milt said it was noon now. Noon whistle. People complained the kids jump. Then they moved it.”

Ruth tapped the calendar with a nail painted the color of a Weigela flower. “Holcomb told me it’s eleven,” she said. “Except if the weather’s rough. They don’t want people thinking it’s a tornado if the sky’s snot-green.”

“Holcomb’s the emergency guy?” I asked.

“Emergency Management,” she said. “Blue Tahoe, busted taillight, says he’s getting to it.”

“What about the bell?” I said. “You said it wakes up when the siren does.”

Donnie brightened. “Right. That’s the thing. Siren, then bell. Or bell, then siren. They go together.”

“Which,” I said.

“You know,” he said, and made a shape with his hands that explained nothing. “Together.”

“Sequence matters,” I said.

“Do you want more toast?” Ruth asked me, which sounded like a joke but wasn’t. She was holding the toast tongs in an upright, referee way.

“Yes,” I said, because toast meant time and I wanted to pin the words to the page right. I pulled my notebook and set it on the edge of the calendar, tiny squares empty of birthdays. “Tell me the last time you remember hearing both.”

“Last month,” trout cap said. “I was in my truck. I was about to turn onto Seven, and the radio did that honk, you know—”

“EAS tone,” I said.

“—and then the siren did its thing up by the firehouse. And I heard that big house bell go a minute later. Or before. Close.”

“Time?” I asked.

“I don’t look when I drive,” he said. “But I was picking up bait for my nephew and Frank closes for lunch at eleven-thirty because he’s cheap with his AC. So it was before that.”

Ruth delivered the toast. “It’s eleven,” she said again, to the toast, to anyone. “First Wednesday. We put a note in the book so the regulars don’t think it’s the power plant. It’s on the church board, too. People read the board.”

“The church board says when the county tests the siren?” I asked.

“They put the food pantry and the car wash and the test, yes,” she said. “Because Pastor Dell got the calls the first year and he said if they were going to call him they might as well have the sign tell them first.”

Donnie stabbed at a pancake that tried to slide away. “Anyway,” he said. “This is my point. That bell. It’s like a sympathy thing. One goes, the other goes. Ask Tom.”

“I did,” I said. “Tom said he was at the generator that time.”

Trout cap snorted. “Tom don’t hear nothing when he’s ear-deep in that thing. He wears them orange cans like he’s on a tarmac.”

“Ear muffs,” I said.

“Yeah. You ask Lila,” he said. “She records everything. She probably got it on her phone.”

“She does,” I said. I put a line in my notebook under the calendar: First Wednesday—1100 hours—(weather permitting). The pen made a clean, straight sound. I looked up. “So you’re saying if I look at the past siren tests—on Wednesdays at eleven—I’ll find that people remember the bell around the same time.”

“Yup,” Donnie said. “Or right after. Or right before. Close. My mother’s mother—”

“—heard it on Mondays,” Ruth said, and took his empty plate away before he got sentimental on it. “Do your eggs.”

I ate the eggs. They were hot enough to convince me calm was an option. A logging truck went by fast enough to pull the napkin under my plate a quarter inch toward Route 7. The calendar had a coffee ring on June and a thumbprint on August; July’s firework looked more like a virus.

“You get a lot of calls here?” I asked. “About the siren? About the bell?”

“First week of the month,” Ruth said. “Folks ask if it’s a drill. I say, if you’re calling me, it’s a drill. If you’re not calling me but I can’t hear you because the sky pulled the roof off, it’s not a drill.” She shrugged. “People like to check before they feel. I’m not judging.”

“Okay.” I pushed the calendar around so I could photograph it without catching anybody’s faces. “Can I take a picture of this?”

“Holcomb will be honored,” she said. “He prints them himself on the copier with the stripe.”

I took a photo. The phone gave a little fake shutter sound. I zoomed; the legend pixelated politely. I took another, squared, in case I needed to show a border later. I put a small star on the corner of my notebook page for anything that existed in print from someone who would answer a phone.

“Let me ask it this way,” I said to the room. “Would anybody bet money that the bell happened at eleven, first Wednesday, last month? If I wrote eleven next to it?”

Donnie lifted his palm, turned it to see if money had materialized there, then let it fall. “Twenty,” he said. “I’d put twenty on it.”

“Ten,” trout cap said. “Because I had to go for bait and Frank gets ornery if you come at eleven-thirty-three, so I wouldn’t have been here then.”

“You hear it here?” I asked Ruth.

“I hear the siren,” she said. “That thing makes the silverware sing. The bell—sometimes. Not always. Depends where you are. If the grill’s hot and the hood’s on, everything sounds like a storm that you can eat.”

I wrote that as “audibility varies with hood,” and drew a tiny line for airflow that nobody needed but me. I drained the last of the coffee and put the cup down. Ruth appeared before I could ask, refilled, turned the pot to check how much was left for the ten o’clock rush.

“Why?” Donnie asked. “Why you care if they’re together?”

“Because if they’re together,” I said, “it’s not random.”

“Ha,” trout cap said, pleased with the neatness of that.

The contractor with the tape asked Ruth about pies. She gave him a list like ammunition. The light over booth three blinked twice then recovered. A kid with a county hoodie came in, grabbed a donut from the rack by the register, left two ones in the jar without breaking stride. The doors’ rubber banded bell gave a padded, disappointed clink.

“You going to bait shop?” Ruth asked, watching me angle my check so it didn’t catch the coffee ring.

“Yes,” I said. “If Frank will talk.”

“He’ll talk,” she said. “He’ll say he won’t, and then he will. He puts the calendar up for the city folks so they don’t yell when the siren scares the minnows.”

“It scare the minnows?” I asked.

“They don’t know if it does,” she said. “But it makes them feel better to have a reason when fish don’t bite. Same as anybody.”

I put cash on the check, too much on purpose. Ruth caught the extra with her eye, not her hand, and made no ceremony of it. “That bell used to ring for Christmas Eve,” she said, putting the calendar back under the counter. “Somebody’d pull a short one every half hour so you’d know to come. That was nice. The tests aren’t nice. They’re just there.”

“I’m just here,” I said. “I need a copy of that calendar.”

“You have a copy,” she said. “On your little space phone. If you want another one you go to Holcomb and ask him to print; he’ll tell you the toner’s low.”

“I’ll ask him anyway,” I said.

“You do that,” she said. “Tell him to fix his taillight.”

I stood, put my notebook in my pocket, and slid the municipal calendar photo into a folder on my phone I called “signal,” then made it redundant by writing the test line again in my book. First Wednesday—1100—weather permitting—county. I drew a box around it. The box was square. I did the same in the margin: Lila vid timestamp: 10:14—Day 83. I didn’t say anything out loud. I didn’t need to. The page held both without argument.

Donnie looked like he was going to say something else, then didn’t. Trout cap adjusted his hat, which adjusted nothing. Ruth wiped the counter with a half-wet rag, a straight-line swipe that took the water ring off June in a single pass.

“Be safe on Seven,” she said.

“I’m always safe,” I said.

“Then be careful,” she said, which was different, and went to pour coffee for the contractor, who had decided on apple pie like it was a job that had fallen to him fairly.

The rubber-banded bell made its quiet, apologetic clink when I pushed out into the bright. The sun hit the asphalt and came back up. Trucks rolled, same as they had before I knew about Wednesdays, before anyone needed a calendar to say what they’d remember anyway. I put my hand on the phone in my pocket like it might wander off: siren, eleven. Bell, locals. I had a posted schedule now. That was something that would sit still when I asked it to. I went across the lot toward the bait shop’s hand-painted OPEN and the little thermometer that read whatever the shade told it.

data.final_scene:
The bait shop door stuck halfway and then gave with a shudder, the hand-painted OPEN sign wagging on its string. Inside it was cool, wet-cold, the kind that came off tanks and rubber boots and a floor mopped more out of habit than hope. An aquarium hum filled the gaps. Minnows fidgeted in a blue tub the size of a horse trough; the aerator breathed like a sleeping dog. A pegboard wall held lures like a color chart for bruise: plums, chartreuse, copper-flash. Coffee steamed in a glass pot that had been on since some other season.

“Leave it shut or leave it open,” said the man behind the counter. “But don’t make it argue.”

He had a jaw like a broken crate and a grip on a styrofoam cup that said he’d hold it whether it was full or empty. A darker beard line had lost the contest with gray a while back. Harlan, from the faded name stitched to his shirt pocket, where two tiny split shot were clipped like medals.

“Sorry,” I said, easing the door flush so the latch didn’t click. “You Harlan?”

“Unless somebody else owes for two dozen shiners,” he said. He didn’t smile; he didn’t frown. He glanced at my shoes, found no waders, and let me exist anyway. “Help you with something that bites or something that don’t?”

“Information,” I said. “Doesn’t bite unless it’s wrong.”

“That’s not how information works,” he said, and took a sip. “But go on.”

“County siren,” I said. “First Wednesday, eleven a.m. Weather permitting. True?”

“True enough,” he said. “If they remember and if it’s not lightning. Dispatch runs it. Sometimes they don’t bother in a blow.” He said bother like it was a moral category.

A boy in a bucket hat was peering into the minnow tub like it might spell out an answer if he stared long enough. Harlan slid a net in without looking, lifted a silver storm that flashed and settled. He counted in twos, clicking them into a plastic bag, his thumb a metronome.

“You hear it here?” I asked.

“If I’m here to hear it,” he said. “Most months, yeah. It’s not for us. We know where we live. It’s for folks that need to know the sky exists.”

“What’s the timing like,” I said, “in practice. Dead on the hour or whenever the coffee cools.”

“Dispatch lady has a watch,” he said. “Doesn’t mean the tower does. I’ve had it 10:58, I’ve had it 11:03. Once they held it to after a thunder cell passed. You could see the wall of rain halfway down the lake and nothing over the other half. They wait. Or don’t. It’s human beings.”

I pulled the municipal calendar image up with my thumb and set the phone on the counter. He didn’t lean; he didn’t need to.

“You and Ruth compare notes,” he said, nodding at the phone like it had raised its hand. “She’s not wrong. First Wednesday, eleven, if they feel like the lightning gods won’t strike them dead for making noise.”

“People have been saying they hear the Greystone bell then,” I said. “Same days.”

“Holcomb Municipal,” I said. “And the buoy?”

“No buoy on the lake,” he said. “College has a thing floats off the science dock, but they don’t share. Weather Underground has a man on Ridge Road with a vane and a Facebook. He’s proud of it. He’s not wrong often. Don’t tell him I said that.”

I put them in a folder I called wind, then dragged it next to signal.

“I did,” I said.

“No,” I said. “Just the part where I know what I’m listening to.”

“Spooky’s expensive,” I said.

data.final_scene:
The office at Greystone had been a proper room once—water level lines on paneled walls from a radiator that had behaved itself, a leather chair that still remembered a posture, a desk you could spread a life across. Now the radiator was cold and flaking its own paint, the chair had gummy arms from too many wipedowns with lemon oil nobody had buffed, and the desk had absorbed paper and power strips until it was a topographical map. The window unit muttered in a way that promised effort more than results and exhaled air that smelled like wet cardboard.

Lila had already colonized the blotter with her recording gear. Two handheld audio recorders lay there like twin fish—one with blue tape marked KITCHEN, the other with a scribble I couldn’t read because the tape had lifted at the corner and collected grit. A third, new-looking, sat on its blister pack beside a half-eaten granola bar and a capless marker. There was a wall clock with a second hand that swept instead of ticked—the cheap continuous kind—and a brass carriage clock on the bookcase that had stopped at an expressive 2:11 and stayed expressive about it.

“You said early afternoon,” she said, without hello. Her hair was up with a pencil through it, and the pencil had bit its own wood down where she’d chewed it. She looked like she’d been listening for something and resented me for interrupting the act of listening.

“It is,” I said.

On the desk: a yellow legal pad with times down the margin, tight small handwriting that skidded when it got excited. Bell—11:17—it said on one line, then on the next, three dots and the word low. There were more entries above and below—Door? 2:03? and a note that seemed to argue with itself in arrows.

I pulled the chair opposite, the one that objected by making a little farting noise when you leaned, and flattened my own notebook open across a stapler that had rust on its teeth. The Wi-Fi from the house’s network bars were weak enough to make my phone try hard, which only made the screen stay a blank promise. I’d downloaded what I needed at the bait shop. I had it.

She followed my eyes to the wall clock. “Don’t tell me about the clock,” she said. “It’s wrong.”

“I wasn’t going to tell you about the clock,” I said. “I was going to ask you about your time.”

Her mouth went tight on one side. “Same answer.”

From the hallway the portrait corridor gave a little throat of quiet. You could smell the diesel if you were the kind of person who had been around it; it clung to the fibers of things in a way cleaning didn’t reach, a cold note under lemon and damp. Somewhere in the mechanics of the manor a relay chose something and clicked. The window unit rattled, chose defiance, kept rattling.

I set my phone face-up and slid it so she could see the folder names, wind and signal, as if that made a case before the case. She didn’t look at it.

“You told me the bell happened at eleven seventeen,” I said. “Day before yesterday.”

“It did,” she said. Her voice had that thinning quality it got when she had been challenged and refused the idea of having been challenged. “That’s what the recorder says. That’s what I put.”

I reached and flipped the blue-taped recorder over. It showed me nothing, a blank little digital window that woke if you pressed MENU, then offered tiny numbers you could not trust at a glance. I didn’t press it.

“Here’s the schedule,” I said. “County emergency management. First Wednesday of the month, eleven a.m. siren test. The lake carries. Harlan at the bait shop hears it all the way down at his dock.”

“So?” she said, eyes going narrower. “It wasn’t Wednesday.”

“Right,” I said. “But two residents on Ridge Road posted videos of the test the previous Wednesday at exactly 11:00:05 and 11:00:12. The wavefront passes the ridge and hits the hollow. You and I both heard people say the bell went at eleven last time. You have it at eleven seventeen.”

“On a different day.”

“On a day with wind out of the south-southwest,” I said. “Which is a carry direction into this valley. The test noise gets in here and becomes bell if you’re listening for bell. You wrote eleven seventeen because your recorder tells you eleven seventeen. I’m asking what set the recorder’s clock.”

She picked up the capless marker and put it down again. It left an oblong bruise of black on the blotter that made an impatient halo around the word PAYMENTS stamped in a corner. “You think I just write things,” she said. “You think I want it to be a bell, so it’s a bell.”

“I think you are doing the work you have. I think your record is only as good as the clock. And the clocks here are—” I let the word spend itself looking around the room, which obliged me with three different clocks, each telling me about itself rather than time. “—social.”

“Social,” she said. “Cute.”

“You’re the one called me,” I said. “You’re the one wanted a map to match your notes. I’m here to match, not to make cute.”

She tipped back in the chair the way people do to flirt with the idea of falling. It creaked in something like a language. “It rang,” she said. “I heard it. Tom heard it. The kitchen recorder caught it and the office one didn’t because the office one was at low battery and that’s why I was in here charging it at noon—look.” She snaked the blue tape one toward its cable and held up the little USB end, accusing. “It reads as eleven seventeen. That’s not me.”

“Does it set itself by NTP?”

“What?”

“Network time,” I said. “Does it pull from the house Wi‑Fi? If it doesn’t, whatever you set it to last is what it is. If you set it when the wall clock said noon, it learned noon from a liar.”

“It sets itself when I plug it into my laptop,” she said. “So it’s my laptop’s fault now? You want to say that? Go ahead, say that so we can be done.”

“I want to know,” I said, “whether your laptop is set to automatic or manual. Whether you drifted it on the drive from the city when you lost service and forgot to resync. Whether Victor’s router hands out time from 1970 because nobody ever clicked a submenu. Whether the phones in this house die and wake and die and wake and each time make a different choice about what time is.”

She laughed once, dry, and didn’t look at me. The laugh bounced off the window and went thin. “You talk like an instruction manual,” she said.

“You want the thing fixed,” I said. “Fixed requires knowing which piece is loose.”

“It rang,” she said again. “If you’re saying it was the siren, it wasn’t.”

“I’m saying the relationship between eleven and seventeen is a problem,” I said. I reached into my folder and put down the printout from the county’s site that I’d picked up at the diner from their bulletin board and had Harlan bless with his dirty thumb. It was wrinkled from my pocket and said in its municipal typeface: MONTHLY SIREN MAINTENANCE TEST: WEDNESDAYS 11:00 A.M. Then below: Any unscheduled sounding will be accompanied by an alert on Holcomb County Alerts. I put beside it the screenshot from the Ridge Road weather nut’s feed, where he’d posted a graph with a red spike labeled SIREN DRAG, 11:00–11:03, SW 11 kts.

She didn’t look at those either. She watched me instead, a small steady animal in brush, waiting to see if I would move wrong. When she did look down it was to the legal pad again, to the line where she’d written Bell—11:17 and drawn a little underline under the 7 like it mattered.

“I know what I heard,” she said. “Do you ever get tired of people saying that to you?”

“No,” I said. “Because sometimes they did hear it. And then sometimes we find out the lake has a way of talking, and ducts do, and a siren does. I’m not saying you were wrong to write it. I’m saying it’s my job to make your eleven seventeen speak to the siren’s eleven like they were in the same conversation.”

She blinked slow. “You make everything a duct.”

“Because the house keeps trying to be one,” I said. “Ferals of pressure and sound. If it’s bell, we will find it bell. If it’s a test on the wind, we will find that too. But only if our time is the same time.”

She pushed back from the desk, scraped the chair legs. The marker rolled and made a small diagonal leap for the floor, failed, lay there. “You’re patronizing me,” she said.

“I’m not,” I said. “I’m telling you I need to audit the sources. Recorder internal clocks. Phone time from the tower. The router’s time. Anything else that stamps numbers on things. I’m telling you what I’m going to do next. You can call that patronizing if it helps.”

“What it helps is you,” she said.

The room did that thing rooms do when two people are picking at the same thread from different directions. Everything else fell out of focus. The air in the window unit’s intake made the plastic shiver like it was too thin for its job. The brass carriage clock held its 2:11 like a posture, refusing to be moved.

“Give me the kitchen recorder,” I said. “Give me the office one. We’ll plug them both in and pull the files. We’ll look at their metadata. If the stamps are blank or nonsense, we’ll set them against something that isn’t. I’ve got a phone with NTP and two other stations to triangulate. We’ll take a new recording right now and mark it against the second hand.” I flicked my eyes at the wall clock, whose second hand swam like an eel and contradicted the whole notion of seconds. “Not that one. My watch.”

She snorted. “Your watch is true and mine lies?”

“My watch is set to UTC offset by this time zone and my phone checks it against the network every hour. If that lies, then the county lies and the airport lies and Harlan lies and we are so far from knowing anything we can stop and go home. Do you want to go home?”

She sat. The chair made its little noise. She reached for the blue-taped recorder and put it in the middle of the blotter like a hostage. Then she pulled the second one—the gritty label said OFFICE when you squinted and took the angle—out from under a manila folder and thumped it to the middle too.

data.final_scene:
Day 85, afternoon. I start with the bag open on the kitchen table and a line of devices like little patient birds waiting to be banded. Two CO puck sensors, three clip-on audio recorders, two throat mics with sticky tabs, one USB splitter, a roll of painter’s tape, zip ties, alcohol wipes, spare SD cards in a pill bottle. A notepad with the trout magnet holding the Wi‑Fi password half-on, half-off the paper the way Lila said; the magnet slides again and clacks onto the floor, trout down, like a fish that gave up the pretense.

“Time first,” I tell the table. That counts as a prayer and as an instruction.

I pull the kitchen recorder Lila gave me and thumb it on. Battery: full. Internal clock: 14:17. The brass clock in the office was dead; the wall clock above the stove here says 2:13. The modem’s tucked back in the pantry behind an army of soup cans, humming like it wants to be a better appliance. I tilt it and read the sticker. The modem’s admin page says 14:21, so four minutes off, just like she said. I take my phone off auto, set it to the modem’s seconds, then set each recorder to the phone, not trusting my eyes alone—putting the world in a line, tick to tick.

“Recorder One, kitchen baseline, 14:24:10 by modem time,” I say into it. My voice is its first note. The fridge motor starts its low choir. I press stop and pocket it. The pill bottle rattles like good luck.

Generator room first. Heat rises and people collude; diesel is the earnest liar. The basement stairs have the kind of old-man carpet runner that’s both threadbare and immortal, held down by brass rods shaped like little shepherd’s staffs. At the bottom the air is a temperature you can feel with your gums. The generator room door is a heavy fire door with a gossip of scrapes around the knob. I shoulder it and the smell remembers how to be a person.

The generator is a boxy orange beast half my height, with the kind of manufacturer logo that looks like a dare. I let the door rest not-quite-closed so the pressure doesn’t make a question mark noise later. I thumb on the CO sensor and wait for its start-up chirp. The little LCD blinks 0 ppm, then 1, then 0—sensitive enough to be annoying, perfect.

“Generator room install,” I say to Recorder Two, clicking it live. “Modem time 14:31:06. Ambient 22 Celsius, 44 humidity. CO baseline zero to one, stabilizing. Diesel off, windows closed. Note: door ajar for noise.” I lay the recorder on the cinderblock ledge and listen to the room listening back. The space has one small casement window painted shut and webbed by a spider with a checkerboard hobby. There’s a narrow return grille near the ceiling, painted the same color as the cinderblock like that would trick air.

Limited units versus the sprawl in my head floats up like an equation. Three recorders for a house that’s mostly lungs.

“Pick your lungs,” I tell the wall. The wall does not argue.

I clean the generator’s exhaust elbow with an alcohol wipe until the rag comes away gray, then stick a strip of painter’s tape and seat the CO puck to it with two cable ties around the elbow and the sensor’s body. The display stays readable. If Victor asks why the pretty orange box is wearing jewelry, I’ll say it’s fashion forward. I run the sensor’s micro-USB to the splitter, to the wall, tape the slack to keep it from learning to snag. I take a photo with my phone, tag it GEN-CO-1, 14:33:52. The pill bottle clicks in my pocket with approvals.

I hang Recorder Two from the same cable with a zip tie so it floats free of vibration. “Recorder Two, Generator, position: elbow height, northeast wall. Baseline start 14:34:10. Gain low.” The generator doesn’t like metal on metal; any resonance gets picked up and will masquerade as an omen. I do a ten-second clap test, soft palms, then three fingernail taps on the cinderblock to mark a known transient. The recorder accepts my fingerprints as its first ghost.

I set the second CO sensor by the return grille, a meter below it on the wall, to test for lazy eddies. Tape, tie, photo. “CO-2, return wall, gen room, 14:35:42,” I say like I’m giving the air its bracelets. I watch the numbers. 0. 1. Back to 0. Good.

Back up to the east wing hall. The east wing keeps itself like a cat that’s done with you. The floorboards are dark and wide, older than everyone still telling this house what to do. Windows at the end make a big zone of light that’s not doing as much work as it thinks. The blind spot in the camera coverage is exactly where a person would stand to listen to the quiet pretend to be loud.

I pull my tape and mark a rectangle on the floor, low, under the second return grille where the baseboard rake makes its mouth. I slide the third recorder into the rectangle, flat to the floor, mic facing the slit. Then I hesitate. The hall wants a second ear higher up to catch duct talk versus foot talk, but I only have one recorder left after the attic. Limited units. Coverage map in my head redraws itself with a faint insult.

“Greed or prudence,” I say to the return. It mews.

I test the duct instead. I unsnap the lower section of the grille—old broad slats, stubborn screws. The inside is a short plenum then a flex duct that runs right, east, and up. The flex is dusty like a lover’s shoulder in a dream. I stick the throat mic to the flex with a square of tape and press, hearing the adhesive find purchase. I snake the wire back out under the baseboard and zip it to the radiator pipe, then to the recorder. The setup looks like a hospital for a snake. “Recorder Three, East Wing Hall, baseboard return. Throat mic on flex. Baseline start 14:52:03,” I say, and my voice pushes itself into the duct and back, a faint paper echo.

I take my phone and do ten slow passes down the hall, heel to toe, stopping at each threshold. “Footfall test east wing, 14:53,” I narrate like I’m teaching myself how to walk. The recorder takes it. My left knee clicks on the third pass and I leave that in as a marker too. It’s honest.

I tape a small index card under the return lip: DO NOT TOUCH—CALIBRATION. The letters are neat enough that anyone will think someone else wrote them. I crouch and listen. The throat mic pulls up a low skateboard rumble that is just the house being a big wooden machine settling in. No voices. Just the white noise of the world pretending it’s purposeful.

Attic crawl. The east service stair is sealed two floors up, but the attic makes more promises than it keeps. The door at the end of the third-floor corridor looks like a closet that got promoted. When I push it, the hinge makes a noise like someone remembering a joke. The air is grainy with old sawdust and mouse talk; it tastes like the underside of cardboard.

I clip my headlamp to my hat and go on hands and knees because that’s the language the space wants. The crawl is framed with thin old joists and floored in threshers of plank.
