data.final_scene:
Late afternoon soaked the study in old honey. The west windows caught it and sent it in through leaded panes, breaking it into bands across the carpet, across the scarred top of the partner desk. The room always smelled older than the rest of the house—linseed, wax, something like cloves ground to dust—and today there was a thin thread of diesel hiding under it, as if the smell had crept under the door and curled up under the radiator.

Victor looked like he belonged behind any dark piece of furniture with drawers, which is a way of saying he made himself into a shadow with a purpose. He had that crisp shirt that never wrinkled and the smile that did, from practice. When I came in, he was bent over the right-hand wall, where the bookcases went to knee level and then dipped to a cabinet with wood panels inlaid with burl. A lady’s writing desk, if the lady collected taxes.

“I need a flat surface for five minutes,” I said, lifting my bag in explanation. “I’ll be quiet.”

“This is the quiet room,” he said, approving himself for having one. His hand hovered where I wasn’t looking yet. “Anything I can get you?”

“Somewhere to spread—” I nodded at the partner desk. “Just to check my logs line up with the modem and the kitchen clock. I won’t touch your systems.”

He smiled like systems was a word he liked. “By all means.”

I set my notebook on the near side, opened it to this morning’s column of times, pulled my phone out, checked it against the modem’s tiny green blink through the doorway. I didn’t sit. I let the room do what rooms do when you pretend not to care: it shivered off its polite face and showed me the working bones.

The cabinet he’d hovered near had a small polished escutcheon at the keyhole, flush with the burl veneer. The brass had been cleaned more than the handles next to it. Over the escutcheon, at eye height, a hairline crack in the finish ran like a faint vein.

“Quiet room,” I said, idly. “But with storage.”

“Hm?” He looked down, then back up, performing not-looking. “Oh, those? Old curios. Lila’s aunt was a packrat.”

He said it with no affection for either aunt or pack. The room accepted the lie and put it in a jar on a high shelf.

I uncapped my pen and wrote: Kitchen baseline marker 15:41. Generator marker 15:35. I clicked to a new line and pretended to think about metronomes. He waited politely. The mantle clock by the empty fireplace ticked a tiny conventional tick. I listened to it and not to him shift his weight.

“Did you want a copy of the insurance rider?” he asked.

“Later,” I said. “What I wanted was the household’s historical log, if you’ve got one. Repairs, fuel, bills, anything that tells me what the building’s been asked to do over the last year. That kind of thing is gold to me.”

“Gold,” he repeated, as if the taste of the word might attract ants. “We keep household accounts.”

“Is that the same as a historical log?” I turned a page. “Names, amounts, dates?”

“It is, loosely,” he said, and went loose himself, shoulders unattached, gaze touching a painting, a window, the clock, then skimming across the cabinet like a bird checking water depth. “We try to be tidy.”

“Could I get access this afternoon?”

“Access,” he said. It hung there about as long as it takes a man to decide if he’s being boxed in. Then he smiled again. “Naturally. Within reason. You’d be looking for maintenance, not salaries or personal expenses.”

“Maintenance, purchases for the building, utilities,” I said. “You’ll keep me cleaner if you let me read it.”

He nodded and moved toward the cabinet. He was smooth but not smooth enough, not to somebody who loves locks for their little theater. The way his hand went to his pocket first and pretended to check for a handkerchief—it found a key instead. Vintage, nickel-plated, hollow shank with a barrel that glinted where it had been burnished by the same pocket a hundred times. An oval bow stamped with a small EAGLE and under it, 12. A warded key, narrow bit—no pins to tease, just a tongue for a particular throat.

He covered it with his palm, but hands are only coverings if the other person agrees they are. He squared up to the cabinet, and I got a clean look at the lock plate embossed EAGLE LOCK CO. TERRYVILLE, CONN. It had the proud air of something that has been imitating importance for a century. He slid the key in and it went with that soft, felted slide you only get when wood swells and shrinks around a piece of metal long enough for them to become shy of one another. The quarter turn was easy. He lifted the left-hand door a hair as he turned, to take the weight off the latch. Someone taught him that, or the cabinet did.

“You really keep the current accounts in here?” I asked, easy, as the door came away to reveal two shelves of ledgers, some new-blacked, some brown and rubbed like old loaves. Their cloth spines labeled in a thin fast hand: FUEL 1Q, FUEL 2Q, GENERAL 83–84, GENERAL 85, MAINT EAST, MAINT GEN SET.

“We keep what needs to be safe,” he said. “People wander. Guests get curious.” He shot me a smile that wanted to be teasing. “You understand security.”

“Security’s just boundaries people agree on,” I said. “May I?”

He didn’t move at first. His hand stayed at the edge of the door, like the wood might slam on his fingers if he were too trusting. Then he pulled one of the newer spines—GENERAL 85—and set it on the edge of the cabinet instead of handing it to me, as if we were joint custodians and the ledger was delicate.

I didn’t make him do the handoff. I stepped over and took the book, firm and clean-handed. Cloth cover, pasteboard inside, the kind of thing that absorbs a little oil and never looks worse for it. The first page was ruled. Vendor. Invoice. Amount. Date. I paged with my thumb and caught a glimpse of color where a sticky tab peeped out—three of them, red-yellow-blue. He watched my thumb like it might dent the paper.

“I’ll sit by the desk,” I said, and already knew he wouldn’t like that. The desk is where people sit who own things.

“By the window,” he offered, and put his hand in his pocket in the same motion he used to close the cabinet: smooth, casual. The key vanished in a practiced little fold, like a coin trick.

“The light’s better there,” I agreed, and took my place where he wanted me to look. The chair cushion remembered other readers.

“Do you need help interpreting anything?” he said, staying by the cabinet now that it was shut, as if his presence pressed it safer.

“Just a quiet room,” I said, and put the ledger on my knees so he’d have nothing to object to. I checked my phone’s time and wrote the page’s header in my notebook. GENERAL 85. First entry: M&T Supply—filter set (diesel) 321.66—date. Then laundry, then a plumber I’d met by the porch steps, then something called East Ridge Freight that felt like a forwarding service, then the name I’d already expected: Hartwell Energy—deliveries of #2.

“You’re very thorough,” he said. I was four pages in.

“I hate guessing,” I said. “Have you got the maintenance ledgers too? East wing, generator? The labels I saw.”

He didn’t blink at the saw. He did a small thing instead: his thumb touched the seam where the cabinet doors met and rubbed the line there, thinking. His nail clicked on the varnish. “I can get you the maintenance summaries. The detailed notebooks are older and… incomplete. People weren’t as careful then.”

“I like incomplete,” I said. “It tells me where care started.”

“We respect privacy,” he said. Which was not an answer to the question I’d asked, and was perfectly shaped to be said in this room. “And our contracts.”

“It’s a house,” I said. “It doesn’t have a private life.”

He laughed, softly. “You’d be surprised.”

I looked down at the ledger until he stopped enjoying the line. “I’ll list the volumes I need in my request,” I said. “If you prefer formal.”

“Formal helps,” he said quickly, with relief. “Paper trail. Keeps us aligned.”

Keeps us contained. I wrote it without writing it. On the next line I actually wrote: Submit access request for MAINT EAST; MAINT GEN SET; FUEL 83–85; GENERAL 83–85. Then below it, smaller, where it wouldn’t shout: ledger cabinet in study—Eagle Lock Co. warded; key nickel-plated hollow barrel, oval bow EAGLE 12. Victor pockets after use. Left door lift required to disengage latch.

He drifted a step toward the desk while I wrote and looked like he might say something about my handwriting, but didn’t. Instead he said, “If you’d rather I make copies—”

“Originals are faster,” I said, turning a page so it made its paper sigh. “And I won’t move them out of your line of sight.”

A small muscle by his jaw made a little decision and then got quiet. “You can work here for an hour,” he said. “Then I need the room.”

“Fine.” I made a tick mark next to a recurring vendor. “How far back do these go? Just so I don’t ask for ghosts.”

“Back to the last audit.” He meant a year without meaning it. “Earlier volumes are boxed.”

“In storage?”

“In storage,” he repeated, which is not a location.

The mantle clock ticked and the late light shifted its bands. Dust hung in them like proof of air. I turned another page and added a small asterisk to an entry I recognized by rhythm rather than by content. He followed the asterisk with his eyes the way a cat follows a laser dot. I smiled at the ledger, not at him.

“I’ll add the boxes to the request,” I said.

“Do,” he said, and the room put that in the same shelf with the earlier lie, and labeled both with his neat pencil.

He left on the pretense that the phone in the hall was ringing, which it might have been, or might have been the rattle of the return vent five rooms away. When he went, he took the smell of his aftershave and left the diesel thread behind. I heard his shoes on the runner, the faint check as he paused at the doorway to glance back at the cabinet, like a man checking the stove is off when he knows it is.

I waited until the hallway swallowed him and then sat forward and looked at the cabinet without opening it. The metal on the escutcheon had that hairline about a millimeter out from the keyhole where someone’s key had scraped often. The wood around the hinge had been newly waxed; the wax hadn’t gotten down into the grain yet. Whoever cleaned it favored the left door; the right had fingerprints in the dull.

I wrote, small and neat, in the margin: add “ledger cabinet” to formal access list. And under it, where I tuck plain things: trust not granted. Requests only.

Then I read what I could see and what I could name, and did not look at what I’d be told I couldn’t. The clock ticked. The bands of light slid. Somewhere the refrigerator in the kitchen hummed itself into a new note I’d already recorded. I let the quiet do the rest.

“Access,” he said. It hung there about as long as it takes a man to decide if he’s being boxed in. Then he smiled again. “Naturally. Within reason. You’d be looking for maintenance, not salaries or personal expenses.”

“Maintenance, purchases for the building, utilities,” I said. “You’ll keep me cleaner if you let me read it.”

He nodded and moved toward the cabinet. He was smooth but not smooth enough, not to somebody who loves locks for their little theater. The way his hand went to his pocket first and pretended to check for a handkerchief—it found a key instead. Vintage, nickel-plated, hollow shank with a barrel that glinted where it had been burnished by the same pocket a hundred times. An oval bow stamped with a small EAGLE and under it, 12. A warded key, narrow bit—no pins to tease, just a tongue for a particular throat.

He covered it with his palm, but hands are only coverings if the other person agrees they are. He squared up to the cabinet, and I got a clean look at the lock plate embossed EAGLE LOCK CO. TERRYVILLE, CONN. It had the proud air of something that has been imitating importance for a century. He slid the key in and it went with that soft, felted slide you only get when wood swells and shrinks around a piece of metal long enough for them to become shy of one another. The quarter turn was easy. He lifted the left-hand door a hair as he turned, to take the weight off the latch. Someone taught him that, or the cabinet did.

“You really keep the current accounts in here?” I asked, easy, as the door came away to reveal two shelves of ledgers, some new-blacked, some brown and rubbed like old loaves. Their cloth spines labeled in a thin fast hand: FUEL 1Q, FUEL 2Q, GENERAL 83–84, GENERAL 85, MAINT EAST, MAINT GEN SET.

“We keep what needs to be safe,” he said. “People wander. Guests get curious.” He shot me a smile that wanted to be teasing. “You understand security.”

“Security’s just boundaries people agree on,” I said. “May I?”

He didn’t move at first. His hand stayed at the edge of the door, like the wood might slam on his fingers if he were too trusting. Then he pulled one of the newer spines—GENERAL 85—and set it on the edge of the cabinet instead of handing it to me, as if we were joint custodians and the ledger was delicate.

I didn’t make him do the handoff. I stepped over and took the book, firm and clean-handed. Cloth cover, pasteboard inside, the kind of thing that absorbs a little oil and never looks worse for it. The first page was ruled. Vendor. Invoice. Amount. Date. I paged with my thumb and caught a glimpse of color where a sticky tab peeped out—three of them, red-yellow-blue. He watched my thumb like it might dent the paper.

“I’ll sit by the desk,” I said, and already knew he wouldn’t like that. The desk is where people sit who own things.

“By the window,” he offered, and put his hand in his pocket in the same motion he used to close the cabinet: smooth, casual. The key vanished in a practiced little fold, like a coin trick.

“The light’s better there,” I agreed, and took my place where he wanted me to look. The chair cushion remembered other readers.

“Do you need help interpreting anything?” he said, staying by the cabinet now that it was shut, as if his presence pressed it safer.

“Just a quiet room,” I said, and put the ledger on my knees so he’d have nothing to object to. I checked my phone’s time and wrote the page’s header in my notebook. GENERAL 85. First entry: M&T Supply—filter set (diesel) 321.66—date. Then laundry, then a plumber I’d met by the porch steps, then something called East Ridge Freight that felt like a forwarding service, then the name I’d already expected: Hartwell Energy—deliveries of #2.

“You’re very thorough,” he said. I was four pages in.

“I hate guessing,” I said. “Have you got the maintenance ledgers too? East wing, generator? The labels I saw.”

He didn’t blink at the saw. He did a small thing instead: his thumb touched the seam where the cabinet doors met and rubbed the line there, thinking. His nail clicked on the varnish. “I can get you the maintenance summaries. The detailed notebooks are older and… incomplete. People weren’t as careful then.”

“I like incomplete,” I said. “It tells me where care started.”

“We respect privacy,” he said. Which was not an answer to the question I’d asked, and was perfectly shaped to be said in this room. “And our contracts.”

“It’s a house,” I said. “It doesn’t have a private life.”

He laughed, softly. “You’d be surprised.”

I looked down at the ledger until he stopped enjoying the line. “I’ll list the volumes I need in my request,” I said. “If you prefer formal.”

“Formal helps,” he said quickly, with relief. “Paper trail. Keeps us aligned.”

Keeps us contained. I wrote it without writing it. On the next line I actually wrote: Submit access request for MAINT EAST; MAINT GEN SET; FUEL 83–85; GENERAL 83–85. Then below it, smaller, where it wouldn’t shout: ledger cabinet in study—Eagle Lock Co. warded; key nickel-plated hollow barrel, oval bow EAGLE 12. Victor pockets after use. Left door lift required to disengage latch.

He drifted a step toward the desk while I wrote and looked like he might say something about my handwriting, but didn’t. Instead he said, “If you’d rather I make copies—”

“Originals are faster,” I said, turning a page so it made its paper sigh. “And I won’t move them out of your line of sight.”

A small muscle by his jaw made a little decision and then got quiet. “You can work here for an hour,” he said. “Then I need the room.”

“Fine.” I made a tick mark next to a recurring vendor. “How far back do these go? Just so I don’t ask for ghosts.”

“Back to the last audit.” He meant a year without meaning it. “Earlier volumes are boxed.”

“In storage?”

“In storage,” he repeated, which is not a location.

The mantle clock ticked and the late light shifted its bands. Dust hung in them like proof of air. I turned another page and added a small asterisk to an entry I recognized by rhythm rather than by content. He followed the asterisk with his eyes the way a cat follows a laser dot. I smiled at the ledger, not at him.

“I’ll add the boxes to the request,” I said.

“Do,” he said, and the room put that in the same shelf with the earlier lie, and labeled both with his neat pencil.

He left on the pretense that the phone in the hall was ringing, which it might have been, or might have been the rattle of the return vent five rooms away. When he went, he took the smell of his aftershave and left the diesel thread behind. I heard his shoes on the runner, the faint check as he paused at the doorway to glance back at the cabinet, like a man checking the stove is off when he knows it is.

I waited until the hallway swallowed him and then sat forward and looked at the cabinet without opening it. The metal on the escutcheon had that hairline about a millimeter out from the keyhole where someone’s key had scraped often. The wood around the hinge had been newly waxed; the wax hadn’t gotten down into the grain yet. Whoever cleaned it favored the left door; the right had fingerprints in the dull.

I wrote, small and neat, in the margin: add “ledger cabinet” to formal access list. And under it, where I tuck plain things: trust not granted. Requests only.

Then I read what I could see and what I could name, and did not look at what I’d be told I couldn’t. The clock ticked. The bands of light slid. Somewhere the refrigerator in the kitchen hummed itself into a new note I’d already recorded. I let the quiet do the rest.

The east wing corridors held their evening chill the way the wood held its varnish: tight, glossy, with hairline cracks that showed when you tilted your head. The squall hadn’t landed yet, but the wind had started its rehearsal. It came as a thin whistle at the casements, a murmur in the returns, a hand flat against the old panes.

I set the orange data logger on the wainscot half-way down the hall where the two branches of the wing met. The little screen pulsed green. Beside it I laid my clamp meter, my voltage stick, and the cheap spiral notebook I was going to throw away when this job was over. A portrait of a woman with a spaniel looked down her nose at the setup. The spaniel seemed to be smelling the cord.

“Tell me you’re not putting that on the sconce,” Lila said. She stood in the threshold with both arms folded, shoulders hitching every time the wind probed the glazing. She had a wool cap on that made her look like a harbor worker, which did nothing for the hall’s argument about its own grandeur.

“Wainscot only,” I said. “Sconces get their own test later.” I ran a strip of gaffer tape under the logger and tucked the probe into the outlet. Then I flipped the notebook open and wrote: Day 85, 18:27, east wing corridor junction, pre-squall.

She made a face at the outlet like it had talked rude to her. “They stuttered earlier. Twice. Once as I was coming through. You were in the library and missed it. Don’t say it’s the grid. I called in May when the kitchen did the same, and they told me grids don’t stutter.”

“Grids don’t,” I said, “but connections do.” I tested the adjacent outlet with the non-contact stick; it chirped and lit. “You said twice?”

“Twice,” she said. “First time like a blink. Second time like—” She flapped her hand. “Like the hallway decided I didn’t need to see the bottom step. You know who else does that? Women in portraits.” She tilted her head toward the spaniel lady. “She hates my boots.”

“The portrait is indifferent, but the neutral might be loose.”

“The what?”

“White wire that carries return current,” I said. “If it’s not tight at a splice or lug, it behaves like a person telling stories on a bad phone line. Drops out at the wrong word.”

Lila pointed an index finger at me, very small, like she carried a tiny wand. “You’re doing that thing. That lecture voice.”

“You’re doing that boots-and-portraits voice,” I said, and got my clamp around the feed in the nearest sconce box. The needle twitched with house load.

A gust shoved hard at the north windows. Somewhere in the blank rooms behind us, a door settled with a sigh, then thunked. The house took it like a big dog asleep and slightly annoyed.

“There,” Lila said. “There, you see? That’s it.”

The lights didn’t do anything. One of the bulbs at the bend had a flick of a filament, like a blink you could miss. I glanced at the logger; the tiny waveform stepped down a hair, then righted itself.

“Gust,” I said, and wrote: 18:29 slight dip -1.6 V with gust.

“Or,” she said with relish, “old lady with spaniel.”

“Let’s give the old lady something to dislike,” I said. I pulled off my glove and curled my fingers near the bottom of the nearest plate. Cold and dry. The paint on the baseboard had a sheen of older wax, the sort that grabbed dust smooth. I kept my hand there, then moved to the trim near the window. The air on my knuckles had a different bite. “You feel that?”

“I feel like the building is thinking about how to get rid of me,” she said. “The runners lift, my ankles slide, and then the lights go, ‘…maybe you don’t need this foot after all.’”

“It’s pulling air,” I said. “Pressure shift. The gusts push and the house breathes. That can flex connections in a damp box. Or the overhead line on the east corner platform moves in the wind and the neutral loosens by a hair.” I looked up. The ceiling plaster had a hairline along the path of a hidden run; somebody had patched it, not expertly. “When did you have water in here?”

“What’s your definition of ‘in here’?” She touched the cap like she could adjust her patience with the brim. “Up in the eaves. Last fall. Tom did the gutters. It rained sideways.”

“If water got into a junction and stayed long enough, it can pit a connection,” I said. “Damp plus wind equals flicker.”

“So,” she said, “a ghost with a glass of water.”

I watched the logger. The wind licked, paused, then came back hard, and with it the light above us hitched two quick syllables. The logger chimed. The green pulse went amber for a breath. Lila’s breath matched it.

“That,” she said. “That is not a syllable I want in a hallway.”

“It dipped to 104 on one leg, rose to 126 on the other,” I said. “Loose neutral. Gave load to one side, took it from the other.” I wrote: 18:33 sag L2 to 104 V; L1 to 126 V during gust.

“Say that again in normal person,” she said.

“See-saw,” I said, and put my hands out, rocking them. “If the neutral’s not solid, the 120 starts to share load unevenly. One side goes dim, the other can over-volt. Lamps complain.”

“And toasters? And people?” She tilted her head again, listening. “I don’t like it when the house does different things in different wings. The west end is normal.”

“The west end is fed on a different run,” I said. “You’re on the east branch here.” I crouched and put the back of my hand near the outlet again. The air had a wet wool feel, the corridor’s energy like static on a sweater you can’t take off. “Any rain getting pushed in under the eaves is more likely to land on this side.”

“You are going to put your hand in a wall and pull out a fish, aren’t you?” She leaned back on her heels, eyes on the light like it was a cat she wasn’t sure about. “Conrad says it’s not wiring. He says there was nothing wrong until Daniel started poking at things, and now everything sulks.”

“Conrad was driving in the mud when I asked him about the boathouse,” I said, because that was a thing and not a mood. I didn’t look at that; I looked at the reading and the time and the way the sconce shadow trembled on the plaster. “We’re looking at a physical cause that correlates with a physical event. If a gust hits and a dip happens, that’s not sulking. That’s physics. I can show you the plot.”

“I don’t mind plots,” she said. “I mind halls that blink like a person tapping a glass with a knife.”

Another hit of wind. The house answered with a click from somewhere behind the linen closet door. The bulbs dimmed a fraction, then flickered twice like a breath caught and then decided. The logger chirped again. I reached to steady it, the tape holding but the table edge wanting to slide.

Footsteps on carpet, then on wood. Tom came around the bend, a coil of plastic drop cloth over one shoulder and a roll of blue tape hanging off his wrist like a bracelet. He looked at my small collection of diagnostic toys and then at the portrait dog as if asking it for the room.

“Storm party?” he said. “You put little hats on those?”

“They have hats,” I said. “They just don’t like to be seen in them.” I straightened. “We’re catching voltage swings in gusts. You had water in here last fall.”

“Had, have, hoping not to have,” Tom said. He shifted the drop cloth and looked up at the corner where the hall branched. “That soffit up there, the lead flashing pulled. I stuffed it with cloth to stop the wasps last spring. Meant to get back up with proper material. Got a call to trim a quince hedge that made me bleed and forgot. You need me to see if I can get up there now?”

“Not in the wind,” Lila said, sharp. “Do not get on a ladder with this going.”

“I wasn’t going to,” Tom said, offense and relief crossing his face like passing cars. “Just asking.”

“We’ll log it and isolate,” I said. “If we can kill just the east wing branch after we capture enough, we can stop the stutter without leaving the whole house in the dark.”

“Victor’ll have a fit you touched a breaker,” Tom said, but not as if he intended to stop me.

“Victor can come and read the dips,” I said. “He likes numbers when they let him disagree.”

“Victor likes numbers when they have dollar signs,” Lila said. “Just write ‘expensive haunting’ on your invoice and he’ll call a priest.”

Tom scratched his jaw. He had new scrapes on his knuckles, old paint under his nails in a color I remembered from the bell hatch. He kept his hands in view, as if making a point to the hall. “You want me to listen in the linen cupboard? Sometimes the noise is behind the towel shelf when it does that little… that jitter.”

“Open it,” I said. “And stand out of the way when you do.”

He opened it. The hinges complained. Towels breathed fabric smell, old starch, a hint of mildew, like a trunk opened after a season too long. The wind hit again. The lights did their two-step. In the back of the cupboard something clicked—a relay maybe, or the cheap ceramic guts of a pull-chain that had been removed sometime in the last forty years but still kept the memory.

“You hear that?” Tom said, triumphant. “Like a cricket.”

“Like a loose set-screw in a backstab,” I said. “Where’s your access to that chase?”

Tom set down the drop cloth, then knelt, pressing at the baseboard inside the cupboard, found a square of wood set on a different grain, and levered it up. It freed with a stiff cough. Behind it, darkness and the smell of thirty winters. He peered in, then pulled back as if the house had politely said no thank you. “You got light?”

I clicked on my tiny LED and handed it to him. He held it between his teeth and leaned in. Lila shifted weight, her hands inching into fists in her sleeves.

“Don’t drop that,” she said.

“I am aware,” he said, around the light. He reached in, felt with two fingers, then paused. “Damp. Not wet. Not dry. Like a dog’s nose.”

“Damp nose, tick,” Lila said, with satisfaction. “Tell her about your dog, Mrs. Spaniel.”

The logger chirped. The gust passed. The amber died to green. The light over us steadied. Tom pulled his hand out and wiped it on his thigh. “Condensation. Or something’s wicking.”

I checked the numbers. “We dropped again, not as steep. You touching anything when it did that?”

“Just the panel,” Tom said. “Didn’t move the wire. Wouldn’t. There’s a twist in there. Somebody used the cheap push-in instead of the screw. You can tell when you wiggle and the whole thing wants to come.”

“No wiggling,” Lila said, and pointed at him like she could staple him to the floor with her forefinger.

“No wiggling,” Tom repeated, solemn.

“Okay,” I said. “We’ve got a pattern now. Gust, dip, damp chase, suspect push-in connection on the branch. We’ll cut power to this run and open it after the front goes through. For now we keep logging, and we keep people who like to look for steps away from the steps.”

“Meaning me,” Lila said, but without heat. She took a step back from the stair head as if the hallway had moved a line.

The wind shifted, the angle a little different, more from the east. The windows jostled with an anxious little tap, like fingertips on a desk. Somewhere in the wall a wire hum settled into a note I could almost call B if I had the piano.

“You got those beeping things near the generator working?” Tom asked. “One of them squealed at me earlier when I went for the fuel. Brief. Went quiet.”

“They’re chirp-happy when the batteries get low,” Lila said. “Everything chirps when a storm’s coming.”

“They chirp for other reasons too,” I said, and glanced down the corridor toward the door that led to the back path. The odor that lived in all the vents—the faint, metallic diesel thread—felt a notch stronger with the wind planned the house. “I’ll check those after this. Right now I want a clear string of dips to tie to the gusts.”

“‘Tie to the gusts,’” Lila said, as if practicing it for later. She watched the sconce. The sconce watched nobody. “If it drops hard, do we get sparks?”

“Mostly you get an argument between devices,” I said. “They don’t all lose the same. Some of them get hit harder. You can cook a charger. You can ruin a fridge compressor. Or you can just scare Lila in a hall she already hates.”

“I don’t hate it,” she said, surprising herself with the truth of it. “I hate tripping in it. Difference.”

“Then you hate the person who didn’t fix the neutral,” Tom said. He eased the access panel back in place, then pressed the little square flush with care that made the act go quiet. “You tell me which breaker and I’ll be ready at the box.”

“We’re not killing it yet,” I said. “I need Victor to stand here and see the logger show him the dips so when I cut the power he can put that in his neat notes and not accuse me of scaring away his ghosts.”

Tom grinned. It was quick, like a flicker, but without the dread in it. “He’ll accuse you anyway.”

“Then he can watch the numbers with me,” I said. “We’ll give him a stool.”

“Make him hold the light in his teeth,” Lila said.

A heavier sound came from the far end: a shutter banging once, then again, then catching on its own latch. The lights did not answer that one. The logger hummed steady, its little heart beating at me like a frog’s.

“You want me to go pin that?” Tom said.

“In a minute,” I said. “Let’s get one more good gust.” I watched the numbers. I watched the seconds. I watched Lila not looking at the stair, and Tom rubbing his knuckles on his jeans in the way of a man tallying tasks and deciding which to do when.

The gust came. It ran the length of the wing like a horse and hit the casements in order: tap, tap, tap, a crack at the corner where the flashing had that gap. The lights did their thrown-shoulder jerk, one-syllable gasp. The logger chime bit and held. I leaned in and read: L2: 101.4; L1: 127.8.

“Got you,” I said, not to the portrait and not to any person with opinions.

“Meaning?” Lila said.

“Meaning I’m calling it,” I said. “Loose neutral or damp junction. We isolate east wing branch. We open the first box on the run and find the lazy push-in and fix it with a real screw.”

Tom nodded like a man grateful for a verb. “And the flashing?”

“After the wind,” Lila said, and he exhaled like a valve and lifted his hands in a surrender he didn’t believe in.

The corridor steadied. The wind set to a low surf instead of a slap. The portrait dog did what dogs do: looked pleased with its own certainty. I taped the logger lead tighter, wrote the numbers clean—time, load, dip—and underlined with the pencil I favored for saying what would hold up.

“Print that,” Lila said, looking at the tiny sawteeth on the screen like they were the heartbeat of something unafraid.

“I’ll send you a plot,” I said. “With the gust times marked.”

She pushed her cap up a fraction, like making room for the concept. “So when Victor says ‘ghost,’ I can say, ‘wind.’”

“You can say ‘cause,’” I said. “And then point at the effect.”

“Cause and effect,” she said, tasting it. “I like that better than ghosts. Ghosts don’t hold ladders.”

Tom picked up his drop cloth and the tape and gave the linen cupboard door a pat with the palm, an apology for opening its back. “I’ll be at the box,” he said.

“I’ll be here,” I said.

Lila tilted her head again, listening. Not for the portrait. For the wind. For the way the building frowned and then let it go. “You know,” she said, voice small in the big corridor, “for once, I hope it’s a stupid little screw.”

“It’s a stupid little screw,” I said, because sometimes a thing can be what it is.

We waited for the next gust. The house obliged, and the numbers did what numbers do. I made the note and drew the line between them. That was the work. That was enough.

“Storm party?” he said. “You put little hats on those?”

“They have hats,” I said. “They just don’t like to be seen in them.” I straightened. “We’re catching voltage swings in gusts. You had water in here last fall.”

“Had, have, hoping not to have,” Tom said. He shifted the drop cloth and looked up at the corner where the hall branched. “That soffit up there, the lead flashing pulled. I stuffed it with cloth to stop the wasps last spring. Meant to get back up with proper material. Got a call to trim a quince hedge that made me bleed and forgot. You need me to see if I can get up there now?”

“Not in the wind,” Lila said, sharp. “Do not get on a ladder with this going.”

“I wasn’t going to,” Tom said, offense and relief crossing his face like passing cars. “Just asking.”

“We’ll log it and isolate,” I said. “If we can kill just the east wing branch after we capture enough, we can stop the stutter without leaving the whole house in the dark.”

“Victor’ll have a fit you touched a breaker,” Tom said, but not as if he intended to stop me.

“Victor can come and read the dips,” I said. “He likes numbers when they let him disagree.”

“Victor likes numbers when they have dollar signs,” Lila said. “Just write ‘expensive haunting’ on your invoice and he’ll call a priest.”

Tom scratched his jaw. He had new scrapes on his knuckles, old paint under his nails in a color I remembered from the bell hatch. He kept his hands in view, as if making a point to the hall. “You want me to listen in the linen cupboard? Sometimes the noise is behind the towel shelf when it does that little… that jitter.”

“Open it,” I said. “And stand out of the way when you do.”

He opened it. The hinges complained. Towels breathed fabric smell, old starch, a hint of mildew, like a trunk opened after a season too long. The wind hit again. The lights did their two-step. In the back of the cupboard something clicked—a relay maybe, or the cheap ceramic guts of a pull-chain that had been removed sometime in the last forty years but still kept the memory.

“You hear that?” Tom said, triumphant. “Like a cricket.”

“Like a loose set-screw in a backstab,” I said. “Where’s your access to that chase?”

Tom set down the drop cloth, then knelt, pressing at the baseboard inside the cupboard, found a square of wood set on a different grain, and levered it up. It freed with a stiff cough. Behind it, darkness and the smell of thirty winters. He peered in, then pulled back as if the house had politely said no thank you. “You got light?”

I clicked on my tiny LED and handed it to him. He held it between his teeth and leaned in. Lila shifted weight, her hands inching into fists in her sleeves.

“Don’t drop that,” she said.

“I am aware,” he said, around the light. He reached in, felt with two fingers, then paused. “Damp. Not wet. Not dry. Like a dog’s nose.”

“Damp nose, tick,” Lila said, with satisfaction. “Tell her about your dog, Mrs. Spaniel.”

The logger chirped. The gust passed. The amber died to green. The light over us steadied. Tom pulled his hand out and wiped it on his thigh. “Condensation. Or something’s wicking.”

I checked the numbers. “We dropped again, not as steep. You touching anything when it did that?”

“Just the panel,” Tom said. “Didn’t move the wire. Wouldn’t. There’s a twist in there. Somebody used the cheap push-in instead of the screw. You can tell when you wiggle and the whole thing wants to come.”

“No wiggling,” Lila said, and pointed at him like she could staple him to the floor with her forefinger.

“No wiggling,” Tom repeated, solemn.

“Okay,” I said. “We’ve got a pattern now. Gust, dip, damp chase, suspect push-in connection on the branch. We’ll cut power to this run and open it after the front goes through. For now we keep logging, and we keep people who like to look for steps away from the steps.”

“Meaning me,” Lila said, but without heat. She took a step back from the stair head as if the hallway had moved a line.

The wind shifted, the angle a little different, more from the east. The windows jostled with an anxious little tap, like fingertips on a desk. Somewhere in the wall a wire hum settled into a note I could almost call B if I had the piano.

“You got those beeping things near the generator working?” Tom asked. “One of them squealed at me earlier when I went for the fuel. Brief. Went quiet.”

“They’re chirp-happy when the batteries get low,” Lila said. “Everything chirps when a storm’s coming.”

“They chirp for other reasons too,” I said, and glanced down the corridor toward the door that led to the back path. The odor that lived in all the vents—the faint, metallic diesel thread—felt a notch stronger with the wind planned the house. “I’ll check those after this. Right now I want a clear string of dips to tie to the gusts.”

“‘Tie to the gusts,’” Lila said, as if practicing it for later. She watched the sconce. The sconce watched nobody. “If it drops hard, do we get sparks?”

“Mostly you get an argument between devices,” I said. “They don’t all lose the same. Some of them get hit harder. You can cook a charger. You can ruin a fridge compressor. Or you can just scare Lila in a hall she already hates.”

“I don’t hate it,” she said, surprising herself with the truth of it. “I hate tripping in it. Difference.”

“Then you hate the person who didn’t fix the neutral,” Tom said. He eased the access panel back in place, then pressed the little square flush with care that made the act go quiet. “You tell me which breaker and I’ll be ready at the box.”

“We’re not killing it yet,” I said. “I need Victor to stand here and see the logger show him the dips so when I cut the power he can put that in his neat notes and not accuse me of scaring away his ghosts.”

Tom grinned. It was quick, like a flicker, but without the dread in it. “He’ll accuse you anyway.”

“Then he can watch the numbers with me,” I said. “We’ll give him a stool.”

“Make him hold the light in his teeth,” Lila said.

A heavier sound came from the far end: a shutter banging once, then again, then catching on its own latch. The lights did not answer that one. The logger hummed steady, its little heart beating at me like a frog’s.

“You want me to go pin that?” Tom said.

“In a minute,” I said. “Let’s get one more good gust.” I watched the numbers. I watched the seconds. I watched Lila not looking at the stair, and Tom rubbing his knuckles on his jeans in the way of a man tallying tasks and deciding which to do when.

The gust came. It ran the length of the wing like a horse and hit the casements in order: tap, tap, tap, a crack at the corner where the flashing had that gap. The lights did their thrown-shoulder jerk, one-syllable gasp. The logger chime bit and held. I leaned in and read: L2: 101.4; L1: 127.8.

“Got you,” I said, not to the portrait and not to any person with opinions.

“Meaning?” Lila said.

“Meaning I’m calling it,” I said. “Loose neutral or damp junction. We isolate east wing branch. We open the first box on the run and find the lazy push-in and fix it with a real screw.”

Tom nodded like a man grateful for a verb. “And the flashing?”

“After the wind,” Lila said, and he exhaled like a valve and lifted his hands in a surrender he didn’t believe in.

The corridor steadied. The wind set to a low surf instead of a slap. The portrait dog did what dogs do: looked pleased with its own certainty. I taped the logger lead tighter, wrote the numbers clean—time, load, dip—and underlined with the pencil I favored for saying what would hold up.

“Print that,” Lila said, looking at the tiny sawteeth on the screen like they were the heartbeat of something unafraid.

“I’ll send you a plot,” I said. “With the gust times marked.”

She pushed her cap up a fraction, like making room for the concept. “So when Victor says ‘ghost,’ I can say, ‘wind.’”

“You can say ‘cause,’” I said. “And then point at the effect.”

“Cause and effect,” she said, tasting it. “I like that better than ghosts. Ghosts don’t hold ladders.”

Tom picked up his drop cloth and the tape and gave the linen cupboard door a pat with the palm, an apology for opening its back. “I’ll be at the box,” he said.

“I’ll be here,” I said.

Lila tilted her head again, listening. Not for the portrait. For the wind. For the way the building frowned and then let it go. “You know,” she said, voice small in the big corridor, “for once, I hope it’s a stupid little screw.”

“It’s a stupid little screw,” I said, because sometimes a thing can be what it is.

We waited for the next gust. The house obliged, and the numbers did what numbers do. I made the note and drew the line between them. That was the work. That was enough.

data.final_scene:
The CO puck gives a polite little bird-chirp as I step off the gravel and pull the shed door. The wind takes the handle and flings it wide, and the rain comes in sideways like grit. I shoulder through, hook the jamb with my heel, and let the door slam behind me to keep the spray out. The generator thuds a steady bass in the concrete bay, a mammal asleep and dreaming bad fuel. My handheld meter, clipped to my collar, blips once and wakes fully, the green diode flicking to amber.

“No,” I tell it. “Don’t start with me.”

The shed is a rectangle of corrugate and shadows. One fluorescent is half-dead, strobing in a way that makes the fan belt look like it’s turning backward. The air has that sweet-bitter diesel tang I smelled on Day One, but thicker now—warm, oily, breathy. The louvers on the far wall rattle in gusts, metal slats chattering like loose teeth. Every time the wind hits, they slap shut instead of opening, backwards to instruction, a fish gill trying to inhale the storm.

“Okay,” I say to the louver, to the fan, to the big green block of engine. “Show me.”

I thumb the meter into live view. CO: 18 ppm. Then 22. The number climbs with the next gust, like the storm itself is climbing down my throat. The CO puck on the wall near the exhaust elbow chirps again, a little more scolding. The concrete floor is spotted with ancient spills and this evening’s footprint of wet grit where I came in. The exhaust stack runs up and out to the louver wall, jacketed with fiberglass wrap that’s gone the color of nicotine.

Another gust. The louvers suck shut, a clap with a cuss-word under it. The generator note changes half a tone, as if the throat is being thumbed. The meter gives me 35. Then 42.

“Not a good number,” I tell it. “We’re not competing.”

I tug the buff over my nose out of reflex, like fabric can sort carbon monoxide, and step wide of the hot elbow, palms out to feel the air path. The fan on the intake is spinning but it whistles thinly when the louvers slam, starving. There’s a seam behind the control cabinet where someone cut a pass-through for cable and never foamed it tight, and now it breathes on my wrist with the rhythm of the gusts—out on the lull, in on the hit. The wind pressure’s turning the whole shed into a lung moving in the wrong sequence.

The meter beeps faster. 58. 63. My chest notices it before my head does—a shallow insistence, a little off on the inhale. The storm chooses that moment to put its shoulder into the hill; the whole building creaks, the fluorescent buzz dithers, and the louver bank slams hard enough that a screw sings on the steel sill and skitters toward the floor drain.

“Alright,” I say. “You win.”

The door is three steps behind me, and outside is cold, messy, and honest. Inside is warm and sweet and stupid. I hold between them a second too long, because there’s the impulse that has gotten me this far in every old house with every bad decision embedded in its walls: measure it now, while it’s happening, while the pressure’s right. Catch the thing in the act. Document it so when the storm passes I’m not left with a theory and a shrug.

The CO puck chirps again, and my meter goes 74, 79, 86. It looks like a heart rate accelerating before a sprint.

“Fine,” I say to the numbers, and to my own pigheadedness. “We’ll time it.”

I pop the meter’s bookmark button with my thumb to flag the spike, then move fast. First the door: I crack it, the wind puts its whole mouth on it and tries to take it away. The rain slices in and flecks the nearest conduit. The meter dips to 70, then 66, as the draft has somewhere to go. The generator coughs once and recovers.

“Crossflow,” I tell the room. “Basic physics. Be helpful.”

The louvers on the far wall are still refusing to act like louvers. They’re designed to fall open when the fan draws and slap shut against weather, but the wind is beating them shut even when the fan wants, and the exhaust plume has nowhere better to be than here with me. I find the broom—broom-ish, its bristles fused with oil and rust—and wedge it under my arm as I cross. I keep my shoulder clear of the exhaust cover. Heat comes off the muffler in sheets. I can hear the exhaust note reverberate off the closed slats and fold back, like yelling into your own hands.

“Don’t be clever,” I tell my feet, because the floor is slick, and the stain under the elbow is wider than I want to think about. The meter hits 92 and I feel a flicker in my temples like a neon sign trying to start.

I test the first louver frame with my knuckles—rattly, not that heavy—and hook my fingers under the bottom slat. It resists in a stubborn, spring-loaded way, and then the next gust helps me by sucking outward for a fraction of a second as the wind shifts, and I shove the slat to open. The fan grabs a gulp. The sound of the generator deepens, happier.

“Good,” I say, and jam the broken broom handle through the slats like a bayonet to keep them from slamming shut again. The wood seats with a bark and holds. The slats vibrate around it. Air moves, finally honest, rushing past my sleeve. The meter drops to 77, then 68.

I reach for the next louver bay and do the same. The first screw that sang to the floor is under my arch now; I feel it roll and step away quick, plant, and shove. The slat gives, and I wedge the broom’s splintered end into the frame. The handle splits with a dry crack. It still holds.

The shed’s air changes quality, like someone cut it with something clear. The diesel smell loses its sugar edge. Rain needles through the louver gap and snaps on the hot muffler with a hiss, but the plume tracks outward now instead of curling back. The meter slides down to 55. Then 49.

“Breathe,” I tell the room, and I listen while it does. The fan settles into work instead of complaint. The CO puck on the wall, cheerful liar, gives me one more warning chirp out of habit and then decides we’re friends again.

The wind hits in pulses. Each gust tries to shove the slats closed around the broken broom, but the prop holds, shuddering. The shed rattles like a drum on a kid’s knee. The fluorescent overhead tries out a steady voice and fails, humming.

I take the moment to kneel by the muffler in the zone that’s now a stream, not a pool, and click a fast set of notes on my phone—time stamp, storm peak, fan status, louver position, ppm trending. No poetry, just facts. I move the meter to the louver face and watch: the number spikes a little in the gust—52, 58—and then settles when the gust passes—44, 41. Near the door, with it set to a hand’s-width crack secured by my shoulder against a two-by-four, the air is cold enough to bite my wrist. The meter shows 28. Outside is better than inside by a factor that matters.

“Temporary,” I tell the broom handle. “You look heroic, but I don’t trust you.”

I scan the wall for anything sturdier. There’s a milk crate of nightmare hardware—random lag screws and anchors furred with rust—and a bent length of strut channel leaning by the fuel tank. The tank has a sight gauge with a bubble that wobbles when the wind goes hard. I slide the strut to my side, carry it to the louvers, and place it across both frames, a horizontal brace. I thread it through the slats above the broom handle, make a clumsy deadman out of it using the crate wedged against the baseboard. Ugly engineering, ugly storm. It holds because it has to.

The meter: 38. 36. When a gust shoulders the shed, the number rises to 45, then retreats. My head stops feeling bright. The air tastes like air again, not like an argument.

“Vent,” I tell myself. “Then measure.”

I swing the door wider, give it a loop of twisted wire to the hinge so it can’t slam and trap me, and step into the head of the breeze. Rain finds the back of my neck, but that’s just water. The generator drones on, oblivious, doing the one job it knows how to do. The plume streams out and disappears into the gray like breath into winter.

I work the perimeter quickly for other sins that will come back the next gust—rag on the floor too close to the elbow, pitch it into a bucket; cardboard leaning against the fuel tank, flatten it and tuck it under the crate; the cable pass-through I felt earlier, I jam in a piece of closed-cell foam pulled off a shipping block and swipe tape over it. Every little leak is a mouth. I make them swallow the right way.

The meter, now clipped to my shirt pocket, drops—31, 27—and steadies. I log the numbers, the louver hack, the wind speed by ear and the way the rain strips off the eave in sheets. I slide the CO puck off its mount and press its test; it complains dutifully and flashes, which is all I need from it now.

“Alright,” I say to the room, and to the storm should it be listening. “You get to be a shed again.”

Another gust comes, hardest yet. The far corrugate wall flexes, the brace hums like a string, and the plumber’s strap on the muffler vibrates its own harmony. The louvers try to slam and fail, held open just enough. My meter takes one more leap—40—and then drops to 33 as the air rips through. I stand in the doorway with my shoulder to the jamb, for balance, for a position that keeps a path to outside always in sight.

“Stay or go,” I tell myself, low. “Stay and stare, or go and live.”

The numbers answer me for once without needing me to argue with them. They’re trending down. The trend, not the absolute, is what teaches. I look at the brace, at the broom pegged like an improvised splint, at the rain slicing through the gap and streaking black on the muffler casing. It’s not elegant. It’s safe enough for now.

I take one last sweep of the meter across the space—by the control panel (25), behind the engine where turbulence gets tricky (29), at the floor where heavier air likes to sulk (24). Then I pull the door wider and let the storm have its vent path. My fingers are stinging from the cold; the rest of me is too warm from standing in diesel breath.

“Hold,” I tell the louver. “Hold and I’ll come back with screws when the world stops trying to tear itself in half.”

The generator thuds on, unconcerned with human remarks. The broom handle creaks like a tired knee and stays.

I step back into the rain, meter still talking to me in its calm, numerical voice. Behind me the shed keeps breathing the right way, and the numbers on my pocket climb down like a child getting off a fence. I pull the door to a safe, wired-open angle, set a cone of rock at its foot so no one can let it slip shut by accident, and write my last line of the moment with a pencil that has known worse wet than this: Day 85, 18:47, storm peak. CO spike at louvered exhaust due to wind-driven backdraft. Propped louvers, established crossflow, ppm trending down. Space vented.

“Enough,” I say, and the wind takes the word and shreds it for me, so I don’t have to keep carrying it around.

The east wing hall is the coldest place in the house that isn’t actually outside. My breath doesn’t fog—it’s not that cold—but the air has that polished feel, scraped thin by the storm and left to ring. The floorboards return my steps with hollow patience. The portraits here are the ones without eyes that follow; these ones stare past you, like bad acoustics hanging on plaster.

“Okay,” I tell the hall, mostly for the recorder’s benefit. “Day eighty-five. Post-squall. East wing.”

The motion sensor I taped to the fire door near the junction box throws a tiny green pulse as I pass. The main breaker for this wing is still up—the stutter earlier didn’t trip anything—but most of the fixtures at this hour are off. My headlamp gives me enough to see the smudging of old trades at the return grilles: greasy thumb arcs, paint scuffs where someone once levered them, the hairline crack along the top screw hole that lets the grille breathe even when it’s set tight.

I kneel at the first grille, the one just before the corner to the linen alcove, and slide my hand near the slots. The skin on the back of my fingers tells me what the meter will say anyway: the hall is under a slight negative. Outside gusts push, the house takes in, the big metal maze answers.

I clip the lapel mic off my collar and aim it directly at the grille. The recorder in my pocket glows a soft, bureaucratic blue. I tap twice on the grille, a reflex I haven’t unlearned since ductwork first started telling me more truth than people did.

From the far inside, behind the slats and the cavity, something answers me, not a tap, but a shift. A tone wraps itself down the run from somewhere high and to the right; it’s not voice, but it sketches the shape of one. Syllables without vowels. Our suspect.

“Noted,” I say, neutral. “Wind-driven resonance suspected. Proceeding to set B.”

I move down to the second grille, by the old map case. I’d placed a dedicated recorder here before sunset—fresh battery, low-cut off, gain fixed, dead cat that looks obscene against the antique oak. I pull it gently into the oval of my headlamp and click to stop, then hit play without moving anything else, earbuds in.

The hall disappears, replaced by the hall a few hours ago. The squall at its height sounds like a chorus trying not to exist. I hear the lights surge—a faint electrical rattle that microphones always make grander than it felt—and then, clean as a penny dropping into a glass, the “whispers.” Long, then short, then a break. The timbre is the same as old radiators when they almost-sing: metal being made to behave like wind instruments by someone who doesn’t understand or care that this is a house.

I scrub back and forth across the file with my thumb, hitting the same thirty seconds over and over, isolating in my head the resonance from the wideband noise. My brain, being the inconvenient animal that it is, insists on syllables. Hhhah. Ssshhha. Üh. The patterning is enough to seduce. It’s also enough to measure.

“Okay,” I say, past my own ears, addressing the recording. “You get to be pressure, not ghosts.”

I pull the handheld anemometer from the side pocket of the pack and the tiny baro that logs at one-second intervals. It’s still clipping data from when I left it on the sill of the east casement, where the wind would see it but the rain only a little. I sync clocks: recorder timestamp, baro timestamp, my wristwatch, the mains frequency tick on the surge protector. When you do this enough you stop trusting whichever clock tells the prettiest story.

I squat with my back to the wainscoting and open the laptop on my knees, the keyboard a field of cold coins. The hall gives me just enough signal to pull a weather station feed I bookmarked the first night: creekside, at the bend. Gusts recorded accurately to the second, with direction. I download the window that brackets my squall, and the log of my baro, and the audio file I just pulled off the mini.

“Run,” I tell it. There’s no audience, so I don’t bother with any flair.

The spectrogram blooms across the laptop, a smudge painting of the storm’s voice. The “whispers” are clear as bands, not as noise. They sit at 126 Hz, 251 Hz, 383 Hz, and a higher partial that isn’t pretty enough to care about. My left hand drifts without permission to the notebook on the floor and lists the numbers. My right hand, meanwhile, draws the hypothesis line without me thinking: duct length approximated at—what, twenty-nine feet?—return to vertical riser—transition at slightly offset angle—termination likely at attic plenum with louvers that rattle when the wind insists.

I pull up the crude diagram I drew last night after crawling the understair return: east wing main runs parallel to the hall, branch taps toward rooms every twelve feet, with long elbows at the far end that turn into the old chase behind the linen alcove. The old house added modern lungs on top of an anatomy made for coal heat. The new parts always sing when the old bones tell them to.

I put the mic back on and do a quick controlled breath into the grille: steady, then pulsed. The hall gives the faintest change to the tone; the fundamental holds like a rung in the dark. I check the angle of the slots, the dust pattern, the gasket’s age. The screen behind the grille buzzes when I speak next, not because it recognizes my voice, but because a G2 is in motion.

“Secondary test,” I say, short. I set the phone to a tone generator, hold it flush to the grille, and sweep from 80 Hz to 200 Hz at a constant amplitude. When I hit 126, the duct gives itself to me like a fork resonating. The wood around it agrees in a small way, sympathetic.

I click the recorder back on and announce the sweep aloud. I keep it robotic: “One-two-six, one-two-five, one-two-seven.” The return makes a hollow mimicry that a person could call a whisper if they were alone and the lights chose that moment to stutter. We do not rely on that.

From the path beyond the hall, the east door flexes in its frame with a sound like a man clearing his throat.

“Good,” I say, to the data. “Stay honest for five more minutes.”

I cross to the end of the hall and shoulder into the cold space behind the linen alcove, where the access panel is a rectangle of paint over old screws. Someone painted it shut a decade before I was born; someone else tested it recently with a knife tip. I lever it gently at the seam and listen—not through the panel, but above it. The riser hum is more felt than heard. Old tin, still working.

The panel resists every polite request. Fine. I don’t need to see to measure. Instead, I tape the little green differential meter to the wall and run a short bit of silicone hose through the crack at the top of the grille down the hall. The meter reads the pressure across the hall face: a whisper of a pascal change when the wind puffs at the casualty tarp still up on the scaffolding outside. Inputs match outputs; nobody is sneaking anything in with strings.

“Log it,” I say. I tap the log button with my knuckle and the indicator blinks into a dull blink rhythm.

I go back to the laptop and align the time bars. The gusts at the creek bend arrive three seconds after the squall breaks on the bay; here, filtered through hill and hedgerow and a hundred small obstructions, they hit our facade eleven seconds later than the creek. The “whisper” events on the audio land exactly thirteen seconds before the peak negative pressure inside by the baro, two seconds after the gust strike outside. The duct length would explain two seconds at the speeds we’re seeing. The rest is the house exhaling what it took in. The math makes a shape that holds in my hands without sloshing.

“Say it,” I tell myself. I hate saying it without a second person as witness, but the recorder is what we have. “Audio anomalies in east wing hall return grilles coincide with gust fronts recorded at creek bend station and on-site barometric dips. Dominant frequencies at 126 Hz, 251 Hz, 383 Hz correlate to calculated quarter-wave and odd harmonic resonances for estimated return run length of twenty-nine to thirty-one feet with one ninety and one forty-five degree elbow. On-site tone sweep confirms. Conclusion: wind-driven duct resonance.”

Something in the duct shifts a fraction when I say the word “wind.” It would be comedy if I let it. I don’t.

The conflict, the part of my brain that eats ambiguity like candy, holds out the possibility that someone could time a whisper to a gust. Humans love to insert themselves into physics. Fine. I drag open the segment where the most distinct “phrase” happens and solo the 126 Hz band, then the 251. When I remove the fundamentals, the words die. You can make a human voice sound like a wind organ with a filter; you cannot make a wind organ sound like a human voice without the fundamentals. That is as clean as we get without opening walls.

Behind me, floorboard six from the corner pops, as it always does when temperature falls. I mark the ambient drop. My headlamp throws a moon-white circle on the paint; the paint refuses to be history, only film. The hall smells faintly of raw wood where the storm licked something at the far end under the threshold.

I ring Victor’s “authorized personnel” line out of habit, then remember the hour and cancel before it connects. Wouldn’t matter; he’d say this was good. He likes words like proven. I prefer numbers like checked.

The recorder hisses a tiny affirmative noise when I stop the file. I pull the card and back it up to the laptop and the portable drive and the drive that never leaves my body. Redundancy is not paranoia; it’s respect for time. The spectrogram export takes a beat; in that beat, the house sighs around me, equalizing.

I pull a fresh page on the notebook and block out the report before the adrenaline can trick me into chasing one more measurement.

Outline:

- Title: East Wing Hall—Wind-Driven Duct Resonance Analysis (Day 85, 22:14–23:02)
- Instruments: Recorder A (hall return, fixed), Recorder B (mobile, cardioid), Barometric logger (sill), Handheld anemometer (yard), External station feed (Creek Bend AWS)
- Conditions: Post-squall, intermittent gusts NW 22–31 kt, temp drop 4°C/hour, doors/windows per status sheet
- Observations: Audible “whisper” events at returns; spectral bands 126/251/383 Hz; no speech content above 500 Hz independent of harmonics
- Methods: Time-sync across devices; FFT windows Hanning 1024; correlation analysis between gust front timestamps and spectral intensity peaks; on-site tone sweep; differential pressure logging at grille
- Calculations: Estimated duct length and geometry; quarter-wave resonance check; speed of sound at measured temperature
- Results: High correlation (r=0.86) between gust events and resonance onset; repeatability across multiple gusts; elimination test via tone sweep
- Conclusion: Anomalies attributable to wind-induced resonance in east wing return duct; no further anomalous human-source indicators in this time window
- Recommendations: Install return baffles or Helmholtz resonators; gasket replacement at grille; optional white-noise damper; include audio and spectrogram figures

I read it back once in my head, then once aloud to the room, which does not care as long as it can keep doing what it’s always done.

“Anything else?” I ask it, out of habit. “Anything we missed?”

The duct says nothing, which is a courtesy. The wind tests the east facade, gets nothing fun back, moves on. I collect the sidewalk of gear I’ve just made and put it back into the corrals on my body: meter pouch, side zip, laptop sleeve. The hall gives me back my footsteps as if they were borrowed.

At the fire door, I stop with my hand on the bar and dictate the final line into the recorder, in the same tone I reserve for writing on forms with small boxes and no character. “Audio plus wind data aligned. Attribution: wind resonance. Report in draft.”

I push the bar with two fingers, feel the outside’s chill slide in and the inside’s warmth yield without any melodrama. The house wants a machine’s kind of order; tonight I let it have that. I relock the door behind me with the prying tool sticking out to hold the latch, a crude lockout so no one gets cute in the next hour.

On the way back through the east wing, I pause at the second grille and listen one more time with my headlamp off. Nothing speaks. The absence has a frequency, too. I note it and keep walking.

data.final_scene:
Ruth’s office has the geometry of a dictation—everything squared to something else, everything abbreviated. Files stand in ranks along the back wall behind glass that catches the gray of the morning. The radiator ticks one notch off from the hallway’s baseboard heater, and the difference draws a faint thread of air across my ankles. Outside the window, the north lawn is a sheet of flattened grass and stiffer wind, but in here the air has the weight of old paper and coffee gone to bark.

“Sit,” she says, not looking up yet. Her pencil makes a clean ruled line, then a second, then a quick erase as if to bring the line into conformity with itself. The desk is deep walnut, the chair I take built too upright for lounging and upholstered in a pattern that pretends to be leaves. On the bookshelf nearest me, three binders are labeled in spine tape: Insurance—Facilities, Permits—Historical, and Access—Keys (Active). The last one has a rubber band around it like a belt.

She closes the ledger under her hands and palms it to the left without stacking it. Then she lifts a flat drawer out of a flat-file cabinet and sets it, arms wide, across the blotter. The paper inside is heavy and blue—true diazo, older than my mother. When she pulls the cover sheet away the smell comes up: ammonia burned into linen, dust that was once white hands.

“1911,” she says. “Second revision, after they added the service wing for the laundry.” Her voice is even, but she watches my face the way she watches ledgers: checking for irregularities that will require a footnote. “These stay in here. You can look, you can photograph. You will not use tape. You will not lean on them. This is me saying that politely.”

“Understood.”

She produces a second bundle from a brown envelope with a shredded string tie. The paper is cheaper—inkjet on copy stock—but the lines run in a different hand entirely: purposeful, crowded with arrows, annotations in the margin in a slanted block print that taps at my chest when I recognize it. Daniel’s. Airflow rates, return sizes, a crude CFD block diagram sketched out with a blue pen. There are little cartoon triangles he used to mark direction, a private compass rose.

“Where did you—?”

“His car,” Ruth says. “The night you arrived, we inventoried what we’re obligated to secure. His backpack was on the floorboard under a sweatshirt. I kept this back because I wanted to see if we had the architectural baseline to check his assumptions.” She taps the corner of the plan set with her fingernail. “We do.”

She stands before I do and takes the top blueprint by two corners, smooths it with the flat of her hand, and rotates it one quarter turn so north points to the window. Greystone reorients itself: the east wing is now to my right on paper, though to my left in the world. Elevations march down one side like school portraits. Someone in 1911 took pride in their shading.

“Here,” she says, and her pencil surprises me by being silver—not graphite. It’s a mechanical pencil with a needle-point lag bolt of a lead. She hovers, not touching, over a square on the plan where the east wing pinches in to meet the central block. “This—Service Stair Two. It’s not on the current life safety map because the opening was closed before the last update. The State Office of Historic Preservation signed off on the closure when they reconfigured the laundry in seventy-nine.” She glances at me. “Before you were born, yes.”

“It’s not on my walk-through,” I say. “I hit two stairs: the grand and the back by the pantry.”

“That’s why I didn’t tell you on day one.” She folds her hands on the desk. “We don’t encourage exploration of closed spaces. There are reasons beyond the melodramatic.”

I let the silence sit exactly long enough to be polite. Then I slide Daniel’s sketch over the same location. He has drawn pressure arrows that converge and then sidle away as if embarrassed. The notation in the margin reads: “Odd: static spike here when bell chimed. Re-check.”

I point. “His spike is at the junction between this stairwell chase and the east return plenum. If the stair’s boxed in, that’s a dead volume. It would oscillate on gusts.”

“Or contain lead paint, loose plaster, mouse nests and all the liability a county can muster,” Ruth says. “You see my problem.”

“I see your problem and raise you mine,” I say. “You hired me to replace myths with mechanics. If this vertical void couples to the returns, it will be a factor. If it’s sealed, I want to know how, where, and with what.”

Her face does not move much when she is thinking. The eyes narrow, but not in suspicion; it’s more like focusing on a distant road sign. She lifts the next sheet: a section through the east wing. The line weight thickens where the plaster stops and brick begins. In the crosshatch is the stair run, flight by flight, with a small square symbol at each landing that denotes a vent grille. It is all lit from above in the drafter’s mind; the arrows repeat the same diagrammatic motion Daniel drew without knowing they already had.

“You’re thinking the closure was superficial,” I say. “Plasterboard over a door, not a fill.”

“I’m thinking we do not make that call without a wall scanner and two adults present,” she says. Then, softer: “I’m thinking Daniel wrote ‘odd’ and you’re here.”

Her right hand moves almost by itself to the corner of the desk where she keeps a single key on a coil bracelet. She does not pick it up. She takes her hand away again.

“We’ll do the scanner,” I say. “We’ll do photos, we’ll do a dust mask. We won’t do demolition. We can at least mark the point on the map and check if there’s an access panel in the baseboard.”

“You love a baseboard,” she says, finally a trace of humor. It passes and her face returns to the set she wears when contractors call and say they went through a pipe. “Ten minutes, and I come. Then I go back to three people waiting in the kitchen to be told they can’t use microwaves for a day because someone rewired a dead outlet to a live plate cover.”

“I’m in awe,” I say, and I am, because there is a kind of competence that looks like boredom from the outside and like a held line from the inside.

Ruth gathers the plans in reverse: section, plan, elevation. She keeps Daniel’s sketch separate, folds it once with neat hands, and tucks it under a legal pad that has today’s date at the top and a list in a left-hand column, each item with a box. Two boxes are checked already. She flips the cover down over it. She lifts the flat drawer back to the cabinet shelf. She leaves the drawer pulled so the humidity can be what it wants under there.

“Bring your pen,” she says.

The hallway outside her door has its own climate. The light is the particular pale you get from glass that still has ripples in it. Half the sconces are off because the painter never reinstalled two bulbs. On the left, the portraits go cold-eyed to the corner and turn with you. “I’m trying to give it less,” I say, just as low. “I know that sounds like a trick.”
