data.final_scene:
I killed the line to Lila and slid the phone deep in my pocket so it would stop chiming with wet little ghosts of my own voice. The hatch lip had collected rain and my knuckles made a sound like tapping a jellyfish when I knocked to see if the sandbag would give me anything. It didn’t. The building breathed once—inhale from the west, exhale out the hatch—then went back to holding itself.

“Hey,” I said into the dark. “We’re not doing this in a storm. Come talk.”

No answer. A pendulum tremor feathered my fingers where they lay on the sill. The bell hadn’t rung, but some other hung thing had remembered its job and wagged its tongue once.

I put my shoulder to the hatch and counted through it. On three the sandbag grudgingly sledded a palm’s width and I got my left hand past the jamb into the throat of the tower chase. The cleat where the rope bit at an angle was right there, slicked like a pastry—resin, honey-hard but wet-slicked now, fresh enough to pull strings when I pressed. My fingers came back shining. I couldn’t smell anything past the storm a minute ago; now the resin pushed up through it, old pine and a chemical that didn’t belong in a church.

“You’re not even hiding it,” I said. “You want me to feel it.”

Something above shifted with a quiet felt through bone more than heard. Not footsteps—weight being persuaded along a track, the dull soft complaint of burlap changing minds. The chain that served the counterweight lay slack, but the coil beyond the corner twitched like a startled animal and then went still, hanging beads of rain, each fat drop reflecting my flashlight spot as a star.

“Careful with the counterweight,” I said, because it was all my mouth knew to say.

The beam cut the corner to the right where the chase tightened. There was only a foot of floor past the hatch—a shelf of old pine and pigeon scurf—before the wall cut left and climbed tight around the rope. The ceiling above the shelf was open to rough masonry and the square throat up to the bell. If there was someone, they were two turns up and hugging stone, working by feel. I could almost plot where their hands were by the way fresh resin stung my nose—somebody had lacquered every place you would grab.

I hooked my elbow around the cleat and leaned in farther. Rain ran down my sleeve, climbed my arm hair, gathered at my armpit, and dumped. I felt ridiculous and cold and also aware that I was about to fall face-first into a space designed for equipment, not people.

“Listen,” I said, voice steady because that’s the trick. “Drop the bag and get away from the rope. You’re getting somebody hurt.”

A reply came, finally: a single clink as if a hook kissed stone. Not language. My own breath came back to me sour and metallic after it bounced off wet rock.

I wedged the pry bar under the sandbag and levered. The bag was obedient when I convinced myself I meant it; it skidded, spilled a little gravel, and the hatch got me another two inches. I slid my shoulder in, rotating like a snake with a mortgage, and planted my right palm on the chase floor—straight into a puddle of resin thinned with rain, invisible in the dark. It went between my fingers, webbing them. When I pulled, there was resistance, a string that thinned and made a sound I’d only ever heard in a shop when you peel tape off a roll with the room quiet enough to make it obscene.

“You’re coating this on purpose,” I said into the wood. “That’s your thing tonight?”

A sliding noise above me, fast, then the soft slap of rope against stone. Instinct sent my left hand without permission to catch it. I grabbed and the rope moved through my palm hot and alive, resin grabbing, then letting go with a stick-slip that burned me in taste as much as pain. I swore and kept my hand closed out of anger more than sense. The rope stopped, humming, not with bell weight but with somebody else’s weight transmitted down it like a conversation you feel through a table.

“You’re right there,” I said, pushing breath up into that shaft. “Two turns. You’re right there.”

Another clink, sharper. A bit of grit came down and grainy rainwater with it, marking my eyelids. I blinked my beam out of my own pupils and caught something: a shadow shift, not a person but the absence of light where light had been a second before. Someone had pinched the lantern glow—no, there was no lantern. It was just the way the storm light moved and the rope wag caught it. I talked because you keep talking at coyotes so they remember you have a tool in your hand.

“Get smart,” I said. “Storm’s not letting up. You’re in a chimney.”

The building replied with a sigh. Pressure pushed the hatch back against my ribs, stalling me. The pry bar squealed in its bite. The sandbag used the excuse to creep back toward the hole it wanted, dragging my courage with it an inch. I got a knee up onto the shelf, got my boot sole onto something that wasn’t quite wood and wasn’t quite stone, and let my weight speak for me.

The shelf flexed. That old pine said hey in a voice that manors use when they’ve been asked to hold one more thing and they will, but they want you to know they’re doing you a favor. I held still. I could see up now: the square throat narrowing, the braided rope rivered with gummy amber, a smear on the jamb where someone had grabbed earlier with a full palm and slid. The smear had fingerprints in it ridged like topography and shiny where the rain hadn’t got to yet. I held my light on it. If I had been a different kind of person I would have photographed it first. I was not that person under a hatch in a squall with my boot flexing old timber.

The chain beyond the corner rattled again and then a dull thud answered from farther up—something put down, not dropped. An unseen hand keeping promises to gravity. The rope jumped once, enough to pop tack in its glaze, and went lax a fraction.

“Don’t,” I said, uselessly. “Don’t—”

I felt the air move before the sound got hashed up in the rain: a small hatch high above breathed open. Wind forced its language down at me. A cold draft blew resin smell from above past my teeth. Whoever was up there had found a vent or a slit and taken it. Air made the sandbag’s life easier; it slid, I grunted, the pry bar skipped, and the hatch took the chance to knee me in the sternum as it tried to reset. I shoved back and got a mouthful of old wet wood for my trouble.

My left palm slipped on resin and I caught myself with the heel, which made a nice coherent print of my entire hand on the cleat face just where the rope used to cross. I saw it clearly: my own hand in amber, a cartoon fossil next to someone else’s smear.

“Great,” I told the unseen ringer. “Now we’re both here.”

I listened. The space above had changed. The hush that comes when someone stops moving and holds their breath had been replaced by the quiet that says no one’s there to hold one. Not absence, exactly. An emptiness with an intention gone out of it. The chain was still. The rope did its little old-house jig with the wind and nothing more.

I eased the pry bar back into place and worked the sandbag an inch, then another, grunting, elbows squeaking on wet wood. When I had enough gap to force my shoulders through sideways, I pushed my head up into the chase. The wall was close enough to scrape my ear. The resin slicked my cheek and I tasted pine and solvent and a memory of church basements.

I let the hatch push me back to the porch line by line. The sandbag resettled with the contentment of a sleeping dog whose human has finally given up making it move. I stood, hissed a little when my burned palm opened all the way, and looked at what I had.

I pressed two knuckles next to it by instinct to measure and left two half-moons of my own.

I wiped my hands on my jeans and that just made my jeans part of the evidence. The resin didn’t want to leave me; it liked me now.

“Enjoy your chimney,” I said to the person who had taken the wind out. “We’ll do this your way for tonight.”

The bell above said nothing. Rain argued with every horizontal surface and won. The east wall hummed with storm the way lath hums when it’s remembering a carpenter. I stood with the hatch at my thigh and let the building breathe me in and out until my shoulders dropped from my ears.

When I backed off the porch, I did it slow, like you do with a dog you’re not sure about. I kept my eyes on the square of dark. I made it to the gravel and stones without the tower doing anything else to me except keep the resin on my skin.

The building breathed once—inhale from the west, exhale out the hatch—then went back to holding itself.

“Hey,” I said into the dark. “We’re not doing this in a storm. Come talk.”

No answer. A pendulum tremor feathered my fingers where they lay on the sill. The bell hadn’t rung, but some other hung thing had remembered its job and wagged its tongue once.

I put my shoulder to the hatch and counted through it. On three the sandbag grudgingly sledded a palm’s width and I got my left hand past the jamb into the throat of the tower chase. The cleat where the rope bit at an angle was right there, slicked like a pastry—resin, honey-hard but wet-slicked now, fresh enough to pull strings when I pressed. My fingers came back shining. I couldn’t smell anything past the storm a minute ago; now the resin pushed up through it, old pine and a chemical that didn’t belong in a church.

“You’re not even hiding it,” I said. “You want me to feel it.”

Something above shifted with a quiet felt through bone more than heard. Not footsteps—weight being persuaded along a track, the dull soft complaint of burlap changing minds. The chain that served the counterweight lay slack, but the coil beyond the corner twitched like a startled animal and then went still, hanging beads of rain, each fat drop reflecting my flashlight spot as a star.

“Careful with the counterweight,” I said, because it was all my mouth knew to say.

The beam cut the corner to the right where the chase tightened. There was only a foot of floor past the hatch—a shelf of old pine and pigeon scurf—before the wall cut left and climbed tight around the rope. The ceiling above the shelf was open to rough masonry and the square throat up to the bell. If there was someone, they were two turns up and hugging stone, working by feel. I could almost plot where their hands were by the way fresh resin stung my nose—somebody had lacquered every place you would grab.

I hooked my elbow around the cleat and leaned in farther. Rain ran down my sleeve, climbed my arm hair, gathered at my armpit, and dumped. I felt ridiculous and cold and also aware that I was about to fall face-first into a space designed for equipment, not people.

“Listen,” I said, voice steady because that’s the trick. “Drop the bag and get away from the rope. You’re getting somebody hurt.”

A reply came, finally: a single clink as if a hook kissed stone. Not language. My own breath came back to me sour and metallic after it bounced off wet rock.

I wedged the pry bar under the sandbag and levered. The bag was obedient when I convinced myself I meant it; it skidded, spilled a little gravel, and the hatch got me another two inches. data.final_scene:
Day 87 started in the service corridor with the light the color of skim milk and my toolkit already sweating. The house smelled like a thrift shop humidifier: hot dust, old linen, coil-funk. I slid the 1911 plan set out on the rolling cart and Daniel’s airflow sketch beside it, weighted with a wrench so the vellum wouldn’t lift in the backdraft. “Okay,” I told the arrows and dotted lines. “Your turn.”

The corridor was a rabbit run of plaster and duct, blind turns where maids once flattened themselves to let trays go by. The returns I wanted loomed like black mouths low in the walls: oval grilles with a little lace of rust, paint flecking around the screw heads. When the supply fan on the basement air handler spooled, they sang a note just south of human hearing. The rumor called it whispering. The manometer on my hip said it was a hiss and a pressure drop with manners.

I set the kit down, popped the latches. Out came magnetic covers, cut to size with rubber edges; gaffer’s tape; foam core blanks; a handful of cut muslin “flags” on painter’s tape to see the draw; a portable differential gauge with two snake hoses; incense sticks for smoke; the tablet showing CO and audio feeds already cartwheeling their little graphs.

“Protocol,” I said, and hit record on my phone. “Day 87, oh eight hundred. Test one. Objective: force pressure shifts, isolate duct-borne audio, compare to alleged whisper events. Plan: close targeted returns in east hall and service corridor, open music-room bay to establish relief path, create controlled negative at known node, observe.”

The first return was at shin height behind a library door that never shut level. I set two magnets to find steel under the layer of paint. “Thank you.” The cover took and the note dropped out of the hall like someone had turned off a refrigerator. I taped the edges anyway, pressing with my burned palm and hissing through my teeth. Resin in the grooves of my hand pulled lint. “You don’t get a voice in this,” I told the grille.

At the next elbow, the corridor widened to let the old service stair access a dumbwaiter. I bent and listened. A wind in a throat. I held a muslin flag in the gap; it snapped hard toward the return. “Hungry.” Tape, magnet, tape. The sound dwindled and the corridor lost its breathy rasp.

An old work light haloed the dust I’d kicked up. Mouse turds, fragments of drywall, a button that had been stepped on fifty years ago. I pulled the differential lines and burped them into the gauge, then pressed one port to the corridor and one to the east hall. The display nodded: plus point zero three inches water column hall to corridor with the returns open; trending to near zero as I choked them. The audio feed on the tablet flattened in the high frequencies as the ducts went quiet. From the dining room mic, the house now sounded like a house.

“Mark,” I said. “Corridor returns A and B sealed. Audio drop of thirteen dB at one kilohertz on duct mic. No whisper band present.”

I moved to the elbow by the linen press, where the rumors always put the “please, please” voice. There the return grille had been kicked sometime in the last decade and one screw had gone missing. It thrummed like a harmonica reed. I held the incense to it. The smoke shot sideways and curled into the steel slots, then came right back out a quarter inch from where it had gone in, the eddies carving little question marks in the air.

“You, you’re coming offline.” Tape, magnet, a firm hand. The pitch hiccuped and died. The incense smoke stopped its acrobatics and just became smoke again, curling lazy, bereft of direction. “Mark: linen press return sealed. Subjective whispering at this location terminates.”

I spoke to the tablet. “Yeah? How do you like that?” The audio timeline made a smooth belly curve down. The CO trace held steady at background. The house didn’t argue, which wasn’t like it, but it was morning and it hadn’t had its coffee.

At the end of the corridor, I cracked the fire door to the east wing hall and let the door closer hold it two fingers shy of latch. Cool air licked my ankles. I set flags along the jamb and watched the pull. A mild drift from hall to corridor, obedient, all in the right direction. Dog on a leash.

“Phase two,” I told the cart. “Open bay, music room.”

The music room bay had three casements that folded out onto the lawn like a hinged greenhouse. The top sash cords were intact and the brass latches had a tiny gnash pattern where someone habitually worried them with a coin. I set my shoulder under the center sash, lifted; it stuck and then yielded with a soft fart of weatherstrip. The room exhaled into the spring cold with such relief I could hear the parquet creak.

I wheeled the box fan into the bay well and set it facing out, not on full—there’s domination and then there’s measurement—just enough to be a consistent exhaust. I taped muslin flags along the valance, along the door back to the hall, on the edge of the baby grand’s polished lid for fun. They all leaned obediently toward the bay, attending. The smell of old polish and embalmed violets ran outward too, replaced by a cut of the river and wet leaf.

“Mark,” I said. “Bay open, exhaust on low. Establishing negative in music room relative to corridor.”

The gauge puffed and settled. Minus point zero two inches WC in the room, corridor now slightly positive to it. The corridor flags swapped direction with the precision of a marching band. The duct whispers stayed gone.

“Now let’s see your trick,” I told the east hallway.

I walked the length of the hall, past family faces who’d watched too many turnings of air. I set incense in the brackets of the return vents I’d left open for controls. Smoke went in and didn’t come back out; no eddies, no rhythm to catch the voice. A child could not have asked to be let in with this airflow. A coward couldn’t have crooned. The rumor required an instrument; I had taken the reed from its mouth.

From the side corridor, the phone pinged. Carla had texted a single word: Status? I snapped a shot of the flags all leaning toward the music-room bay and the gauge face with its modest negative and sent it with: Live. Whispers off on cue.

I walked back to the cart and put on nitrile gloves to keep from giving the resin a new home. “Test three,” I told the phone. “Increment exhaust to medium. Confirm no emergent tones, watch CO.”

The fan gave me a useful hum when I clicked it up. The flags kicked, the curtains nuzzled the windows like cats, and somewhere in the crawl above the pantry a forgotten candy wrapper made a high, annoyed whine for half a second and then shut up as I taped its little edge down through the gap. The CO stayed at baseline. The duct mics stayed smooth, pure HVAC boredom.

“Mark: music-room bay provides adequate relief for wing. Rumor-driven pattern does not survive modified pressure regime.” I let the formality of it steady me. It did. The house had always liked rules, even when it pretended otherwise.

On my way back to the service corridor I closed the door between the trophy hall and the solarium by exactly two degrees and watched the flags shift; a tiny boundary change made a tiny change in flow, the kind that became a voice when the duct addicts found a note. I noted it, measured it, and made it unimportant.

By the laundry chute I found one more return I’d missed behind a wicker hamper. The grille was flush with the wallboard, hiding under a layer of cream paint that had rolled a perfect scallop into each slat. I slid the magnet over it, felt the tug, smiled, and gave it its cover. “Shh,” I said, for me more than for it. The return said nothing at all.

Back at the cart, I lined up the covers I hadn’t used in case this had to be replicated. I wrote locations on the tape tails: LP, LIB, SC-2, MRM bay. I took photographs at each stop, the kind with fingers in frame for scale and arrows in Sharpie pointing to the nothing that mattered. I liked my handwriting best when it was on tape.

I took one last pass with the incense. The smoke went where I told it. The little muslin flags held the line. The tablet showed a flat, blank comfort of fans doing fan things. My phone captured each “mark” and timestamped it like a metronome. I put my ear to the wall where Lila had written in her log that she’d heard the words between two and four in the morning. The plaster was cool. Behind it, air moved in a way that couldn’t form syllables; it was a river at six inches per second, steady and headstrong.

“All right,” I said, stepping back, voice low so it wouldn’t stir anything I hadn’t planned. “We play by my rules for a while.”

I logged the final state. Returns sealed as specified. Bay open one sash width, exhaust on medium. Doors set at angles, noted. Baseline achieved. Controlled test established.

The house breathed the way I wanted it to breathe. I let it. Then I sat on the rolling cart and watched the flags for a minute, like a firefighter staring at a watch pot to keep it from boiling. The building stayed obedient. The rumors, if they needed air, would have to find a new lung.
